summary: General Commercial and Public zoned areas in the Downtown Commercial Core are exempt from parking mandates.
Parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking, public parking and proximity to transit. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums for nonresidential uses.
The C-1 Central Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates.
Non-residential uses in the C-3 central business district are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No off-street parking facilities are required in the C-4 Central Business District.
Existing buildings within the Central Business (CB) district are exempt from parking requirements. On-street parking may count towards minimums for new development in the district.
The C-2 Central Business Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums.
Commercial uses in the downtown commercial (C-1) area (North and South Main Street from Lehr Avenue to Highland Avenue) are exempt from parking mandates.
The following area is exempt from off-street automobile parking requirements: Blocks 82, 83, 84, 90, 91, 92, 93, 96, 97, 98, 99, 100, 104, 105, 106 and 107, all in the original townsite of the city.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Within the TOD Transit Oriented Development District, on-street parking may count towards parking requirements and nonresidential uses under 2000 square feet are exempt from parking mandates. Housing for the elderly or for those with disabilities has a reduced requirement. Parking maximums also apply in the TOD District. County-wide, parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of motorcycle parking, EV chargers, or a TDM plan.
The B-3 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.

Off-street parking is not required for uses located in the Central Business District of the DB Zone District. In addition, off-street parking is not required for religious institutions located in any Historic District listed on the Aiken Historic Register.

Commercial developments within the Downtown Mixed Use District are exempt from the parking requirements. Surface parking may not exceed 125% of the minimum parking requirements within the DMU District.
Parking mandates only apply to apartments in the C Residence District, the E Industrial District, and to mobile homes.
The CBD Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Akron Ohio has no minimum requirements for parking for residential or commercial parking downtown.  Maximum allowed is one space per residence.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of motorcycle parking.

The Ashland and Cherryland Business District Specific Plan regulates a 246-acre area along two major streets in unincorporated Alameda County. Within the plan area, there are no minimum parking requirements for restaurants and small retail establishments. In most zones within the plan area, there are also no minimum requirements for offices, “general commercial”, gas stations, car washes, and automobile sales, rental, and repair establishments. For land uses where minimum parking requirements still apply, the requirements are generally lower than the County’s standard requirements. The plan sets maximum parking requirements for most land uses. At many residential developments, the plan also requires the unbundling of parking costs and the provision of designated spaces for carshare cars.
Effective 12/16/2021, Alameda has repealed parking requirements for all uses, citywide, and implemented maximums.
The C-1 Core Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Off-street vehicle parking is not required for any lot containing less than 5,000 square feet of gross site area or any property located within the Mixed-Use Downtown (MU-DT) District. Parking maximums apply to most uses. Parking reductions are available through the provision of frequent transit, on-street parking, a TDM plan or the payment of a fee-in-lieu of parking.
On June 14, 2023  Albany, OR eliminated parking mandates citywide for all uses. Parking maximums apply to all uses. The reforms were instigated by Oregon's statewide reforms.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Albemarle has no fixed parking ratios for nearly all uses other than: ADUs (one space required), selected home-based occupations (lawyers, physicians, dentists, and chiropractors), church tent uses, auction houses, and some light industrial uses.

Within the B-3 central business district, there is no requirement for off-street parking for properties located in parking maintenance district A, B or C. A description of the parking maintenance districts is filed in the office of the city clerk.
Permitted uses within the GC General Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements. A change of use in any district is exempt.
Bike parking may substitute for automobile parking in parking lots with 25 or more spaces.

In the C-2 Downtown Commercial District, on-street parking within 400 feet of the use may be included in the total required off-street parking, except for apartments. For Public Uses within a Residential District, on-street parking within 400 feet of the use may be included in the total required off-street parking, except for apartments.
On-street parking in the C-B, Central Business District may count towards parking requirements.

Albuquerque New Mexico has eliminated off street parking requirements in the downtown and SU-1 Transit Oriented Development.  They have also reduced parking minimums in many other areas and had on street parking account for off street parking by different reduction rates in areas like transit oriented developments.
Uses in the Commercial District, except for residential and lodging uses, may count on-street parking towards parking requirements.

No off street parking is required for buildings and uses located within the boundaries of the downtown area enclosed by NW/SW 3rd Avenue, SW/SE 4th Street, NE/SE 3rd Avenue, and NW/NE 2nd Street provided they are located within five hundred feet (500') of a public parking lot or an alternative parking plan is approved.
The B-1 Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Off-street parking is not be required in the CBD district for commercial uses. Parking maximums are set at 110 percent of the minimums unless any parking above the 110 percent threshold is pervious or is provided through use of structured parking.
Parking mandates may be waived for existing buildings in the Central Business District.

Alexandria has established maximum parking requirements In some commercial land uses and reduced minimum requirements in 'enhanced transit areas'. 

Additional reductions may be applied to multi-family/affordable housing land uses if in proximity to transit.
The BGC—Central general business district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Uses within the C-1 Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Within the C-5 Central Business District, retail, personal service, professional service, and residential uses are exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements are reduced within a special parking district along Park Avenue and Allen Road.

Off-street parking is not required for uses within the B-2 Central Business District except for residential uses consisting of five or more dwelling units. In such cases, and in the case of urban transition multifamily development within the B-5 District, the required number of spaces is 1/2 of the normal requirement for dwelling units. Off-street parking is not required to be provided for nonresidential uses on properties in the B-1/R District fronting on North 7th Street having a nonresidential floor area of not more than 2,000 square feet. Citywide, parking requirements may be reduced by one space through the provision of bike parking.
The C-2 Central Business Zoning District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Nonresidential uses may not provide motor vehicle parking in excess of 125% of the minimum motor vehicle parking ratios. Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of long-term bike parking or the availability of nearby public parking lots.
Within the B-1 central business district bounded by Downie Street, Pine Street, Center Street, and Wright Avenue and Lincoln Streets, a use may be exempt if certain conditions are met.
Off-street parking requirements are not applicable to any existing commercial use in the C-1 Central Business District.
Parking requirements do not apply in the B District bounded by Dairyland Street on the South and Sunset Drive - Riverview Drive on the North.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking. Parking maximums are set at 150% of the minimums.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to commercial buildings in existence at the time of adoption of the parking ordinance or to new commercial uses where it can be demonstrated
that adequate public parking exists when located within the CBD. Parking minimums are not applicable to uses located in the CBD Central Business District or DOD Downtown Overlay District except where more than four dwelling units are constructed above a commercial use. 

For existing buildings within all Business Districts, no additional parking space need be provided when remodeling or rebuilding of structures is proposed, provided the floor area of existing structures on such site is not increased. Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking. Parking maximums are set at 130% of the minimums citywide.
Single-family dwellings are exempt from minimum parking requirements. The D Public and Semi-Public, the E Light Industrial, and the F Agricultural districts are also exempt.
The (C-1) Downtown Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Off street parking spaces are not required in the C-4, downtown commercial district, and MR, marina recreation district.
Within the C-4 Village Commercial District, the minimum parking requirements are also the maximum allowed. On-street parking spaces may be counted in parking requirements.
Parking maximums apply to most uses citywide.

In Blocks 1, 2, 7, and 8 of the original plat of East Eau Claire, now City of Altoona, the minimum automobile parking requirement for commercial uses is fifty percent (50%) of the minimums set forth in the tables. Parking maximums exist for all uses citywide.
Within the Urban Center (UC) District, on-street parking may count towards parking minimums.
The CI Intensive Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates.
The General Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Nonresidential uses in the CB Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Within the Community Business District (CBD), artisan/maker spaces, indoor recreational facilities, offices and retail uses are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums apply to certain uses in the CBD, Midtown District (MID) and Gateway South District (GWS).

Within the Downtown and Campus Town Service Center Zones, parking requirements are eliminated for most uses, except for dwelling units, short term lodging uses, high schools and universities, and sports practice facilities.
Commercial uses in the B-2 Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Except for lodging uses and residential uses, no off-street parking is required in the Central Business Development District/Main Street Overlay (CBDD/MSO). Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums citywide.
Anacortes reduced parking minimums for most uses and implemented discretionary review for other uses. New projects in downtown have an additional reduction of 50%

ADUs are exempt from minimum parking requirements depending on transit proximity, number of bedrooms, and other factors. Two-family dwellings are exempt based on transit proximity and carshare availability.
No off-street parking is required in the C-1 Central Business Commercial District.
Anchorage eliminated all parking minimums citywide on Nov 22, 2022, effective January 22, 2023 per AO 2022-80(S), as amended.

All uses in the C-3 Commercial District and residential uses in the
Central Business District are exempt from parking mandates. Small uses in the C-N District are eligible for a reduction of parking requirements.
Parking requirements do not apply in a block where 50% or more of the area was occupied by business or industrial structures at the time of passage of the zoning code.
Nonresidential uses in the DC Downtown Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Maximum parking limits exist citywide, but may be exceeded with more landscaping.
The C-2A Central Business Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Ann Arbor has no car parking mandates for any land uses citywide.
The B-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Except for residential uses, the minimum amount of parking required does not apply within the C-1 District.

Uses under 20,000 square feet in the C2 or C2A districts and under 15,000 square feet in the WMC District are exempt from parking mandates. Additionally, narrow lot single-family dwellings without alley access and uses that would otherwise require 3 spaces or less are exempt. There is a proposal from two city councilors to eliminate on-site parking requirements for all food establishments in all zones (restaurants, bars, deli's, clubs with food service, etc.) in the City of Annapolis. Annapolis previously reduced requirements for restaurants in West Annapolis.
Parking requirements are reduced for workforce housing near transit and may be further reduced for bike parking.
The B-3 General Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

The total number of accessory parking spaces provided for a single-family, two-family or multiple-family dwelling may not exceed those required for such use or for an equivalent new use by more than 50 percent or four spaces, whichever number is greater.
When the application of the off-street parking regulations results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single zoning lot in any business district, such parking spaces need not be provided. However, where two or more uses are located on a single zoning lot, only one of these uses is eligible for this exemption. This exemption does not apply to dwelling units.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Small residential and business land uses within the Downtown Parking District (DPD) are exempt from the minimum parking requirements. Large commercial or office development with a gross floor area of ten thousand (10,000) square feet or more will have to provide the village with a parking plan, and it will be subject to village board review and approval. If parking is required of a particular use in the DPD, all on-street parking spaces within six hundred feet (600') of the proposed use and any parking spaces within municipal parking lots within six hundred feet (600') may be included in the calculation for the required number of off-street parking spaces. Commercial establishments within the DPD may not provide off-street parking spaces in a greater number than one hundred percent (100%) of the parking requirement for that establishment's land use.
There are no minimum parking requirements for off-street customer parking in the Downtown Commercial District, however, parking for residential uses and employee parking is required.
Due to the primarily pedestrian orientation of the Central Business District (CBD), provision for off-street parking and loading spaces are not required for uses in the CBD.
Existing buildings as of August 2, 1960 are exempt from parking mandates.

No parking minimum for development in the Commercial Central zoning district, except for residential developments with more than 7 units. Parking Maximums are in place citywide, but are high enough that they do not impact development.
Parking requirements in the C-1 District are reduced by 50% for commercial uses in existing buildings. Parking requirements may be reduced citywide through motorcycle parking.
Parking requirements for personal services, restaurants, and retail sales are reduced by one-half if located in the CBD, Central Business District, "Core" subarea.
No off-street parking is required in the B-1 General Commercial District.
No off-street parking or loading spaces are required in the CD Downtown Commercial District.
The B-1 General Commercial District is exempt from parking regulations.
No off-street parking facilities are required in the C-4 Central Business District.

The total number of accessory parking spaces provided for a two-family or multiple -family dwelling or hotel may not exceed the requirements for such use or for an equivalent new use by more than 50%. The total number of accessory parking spaces for a single-family residential zoning lot may not exceed six.
The 2023 Annual Town Meeting passed a zoning change to eliminate parking minimums for non-residential uses in the B5 district, which represents a portion of the Arlington Center business district.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Properties in the  B-3 Downtown Zoning District, adjacent to the original Depot Square, as shown in Section 4.4.3, are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Elsewhere in the B-3 District, parking requirements may be reduced due to proximity to on-street parking or public parking. Maximum parking limits apply to most uses citywide.
Parking minimums are reduced in the DB, DNO, and LCMUO Districts and on-street parking may count towards the minimums. Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums in the EDO District.
Within the C-1 districts, uses that are located within 500 feet of an off-street public parking facility are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums apply to all uses.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for commercial and industrial uses in those districts.
The (C-1) Downtown Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Parking reductions are permitted in Transit-Oriented Development and Urban Center areas through Valet parking, proximity to transit, TDM, carpool parking or bike parking. Within Zone A, commercial uses not required to meet minimum parking requirements.
Adjacent on-street parking may count toward parking requirements in the TND Traditional Neighborhood Development zone.
There is no parking required for any uses in Asheville's Central Business District, except for hotels.

Commercial buildings fronting on either side of the following street segments are exempt from parking mandates: Mechanic Street between Hardin Street and Yates Street; Editor Street between Clay Street and Yates Street; Washington Street between Hardin Street and Yates Street; Hardin Street between Washington Street and Mechanic Street; and Yates Street between Washington Street and Main Street.
The B-3 Business/Downtown district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

On December 19, 2023 Ashland removed parking mandates citywide. Parking maximums apply to all uses except single-family and two-family dwellings. Previously, parking was not required in the Commercial Downtown Zone or the North Mountain Plan District, other than residential uses.
Commercial uses in the City Center District that do not abut US Highway 2 are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums apply to all uses.
The C-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements are reduced for nonresidential uses in the VC Village Center District.
On-street parking within 50 feet of the subject property boundaries may be included within off-street parking requirement calculations.
Parking maximums apply to uses in the infill area. Parking requirements may be reduced through a fee in lieu of required parking or mobility measures such as a TDM plan.
City allows for on-street spaces to count towards minimums in residential zones and allows for shared off-site parking reductions in other zones.
Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums in the TND Traditional Neighborhood Development District.

Within the B2-D downtown business zone, the off-street parking requirement for principal permitted business uses not including residential uses may be eliminated if there exists improved public parking to satisfy the requirements. Furthermore, all uses in all districts may reduce requirements by 50 percent based on nine available strategies including bike parking and transit access.
The B-1 General Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
On-street parking may count towards parking requirements. Parking maximums apply to surface parking lots.
Any use within the C-3 Town Center District is exempt from off-street parking requirements.

No parking is required within 1/2 mile of MARTA Stations and near more than a dozen activity centers (Special Public Interest Districts) for any uses except establishments that serve alcohol. No parking is required for any buildings built before 1965, citywide. Many districts exempt affordable housing from parking mandates. In February 2024, the city exempted most uses in the Beltline Overlay District.
The D Downtown Districts are exempt from parking mandates.
The minimum parking requirements do not apply in the downtown area as enclosed by Monroe Street, Sixth Street, Adams Street, and Front Street extended.
The DC Downtown Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements have been removed for all uses except for residential uses under Formed Based Code.
Developers can reduce parking lot requirements by providing on site bicycle parking spaces.
Off-street parking requirements do not apply to the renovation or rehabilitation of existing structures in the C-1 Central Commercial District.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for all uses except entertainment venues. The amount depends on location or if the project is a residential conversion.
Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums.
Parking requirements are reduced in the CBD Central Business District. On-street parking and bike parking may be used to reduce requirements citywide.
Within the KBD1 district and on Cony Street, west of Cony Circle, parking mandates are reduced and a change of use or expanded use is exempt from parking requirements.
The C-1 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

On-street parking and public parking in the OA Original Aurora District may count towards parking requirements for commercial uses. Adaptive reuse projects are exempt from parking requirements in the OA District. Numerous parking reductions are available based on transit, bike parking and other factors citywide for all except multifamily uses.

Within the FoxWalk Overlay District, the off-street parking regulations, with the exception of the loading requirements, do not apply to any uses of new buildings or structures, or any existing principal building or structure which is enlarged or increased in capacity.
The B-2 Community Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for dwelling units, hotels or motels.
Off-street parking requirements are not applicable to any existing commercial use in the C-1 Central Business District.
Parking maximums are set at 10% greater than the minimums.
On November 2, 2023 Austin City Council voted 8-2 to eliminate car parking mandates citywide for all uses.
The C Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Laundromats are exempt from parking mandates.

Off-street parking is not required around the boundaries of the historic properties/buildings as described in the Avilla Comprehensive Plan or in the downtown along East Albion Street from Main Street to VanScoyoc or Baum Street, and Main Street from Washington Street to Adams Street.

No minimum off-street parking space requirement may be exceeded by more than 20 percent unless good cause can be shown by the applicant and approved by the Planning Commission. Single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings, and multi-family dwellings are exempt from this provision.
Surface parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums for commercial or industrial uses.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Uses within the C-B Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The B-3 General Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

On-street parking may be used to satisfy off street parking requirements at a conversion rate of 2:1. No more than fifty (50) percent of required parking can be used for calculating off street requirements.

ADUs are exempt from parking mandates when located near transit or is a garage conversion. Parking requirements are reduced for uses near transit or for nonresidential uses that provide motorcycle parking. On-street parking may be counted towards the minimums for nonresidential uses or for guest parking of residential uses. Affordable housing has reduced parking requirements. Uses in the “central district,” “Old Town Kern,” and other mixed-use areas may have reduced requirements.
Uses in the C-1 Village Center Commercial District may use public parking to meet parking requirements.
The C-2 General Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The off-street parking requirements do not apply to any C-2 regional shopping district nor in any C-3 planned limited commercial district.
Minimum parking requirements are not applicable to property in the B-1 Business District, except for residential uses which are authorized by a conditional use permit.
Parking requirements may be reduced for uses near frequent transit.
Developments in the  C-1, C-1-E, C-1-VC, and C-5 districts are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums are generally 2X the minimum, citywide.
The Downtown Mixed Use District is exempt from parking mandates.
Bandara adopted a place type zoning code which calls for market driven parking supply in residential zones and maximums in the downtown zone. There are no set parking ratios.

The Downtown Development District and the Bass Park District are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Properties within the Waterfront Development District may be exempted depending on the availability of public parking. Uses in the Neighborhood Service District are permitted to have five fewer parking spaces than would otherwise be required. Citywide, small day-care facilities, outdoor seating for places of assembly and accessory dwelling units are exempt.

A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided in the  Town Center, Neighborhood Commercial Residential and Gateway Commercial Districts. Within the Town Center District and Neighborhood Commercial Residential District, parking requirements are reduced. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
The Central Business District (B-l) is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-D Downtown Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates.

Except for certain residential uses, there are no minimum required parking spaces. Instead, the owner provides parking spaces based upon the number employees, expected level of customer traffic, or actual counts at similar establishments. Maximum parking limits apply to all uses.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from off-street parking and loading regulations.
No off-street parking is required for housing for the elderly.
The total number of accessory parking spaces provided for a dwelling may not exceed the requirements by more than fifty percent (50%) or four (4) spaces, whichever number is greater.
Parking maximums are set at 115% of the minimums for business uses located along County Road within the Business District.
The area outlined on the official zoning map and entitled the Central Business District is exempt from parking and loading regulations.
The C-4 Central Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates.
Within the B-1 Village Center District, the owner may, at the discretion of the Village Board, contribute to the Bartlett Public Parking Fund for the required number of parking spaces not provided.

Within the Downtown Parking Area, a fee in lieu of require parking may be provided for commercial or mixed-use developments. Within the CSC District, parking requirements are reduced and on-street parking may be used to satisfy requirements, while surface parking is prohibited in certain areas. Uses designated as landmarks have reduced parking requirements citywide.

In the Downtown Zone, Off-street parking is not required for buildings located on sites smaller than seventeen thousand five hundred (17,500) square feet. On larger sites, on-site parking may be required as necessary to accommodate parking demand in excess of available on-street parking adjoining the site.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The Center Main Street District (C-MS-3) is exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements may be reduced through tree preservation, carshare or structured parking. Parking maximums are set at 150% of the minimums.
Bastrop Building Block (B3) Code eliminated minimum parking requirements citywide.

In all Zoning Districts, except the LI Light Industrial District, GI General Industrial District, Single-Family and the R2 Two Family Residence districts, no use except Conference Centers, and Hotels and Commercial Lodging may provide parking in excess of 125% of the required minimum parking. On-street parking may be counted toward the visitor parking requirement for developments in the R2 Two Family, R3 Multi-Family Low Density, R4 Multi-Family Medium Density, and R5 Multi-Family High Density zoning districts. Within the DMU Downtown Mixed Use Zoning District, existing buildings are exempt from minimum parking requirements, while new uses and additions must provide parking, but may pay a fee-in-lieu instead.
Off-street parking spaces are not required in the B-1 Village Business District, provided on street parking and public parking areas are available within the district.
Within the T-1 Traditional Business District, a change of use in existing buildings is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Off-street parking facilities are not required in a block frontage contained in a B3 or I-1 district in which the ground floor area of business or industrial structures, existing on July 11, 1988, equaled 50% or more of the entire area of the block frontage.
Within the Mixed Use District, on-street parking may count towards parking minimums.
The Planning Commission may reduce the amount of off-street parking as they deem necessary. They may also require bicycle parking.
There are no minimum parking requirements in the C1 Downtown District.
The Parking Overlay District which encompasses downtown Bath is exempt from parking mandates.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The C-5 District is exempt from minimum parking requirements. Reductions are available for transit availability, structured parking, nonresidential on-street parking, and tree preservation. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The T-4 Downtown Commercial and T-5 Core Downtown Commercial districts are exempt from parking mandates. Citywide, bike parking may substitute for automobile parking and parking maximums apply to all uses.
The C-1 District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-3 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
No off-street parking is required in the B-2 General Business District.
In the Mill Street district, in lieu of providing all or any part of the parking spaces, a sum of money may be contributed to the "public parking solutions fund."

No off-street parking is required for buildings existing in the Commercial or Waterfront Zoning District as of August 26, 2008, except any off-street parking already in existence. A change of use does not require the provision of parking, however, any expansion would require additional parking.
All off-street parking space requirements are waived for uses in the DBO District. Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums.
Any use within the Central Business District (CBD) is exempt from the off-street parking requirements.
Uses within the central business district are exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements may be reduced citywide through the provision of increased landscaping.
The DBD Downtown Business District is exempt from parking mandates, unless specifically required by Conditional Use or Special Exception.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.
The city council of Beaverton, pop. 99,000, voted 7-0 to repeal costly parking mandates city-wide.

Within the Temperance Village Overlay District, Lambertville Village Overlay District, and Samaria Village Overlay District, parking requirements are reduced by 50 percent by right for nonresidential uses and may include on-street parking towards parking requirements. Residential uses have reduced requirements when located in a mixed-use development.
The C-1 Central Commercial District and properties located in the RLC Residential and Light Commercial District used for nonresidential purposes are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Beijing features four parking zones, with zone 1 (the city center) having parking maximums and no minimums, zones 2 and 3 having both minimums and maximums, and zone 4 having only minimums.

Retail and service uses in the B-2 Central Business District which do not exceed a requirement 50 spaces per property are exempt from minimum parking requirements. A fee in lieu of parking may be provided for uses in the B-2 District.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums for parking lots with 20 or more spaces.

There are no off-street parking requirements for existing or proposed uses in the areas identified on the map entitled "Areas Exempt from On-site Parking". 

Reductions are eligible if using on-street parking, public parking, or shared parking strategies.
Bella Vista removed all minimum parking requirements for nonresidential uses on May 24, 2021.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: Uses in the CBD and on Bridge Street between Antrim and 4th Street are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The B-4 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
A change of use in a building existing prior to the code adoption is exempt from parking mandates.
The Central Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No parking is required in the C-1 Central Commercial District except for dwelling units constructed in conjunction with business uses.
Commercial uses in the B-3 Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements. For facilities that contain residential units, two (2) parking spaces are required per unit.
Non-residential uses in all zoning districts may not contain more than one hundred and ten percent (110%) of the minimum number of parking spaces required.
Within the RMX-1 Residential Mixed Use 1 District, commercial uses are exempt and one residential unit combined with commercial uses is also exempt. This went into effect on May 8, 2023.

Libraries, museums, art galleries, government buildings, eating and drinking establishments, and retail uses within the Central Business and Waterfront Business Districts are exempt from parking mandates. Industrial uses, business, professional and financial offices, and multifamily housing have reduced requirements in the districts.
Commercial uses in the area shown on the map are exempt from parking requirements if they are located within 500 feet of a municipal parking lot.
The C-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Areas which are located in a fire district as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The “C-1” Central Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Off-street parking is not required in the B-1 Central Business District.
Laundromats are exempt from parking mandates.

Parking minimums are reduced for housing near transit, and within the Downtown, Eastgate Transit Oriented Development, and East Main Transit Oriented Development districts. Parking maximums apply to most uses citywide.
The C-1 Central Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

There are no minimum parking requirements for specific land tracts in the downtown area, with the exception of hotels/motels. 

The planning director may reduce minimum parking required if the development includes programs to reduce single occupancy vehicle trips through senior and affordable housing, implementation of a shared car service (i.e., Zipcar™), enhanced bike storage facilities, purchase of WTA transit passes, installation of covered transit shelters, off-site pedestrian infrastructure improvements, or other similar strategies.

When the application of the off-street parking provisions results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single zoning lot in any business or industrial district, such parking spaces need not be provided; however, where two or more uses are located on a single zoning lot, only one of those uses is eligible for the exemption.

Off-street parking requirements do not apply to uses within the C-2 General Commercial District, however all uses considered places of assembly, such as churches and halls, should provide for off-street parking.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to areas in the Commercial District (C-1).

Uses less than 2,500 square feet are exempt from parking requirements in the D-D Downtown District and NC-C Neighborhood Center Commercial District. Within all districts, parking requirements may be satisfied using on-street parking in front of buildings or public lots within 300 ft of primary building entrances. The maximum number of parking spaces allowed is 125% of the number of required parking spaces. Structured parking facilities are exempt from the maximum.
There are no parking minimums in the central business district, neighborhood parks, school play areas, or in vacant lots.
Parking requirements within the central business (CB) district are waived, unless the zoning administrator notes otherwise.
Laundromats are exempt from parking mandates.

On January 18, 2023, the Bend City Council voted 4-2 to no longer require that developers create a minimum number of off-street parking spaces for new developments.  Parking maximums apply to most uses.
Commercial uses in the (B-2) Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

In the C-1 Highway Commercial District, C-2 Highway Commercial Center District (Overlay), C-3 Downtown Commercial District, and C-4 Flex Business District, on-street parking within 400 feet of the use may be included in the total required off-street parking, except for apartments.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Minimum parking requirements do not apply to non-residential uses in the C-1 District with approval of the Zoning Administrator. In all districts, the off-street parking requirements may be reduced for non-residential uses with prior written approval by the Zoning Administrator based on proximity to a commuter rail station, proximity to a bus stop, or proximity to a municipal parking lot. All uses may reduce parking requirements with approval by providing an EV charging station, paying a fee-in-lieu of required parking, or providing dedicated carshare spaces. No use may provide parking spaces in excess of one hundred twenty five percent (125%) of the required minimum parking amount, except residential uses in residential districts,  or for uses requiring 10 spaces or less.
Ground floor non‐residential uses in the C‐B Central Business District are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums in the M-U Mixed-Use District.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Within the TC-3 Town Center Zone, there are no minimum parking requirements and surface parking is not permitted. Parking requirements are reduced in the C1 Neighborhood Commercial, TC-1 Town Center Zone, and TC-2 Town Center Zone.
Off-street parking is not required for any permitted use except special uses in the B-1 Central Business District.
No parking is required in the B-2 Central Business District.
Areas which are located in a fire district as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Within the DC and DE Downtown zoning districts, a structure with less than 
 3,000 square feet on the ground floor is exempt from minimum parking requirements. All other uses in the districts have reduced requirements. The R-C2 Central Residential - Moderate Density, and R-C3 Central Residential High Density Districts have reduced parking requirements.

The US-31 Corridor Overlay Top-of-the-Hill District (COD-T) is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Within the Village Mixed Use District (VMU) or a property within 800 feet of the district, parking requirements may be reduced based on the availability of public parking. Parking requirements may be reduced in all districts through the provision of bike parking or EV chargers.
Minimum parking requirements are not applicable to property in the CB Central Business District, except for residential uses which are authorized by a conditional use permit.

Berkeley has no parking requirements for new residential developments of any size, except for new developments on certain narrow streets in the hills. The city has parking maximums for new residential uses.

If a non-residential use is within 500 feet of a municipal parking lot, without crossing a major thoroughfare, no parking is required. Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking.
Berlin eliminated parking mandates citywide in 1997.
Within the B-1 Town Center District, a fee in lieu of parking may be provided.
Parking requirements are reduced for retail uses in the C-3 General Commercial District.

Berrien Springs has no off street parking requirements in the central business district. There are no set minimums along the M-139 Corridor for non-residential uses, but developers must demonstrate adequate parking supply.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply within the C-1 Central Business District.

Within the “MS-C” Main Street Commercial District, all customer and employee parking for businesses located on Main Street must be on-street parking. However, businesses with company vehicles that remain on-site after business hours are required to be parked either within the building or in the rear yard of the property.

Commercial uses either renovating or expanding existing properties fronting on Massachusetts Ave. between 3rd and 5th Streets, Mountain Ave. between 1st and 5th Streets or Welch Avenue between 1st and 5th Streets are exempt from parking requirements. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums for nonresidential uses.
On-street and public parking may count towards parking requirements in the C District. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.
The C-3 District (Downtown Commercial District) is exempt from parking mandates.

Parking requirements may be reduced through the availability of on-street parking, or the proximity of a commuter rail station or bus stop. In the C-2 Traditional Mixed-Use District along Cermak Road only, developments that are located within 400 feet of a municipal parking lot have reduced parking requirements. Any property in the C-2 Traditional Mixed-Use District or C-3 Depot Mixed-Use District may satisfy any off-street parking requirement for a non-residential use through payment of a fee-in-lieu of providing parking spaces, subject to approval by the Zoning, Planning, and Development Commission.

Within the CC City center district parking must be provided unless it can be accommodated within 500 feet of a public parking lot as determined by the administrator. Parking maximums are set at 150% of the minimum parking standards. On-street parking may be used to satisfy some of the off-street parking that otherwise is required for a particular use.
No parking lot shall exceed the minimum parking space requirements by ten percent (10%) greater than required.
Commercial uses in the C-1 Central Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

If off-street parking spaces were not provided for structures that were occupied before the enactment of parking requirements, provision of parking is not required. The erection, expansion or change of use of any principal building and/or secondary structure located in the B Business District may not be required to provide minimum off-street parking upon approval of a conditional use permit if it can be demonstrated that the parking requirements can be satisfied by public parking facilities.
There are no parking minimums in CB Central Business District of Bethlehem.
The Downtown Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements are reduced in the Village Center Overlay District.

Within the Main Street District, parking requirements may be reduced for on-street parking or for cross access agreements. Parking maximums apply to all uses except institutional uses in the district.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Nonresidential uses in the Transit Oriented District are exempt from parking requirements. Residential uses have reduced requirements and parking maximums apply to most uses.

Uses within the C-2 Commercial District and within 300 feet of a municipal parking lot may utilize such lots in required parking space calculations. Parking maximums are set at 115% of the minimums citywide.

Existing uses in the Central Business Parking Overlay District are required to provide as many parking spaces as possible under their current configuration, but otherwise are exempt. Additions and new uses are exempt if they do not increase the parking deficiency by more than 4 spaces.

Parking requirements for commercial uses in the CBD Central Business District are reduced. Additionally, commercial and retail uses in existing structures in the CBD may change from one permitted use to another without providing additional parking.
The "C-2" Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: There are no minimum parking requirements in the Central Business District or the East Billings Parking Overlay. Parking maximums apply to all surface parking. On-street parking may be counted towards parking requirements.
Development in the Downtown (DT) District is exempt from the minimum off-street parking requirements.

Off-street parking requirements do not apply to any existing buildings located in the Downtown Business (C-2) District where no parking presently exists and there is no opportunity to provide it, except for certain residential uses. In all Zoning Districts except C-2, off-street parking requirements do not apply to a non-residential land use occupying 4,000 square feet or less and located within an existing structure. Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of EV chargers. No use other than one or two-unit dwellings may provide parking in excess of 110% of parking minimums.
The Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

In May 2024, Birmingham replaced parking minimums with parking maximums for all uses citywide. Previously, off-street parking was not required in the B-4 Central Business District and were reduced in the B-3 Community Business District or by 10% when within 1000 ft of transit.

Within the Downtown Birmingham Overlay District, both nonresidential uses located within the parking assessment district and residential units in an existing second or third floor of a landmark building, located within the central business historic district, are exempt from parking mandates. Within the B3 and MX districts, parking requirements are reduced for mixed uses, and on-street parking may count towards requirements in the TZ1 and TZ3 districts.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Off-street parking is not required for properties within the Downtown Parking District in Bismark.
Parking maximums are set at 115% of the minimums.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking mandates only apply to the C Commercial and C-M Commercial-Manufacturing districts. All agricultural and residential districts are exempt.
Within the Commercial Gaming District, a fee in lieu of required parking may be provided.
The B-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking regulations.
Single-family dwellings have a parking maximum of four spaces.
The C-2, Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
The C-2 District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

The minimum parking requirements are waived for nonresidential uses in the D-1 Central Business District. In addition, when the application of the off-street parking regulations results in a requirement of not more than three parking spaces for any nonresidential use, such parking spaces need not be provided. However, where two or more uses are located on a single lot, only one of these uses is eligible for the exemption.

In March 2024, parking mandates for nonresidential uses in the D-2 Downtown Transitional District were removed and reductions expanded for transit, mixed-use areas, on-street parking or public parking.

Minimum parking requirements do not apply to development in the Courthouse Square Character Area or the Downtown Core Character Area south of 4th Street. In addition, parking maximums exist for all uses.
The C Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates.

There are no parking mandates for uses other than single-family and two-family dwellings. Instead, an applicant is required to provide an "adequate" number of spaces as determined by the Community Development Director. Surface parking in the Downtown "DT" district is limited to a maximum of 35% of the lot.
Restaurants, cafes, bars, taverns, and night clubs in the Central Business District are exempt from parking requirements.

The first 2000 square feet of a commercial use in the C-1 Central Area Commercial District and UTOD Uptown Transit Oriented Development District is exempt from parking mandates. Any business use may count on-street parking towards the minimums. Prior to 2024, all uses in the C-1 District were exempt, while parking minimums were generally higher.
No more than 5 motor vehicles may be parked outside of a closed garage on any lot.

Minimum parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking, bicycle parking, a walkable development credit based on dwelling unit density and activity streets, and the availability of public parking lots nearby. Parking maximums exist for all uses.

No minimum off-street parking is required in the BC central business district, except for off-street parking which may be required by the board of adjustment as a condition for granting a special exception.

Uses in the B-1 Central business district, with the exception of assembly, lodging and educational uses, are exempt from the minimum parking requirements. In addition, all agricultural, industrial, transportation, utility, and wholesale uses are exempt. No more than 150 percent of the minimum number of required parking spaces may be provided, except for uses providing ten or fewer parking spaces, or single family dwellings.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
Parking minimums were reduced in much of the city as part of a wider zoning rewrite, which was approved in June 2023, and went into effect in December 2023. 
The MX-5 District as well as ADUs are exempt from parking mandates and minimums may be reduced through a variety of means.
Additionally, Parking Maximums were implemented for many uses, including Multi-family Dwellings, Art Galleries, Community Centers, and Restaurants.
Off-street parking is not required in the C-3 Central Business District.
Parking requirements are reduced for mixed-use developments.
The C-1 General Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Parking requirements are reduced by 10 to 40 percent in three zones which cover the entire city. Parking requirements for a change of use may be waived or reduced. A fee in lieu of parking may be provided. Parking reductions are also available for carsharing, increased parking fees, bike facilities, and transit passes.

The maximum number of parking spaces for all uses except for single family dwellings, is thirty (30) percent greater than the required minimum number, unless a parking study acceptable to the Zoning Administrator is provided.
The C-3 District, designated as the “Central Business Area”, is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Commercial uses in the TC Town Center District are exempt from parking mandates.

Permitted commercial uses in the B-4 Downtown Business District are exempt from providing off-street parking and loading spaces if they are fronting the following streets:
Along Barksdale Boulevard between Minden Street on the west side, and Bennett Street on the East side of the B-4 District.
Parking maximums are set at 150% of the minimums.
Boston City Council passed a resolution in October 2021 to eliminate parking mandates for developments with more than 60% affordable housing. Boston also has citywide parking maximums.
In 2014, the city amended the city code to exempt off-street parking requirements in the downtown area.

Within the MU-4 and RH-7 districts, there are no residential parking mandates while parking maximums apply. Nonresidential uses are exempt within the RH-3, RH-6, RH-7, MU-4, DT, MU-3, and BMS districts and parking maximums apply in the RH-3, RH-6, RH-7, and MU-4 districts. All nonresidential uses in General Improvement Parking Districts are exempt from parking mandates.

Minimum parking requirements do not apply when application of the off-street parking provisions result in a requirement of three spaces or less on a single zoning lot in any business or manufacturing district.
Minimum parking regulations do not apply to the "B-2" Central Business District.
Bowling Green, Ohio does not require parking in the Central Business District.
All existing and future uses in the DC (Downtown Commercial) overlay district are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Within the TC Town Center District, lots fronting portions of Philadelphia Ave and South Reading Ave are exempt from parking mandates. Commercial uses elsewhere in the district have reduced parking requirements when located in a building existing prior to 1960. A fee in lieu of parking may be provided for any remaining required parking.

In order to minimize excessive areas of pavement which depreciate aesthetic standards and contribute to high rates of stormwater runoff, exceeding the minimum parking space requirements by greater than 20 percent is not allowed, except as approved by the planning commission.
Bozeman eliminated minimum parking requirements in the Midtown Urban Renewal District.
Parking maximums apply to residential uses.
The B-2 General Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
The C-1 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No off-street parking is required for businesses located in the CBD Central Business District, except where residential housing will be included.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
Previously, Brainerd had no off street parking requirements for the following zones: B-4 (General Business) District, B-5 (Commercial Amusement) District, B-6 (Washington Street Commercial) District, I-1 (Light Industry) District, I-2 (General Industry) District. 
On October 16, 2023, the city added parking minimums to the TC Town Center and MS Main Street districts at a reduced requirement. All other nonresidential uses outside of these districts are now exempt from parking requirements. Parking maximums apply to all nonresidential uses and bike parking may substitute for required automobile parking.
The C-1 Central Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

No off-street parking is required in the downtown district, except that adequate on-street and off-street parking and unloading spaces must be demonstrated by the applicant for places of assembly, daycare centers, schools, and residences.
Minimum parking requirements are not applicable to property in the CB Central Business District, except for residential uses which are authorized by a conditional use permit.
Areas which are located in a fire district as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Branson parking minimums were flipped to parking maximums.
Brattleboro has no off-street parking requirements in the city center district.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for commercial uses within the service area. Parking maximums apply to most uses.
Mixed-use developments have reduced parking requirements.
Parking requirements are reduced within zones 1 and 2 which cover the city center. A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for most uses citywide.

Commercial uses in the MUN Mixed-Use Neighborhood District are exempt from parking mandates when the commercial use abuts a public street that has on street parking, or when other public parking is available. No parking is required for the residential portions of mixed use buildings in the MUN District where there are three or less residential units in the building.

Brevard's Downtown Mixed-Use zoning district and Neighborhood Mixed-Use in the Railroad Avenue/Lumberyard area are exempt from non-residential minimum parking requirements. Parking maximums apply to any parking that exceeds 10% of the minimum.
There are no specified parking minimums. Instead there are recommendations and the Zoning Administrator and/or the Planning Commission may require a minimum or maximum amount.

Bridgeport has no established car parking mandates except for when accessible parking is required by state law. There are maximums for retail and office uses. These reforms were adopted November 29, 2021 as part of a comprehensive zoning reform.

Within the NC Neighborhood Commercial District on 4th Street, nonresidential uses in existing buildings are exempt from parking mandates. A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for commercial uses in the district along 4th Street or DeKalb St.

Parking is not required for any use within the Form Generating Districts (DC Downtown Core, CG Community Gateway, DE Downtown Edge, and NE Neighborhood Edge districts). On-street parking within 750 feet of a building entrance may count toward meeting the parking requirements citywide.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Nonresidential uses under 10,000 square feet are exempt from parking mandates within the DT District. Parking requirements citywide may be reduced through on-street parking, public parking or bike parking. Maximum parking limits are set at 150% of the minimums for nonresidential uses.
Within the DBD Downtown Business District, any nonresidential use which would otherwise require 65 parking spaces or less is exempt from parking mandates.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for nonresidential uses in the TC Town Center District.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Within the downtown (D) zone, retail, office, institutional and residential uses are exempt from parking mandates. The Waterfront District and Urban rehab LDP overlay zone have reduced parking mandates. Parking requirements may be reduced where share access is provided. Parking maximums are set at 110% or 50 spaces above the minimums for nonresidential uses citywide.

Within the C-1 Roosevelt Road Commercial District, off street parking is not required at locations where limited parking or no parking is currently provided. New uses which are similar to those in operation are not required to add additional parking. However, where new construction or a change in existing use warrants additional parking, one-half (1/2) of the standard parking requirements for commercial uses, excluding restaurants, is required. No reduction in required parking for restaurants may be granted without a variation.
Elderly housing is exempt from parking mandates.
Off-street parking is not required for uses in the DM downtown mixed-use core district.
Off-street parking requirements do not apply to lots zoned C1 which are located within the Central Business District.
Off Street parking requirements can be removed by paying 500$ per required parking.
Mixed-use developments have reduced requirements.
Commercial uses in Station Area-1, Core Mixed-Use District, and Station Area-4a, General Mix District, do not require on-site parking.
Parking maximums apply to office uses.
Parking maximums apply to all uses.

All uses within the area defined as the B-1 Central Business District as designated on the official zoning map shall not be required to provide off-street parking except for any building or use that would be required to have in excess of 75 parking spaces, the additional off-street parking spaces shall be provided within 300 feet of the building or use.

A Fall 2021 zoning change reduced parking minimums for housing units created within 0.5 mile of rapid transit to 0.5 per studio apartment and 1.0 parking spaces per 1-bedroom or larger dwelling unit. It further allowed the Zoning Board of Appeals to reduce or eliminate required parking spaces if doing so accomplishes material Townwide benefits such as the creation of additional housing units, affordable housing units, or open space.
Parking maximums exist for most multi-family residential and commercial uses.

Parking may be reduced by 10% for any parcel located within one-quarter mile of a transit stop. This 10% must be shown on the site as proof of parking in the event transit services are altered and additional parking is required. To qualify, the transit stop must be served by regular transit service on all days of the week and adequate pedestrian access must be available between the transit stop and parcel. Regular transit service must operate at least twice hourly between 7:30 a.m. and 6:30 p.m. on weekdays and once hourly after 6:30 p.m. Regular transit service must operate on Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays. In addition, two motorcycle/scooter parking spaces may be provided in lieu of one required automobile parking space. The maximum automobile parking space reduction under this provision is calculated at a 1:30 ratio (For every 30 required automobile parking spaces, one automobile space may be waived). Parking areas under 30 spaces may reduce the parking requirement by a maximum of one automobile parking space.

The parking requirement in the Central Business (C-1), General Commercial (C-2) and Light Industrial (I-1) districts may be reduced by providing bike parking. Dwelling units located in mixed-use buildings in the C-1 District have reduced requirements.
The Historic Overlay District is exempt from parking mandates.

Parking minimums are reduced for certain uses within Parking Reduction Areas. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums citywide, except in Parking Reduction Areas where maximums are set at 100% of the minimums.

Commercial buildings within 300 feet of a municipal parking lot may reduce the amount of required off-street parking by subtracting from their total required off-street parking, 1 parking space for each 750 gross square feet of floor area. All other commercial buildings may reduce the amount of required off-street parking by subtracting from their total required off-street parking, 1 parking space for each 1,500 gross square feet of floor area.
No more than 125 percent of the minimum required number of parking spaces may be provided for any particular use.
Parking maximums apply in non-residential zoning districts. However, maximums may be exceeded when increased landscaping is provided.
On-street parking may be credited towards meeting off-street parking requirements in the Town Center Districts. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: New buildings downtown are exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking or bike parking. Parking maximums apply to most uses.
The Central Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The GCCore General Commercial Core District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Within the B-2 Central Business District and B-3  Business Transitional District, commercial uses are exempt from parking mandates where on-street parking exists.
Parking maximums apply to most nonresidential uses.
Parking requirements in the C-3 Central Business District are 75% of the requirements in other districts.
The C-3 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
The CBD Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for uses requiring site plan approval.
Parking requirements are reduced within the Downtown Business (DB) District.
Parking requirements are reduced for mixed-uses, joint provision of parking, or other public benefits.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Existing buildings and properties in the MU-1 and MU-2 districts without an alley are exempt from parking mandates. A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided in the MU-MS district. Parking requirements are reduced in the downtown area, where ADUs are exempt. Parking maximums apply to retail uses in the HC District. Parking requirements may be reduced citywide for bike parking.

There are no provisions that require a minimum number of off-street parking spaces for all land uses. A TDM plan is required for new construction (5,000 square feet or more) that determines the number of on-street, off-street, and shared vehicle parking spaces.
Allowed uses in the C-1 Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-1 downtown commercial district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-3 central business district is exempt from minimum parking regulations.
No parking is required in the C-1 Central Business District except for dwelling units constructed in conjunction with business uses.
No off-street parking is required for any uses in the "C-3" Central Business District.
Burlington, VT has eliminated parking mandates citywide and has maximums for many uses.
The B-2 Central Business District and the I-1 Institutional District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Uses within the TOD Transit Oriented Development District have reduced parking requirements up to 25% by right, while requirements may be further reduced through car-sharing and improved transit facilities. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the normal minimums.
Single-Family Dwellings have a maximum parking ratio of four spaces.
Off-street parking spaces are not required for business uses in the Butler Historic District.

Any establishment located within the C-3 Central Commercial zone (or any other zone) is exempt from minimum parking requirements when participating in an approved Butte-Silver Bow parking district. A fee-in-lieu of required parking may be provided in the C-3 District.
Parking requirements are reduced in the DE Downtown Enterprise District.
Commercial uses in the downtown commercial area, as identified by the Byron Comprehensive Plan are exempt from parking requirements.
The C-1: Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The Downtown Business District is exempt from parking mandates.

The B-2 zone, as well as commercial uses in any zone which abut off-street public parking located within the B-2 zone are exempt from minimum parking requirements. This exemption does not apply to overnight lodging uses.
The Downtown Architectural District (A-1) is exempt from parking mandates.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.
The City of Calgary has removed minimum parking requirements for non-residential uses from the Land Use Bylaw.

AB2097, signed into law in September 2022, prohibits cities and counties from enforcing parking mandates within 1/2 mile of high quality transit service. There are avenues for city's to enforce multi-family residential mandates on a case-by-case basis, but also a backup exemption for developments which include affordable housing.

Previous California laws limited local parking mandates. 

Senate Bill 35, adopted in 2017, has streamlined the approval of thousands of affordable homes near transit. The law grants these projects relief from local parking mandates.

Senate Bill 9 signed into law in 2021, makes it legal statewide to build up to four homes on most lots that are currently zoned for single-family homes only. Cities cannot require more than one parking space per home for projects built under the law.
No off-street parking is required in the C-1 General Commercial District, except for dwelling units above a store or shop, hotels and motels, and funeral homes.

Within the MU Mixed-Use Overlay District, off-street parking is not required for commercial uses abutting the sidewalk unless the use exceeds ten thousand (10,000) square feet. A maximum of 1.5 parking spaces may provided per residential unit in the district.

The maximum parking permitted for any nonresidential use may not exceed the minimum parking space requirements by more than 10%, unless additional parking is granted by approval of the zoning board of appeals. The zoning board of appeals may reduce the parking requirements based upon a finding that there will be a lower demand for parking due to convenient municipal off-street parking or on-street spaces located along the site’s frontage, sidewalk connections to adjacent residential neighborhoods or employment centers, the availability of other forms of travel, such as transit or non-motorized transportation, or where a parking study demonstrates that another standard would be more appropriate.
There are no parking minimums and the Village has parking maximums.
Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums for nonresidential uses. Nonresidential uses which provide EV chargers may reduce their required parking.
No off-street parking is required in the C-1 Commercial District, except for funeral homes, dwelling units, motels and gas stations.

Cambridge City Council voted 8-1 in favor of eliminating all minimum parking requirements for residential and commercial developments citywide. It is the first city in MA to do so.

The Policy Order does require developers of buildings with 4+ housing units and buildings requiring special permits to submit a written rationale to the City explaining why they chose to include a certain number of parking spaces. 

It also requires the Community Development Department submit a report by 2025 detailing how many housing units and parking spaces have been added since this policy's passage, and any impacts on street parking availability.
Cambridge replaced minimums with maximums for all uses citywide in September 2021.
Existing and new uses in existing buildings in the B-1 Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for all dwelling units.
No off street parking or loading space is required for any use in the “C‐1” General Commercial District.
The CBD Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Areas which are located in a fire district as designated on the official map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-3 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No off-street parking is required in the “C-1” Central Commercial District.

Parking requirements may be reduced for commercial uses in the MDR or DT District when located near public parking. On-street parking may count towards parking requirements in the Mixed Use Zoning Districts. The provision of bike parking for commercial, institutional or multi-family development allows for a parking reduction. Multi-family uses in the DT District have reduced requirements.
The C-1 Central Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates.
The Central Business District (B-3) is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Bikeshare facilities with a minimum of 15 bicycles may be substituted for up to four automobile spaces or 5% of the required parking spaces, whichever is less.

The City of Camrose approved Land Use Bylaw 3222-22 with an effective date of January 1, 2023. In addition to the 2018 elimination of parking minimums on 3 blocks of Main Street (50th Street) and the reduction of parking requirements for commercial uses in 2016 by up to 35%, the 2023 Land Use Bylaw reduces parking minimums on the remaining 28 commercial blocks in downtown by a further 50%.
In exchange for funding from the new Permanent Transit Fund, cities have to eliminate parking minimums within 800 meters of a frequent transit line.
Parking requirements are reduced for mixed-use developments in the Old Town Commercial District.

There are no provisions that establish a minimum number of off-street parking spaces for development. However, certain development proposals are required to complete a parking demand analysis, which will assist in determining off-street parking spaces required.
The Historic Downtown Overlay District is exempt from all parking requirements.
The Central Business District (CBD) is exempt from parking mandates.

Lots in the B-3 Central Business District with a width of less than forty feet (40') and/or less than five thousand (5,000) square feet in area are exempted from off street parking requirements. Parking requirements are reduced for mixed uses citywide.

Minimum parking requirements may be reduced at the ratio of one (1) automobile off-street parking space for each six (6) bicycle spaces provided. The total number of required automobile off-street parking spaces may not be reduced by more than five percent (5%) however.
Minimum parking requirements are not applicable to property in the CB Central Business District, except for residential uses which are authorized by a conditional use permit.
ADUs are exempt from parking mandates when certain conditions are met to comply with state law.
The CBD Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
On December 19, 2023, the city eliminated parking minimums for restaurants, bars, clubs, and lounges citywide.
Parking requirements are reduced in the South Cape (SC) and Mixed-Use Bimini (MXB) districts. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums.
Uses and developments in the CBD, Central Business District, are not required to provide off-street parking facilities.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of motorcycle parking or bike parking. Main dwelling homes in the PT2 areas are exempt from parking mandates.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Nonresidential uses except for lodging uses are exempt from parking mandates in the HCC District. Lodging uses in the district may pay a fee in lieu of required parking. Parking requirements are reduced in the MU Mixed-Use District and may be further reduced through transit availability. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums for commercial and industrial uses citywide.

Uses in the NB Neighborhood, BPR Primary Business, or Retail Revitalization Overlay districts are exempt from parking mandates. Commercial developments citywide are eligible for reduced parking requirements in exchange for additional bicycle parking facilities.
No off-street parking or loading space is required for any use in the B-1 Local Business District.
There are no parking minimums. Parking maximums apply to all uses.
Small scale restaurants, retail uses, manufacturing plants, and furniture and appliance stores are exempt from parking mandates.
The C-3 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates except for hotels, motels, bed-and-breakfasts, dwelling units, or buildings involving more than 15,000 square feet of total floor area.
Parking requirements may be reduced when a use is located near transit or within the C-1 commercial district where on-street parking is available.
Minimum Parking Requirements are not applicable to "B-1" Business Districts.
Parking requirements are reduced in the UR Urban Residential, UC Urban Core, and MC Meridian Corridor districts and may be further reduced when located near a transit hub.

Uses in Commercial Districts which are bounded by Mansfield, Kinney Street, Third Avenue, Williams Street and Broadway are exempt from parking mandates. A change of use for commercial uses in an existing building within the C-1 District is exempt.
Unless otherwise approved by the Community Development Director, the maximum permitted number of accessory off-street parking spaces is an additional 20% beyond the minimum requirement.
On October 24, 2023, Carrboro removed residential parking requirements and replaced them with parking maximums across all zoning districts except the WR Watershed District.
Parking requirements are reduced within the Downtown Commercial District.
The “B-3” Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Off-street parking not required in the C-1 Central Business District.

Within the Transit Center District, parking requirements are reduced and surface parking lots are banned.
Parking requirements are reduced for mixed uses, and public parking may count towards the minimums.
