Hotels, apartment hotels, clubs, hospitals, institutions and places of assembly are exempt from minimum parking requirements when located in District "E", General Business District.
The "B-2" Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The central business district ("CBD") and agriculture ("A-1") zoning districts are exempt from minimum parking requirements. However, all zoning districts have maximum parking requirements.

Off-street parking is not required for non-residential uses within the HMXD sub-district of the Town Center district or for any commercial uses citywide. Parking maximums apply to commercial uses citywide.
Developments other than Small Residential Uses may provide no more than 200% of minimum parking required on site.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.
Within the C-2 Central Business District, no off-street parking is required for nonresidential uses.

The B-1 community business district is exempt from parking mandates.
In the existing Business Districts, parking is only required to be provided for new development where it is reasonably possible.
Land uses within the C-3 Central Business District are exempt from providing off-street parking.
Off-street parking is not required in the C-1 Central Business District for existing structures.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Within the North Non-Residential Downtown Parking Area, the first 2000 square feet of a nonresidential use is exempt from parking mandates with reduced requirements thereafter. Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums citywide.

Within the W Waterfront and WOD Waterfront Overlay District, on-street parking may be counted towards parking minimums.
The B-1 Central Commercial Zone is exempt from parking mandates.
Large commercial mixed-use projects are entitled to a parking reduction.
The Cayce Arts Design Overlay District has "No minimums; but Planning Director must approve parking plan to ensure it meets the demands of the proposed business"

Nonresidential uses in the Central Business (CB) District are exempt from parking mandates as well as locally designated historic structures. Parking requirements may be reduced for on-street parking, bike parking, motorcycle parking, or through a fee in lieu of parking. Within the Riverfront districts, parking requirements are reduced by right and may be further reduced through bike parking, carshare, affordable housing or on-street parking.
The C-C Community Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.

Principal permitted commercial uses in the C-3 Commercial District, and residential uses established as a permitted secondary, incidental or accessory use to a principal permitted commercial use in the C-3 Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Cedar Rapids has no parking required in the downtown district. There are many reductions available for parking requirements elsewhere. Parking maximums apply to all uses.

Nonresidential uses in the Central Business (B-2) Zoning District may count on-street parking towards parking requirements. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums for parking lots with 20 or more spaces citywide.
Nonresidential uses in the B-3 Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The B-2 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Parking requirements may be reduced for on-street parking, public parking, carsharing, bike facilities, or shuttle connections to transit.
Parking requirements within the  B-1A City Center Redevelopment District may be reduced when parking is located in the rear yard.
Uses in the area designated as the commercial district are exempt from parking mandates.
There are no minimum parking requirements for uses in the VC Village Center District. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums citywide except for single-family and two-family dwellings.

Any use within the downtown commercial district other than downtown residential is exempt from the off-street parking requirements provided by Section 17.28.030. Any off-street parking facility constructed in the downtown commercial district after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this title must comply with the design standards set forth in this chapter.
Vehicle parking requirements do not apply in a block where 50% or more of the area was occupied by business or industrial structures on 5-27-1957.
Properties in the Architectural Preservation District that are parties to the Uptown Parking District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements are reduced in the Historic Downtown and Historic City districts.

Within the CCO City Center Overlay District, on-street parking may count towards the minimums for nonresidential uses and parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.

No off-street parking or loading spaces are required for any permitted use located within that portion of the B-2 Central Business District located east of the railroad tracks bounded by McCord Street and Third Street on the north and south and by Elm Street and Oak Street on the east and west and those properties located west of the railroad tracks bounded by Noleman Street and Second Street on the north and south and Chestnut Street and Walnut Street on the east and west.
No off-street parking is required in the "B-1" Central Business District except for theaters, auditoriums, churches, stadiums or other places of public assembly.
Parking areas in the Village Commercial District, excluding driveways or aisles, may not occupy more than the equivalent of six parking spaces (960 square feet).
The B Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Any use within the DC Downtown Commercial District is exempt from off-street parking.
The "C-3" Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Within the Central Shopping District, a change of permitted use to another permitted use occupying the existing floor area of a building does not require more parking than already provided for the previous permitted use of such building.
Parking requirements are reduced in the Park Avenue TOD Overlay District.
The Central Core Area is exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements are reduced by 50% in the Southgate Neighborhood Overlay District.
The B-5 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: Champaign eliminated parking requirements for all multi-family dwellings in the "University District". No off-street parking is required for any use within the MFUniv, CB1, CB2, and CB3 Districts. Elderly housing is subject to reduced parking requirements in all zones.

No parking or loading is required for commercial uses in the C-1 Central Business District.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Chapel Hill has no parking mandates in the Town Center if the developer pays into the parking fund and/or presents an approved TDM Plan. Vehicular parking requirements do not apply for uses located within the Office/Institutional-3 or Office/Institutional-4 Districts or for any  single family homes or duplexes. Parking maximums exist for all uses. For all residential uses located in a Residential-Community Priority-Conditional Zoning District (R-CP-CZD), the minimum number of vehicular parking spaces required per dwelling unit is reduced by twenty (20) percent.
Parking maximums apply to most nonresidential uses in the four commercial districts.

Commercial uses in the CBD and MU  Districts are exempt from parking mandates when there is adjacent on-street parking, or when other public parking is nearby. All uses may count on-street parking towards the minimums.
The B-2 Downtown Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums for nonresidential uses. On-street parking may count towards parking requirements for all uses in the Core Mixed-Use Zones and for nonresidential uses in the Core and Gateway subzones of the Hughesville Village Zone.

No off street parking is required for the area known as the "Courthouse Square". The "Courthouse Square" is defined as the area from the center of 5th Street to the center of 8th Street and from the center of Van Buren Avenue to the center of Madison Avenue. This encompasses 9 blocks of downtown.
Minimum parking regulations do not apply to the "B-2" Central Business District.

The GP Gathering Place District is exempt from parking mandates. Changes of use in existing buildings within the Special Parking District, SPD Overlay Zone, have been exempt since July 20, 2021. The Special Parking District covers properties fronting King St, from Calhoun to Broad Streets.

There are no on-site parking requirements in the CBD Central Business District. Parking requirements may be reduced in the CVD Corridor Village District.
Within the Neighborhood Reinvestment Overlay (NRO) District, single family dwellings, accessory dwelling units, and duplex dwellings are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Further reductions to the parking requirements apply to other uses. 
In all districts, when the expansion of a commercial or industrial building requires two (2) or less new spaces, no additional parking spaces are required. 
The city has a standing administrative decision by the Planning Director to reduce on-site parking requirements for low-income and elderly/disabled housing developments from 2 spaces per unit to 1.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Hospitals and institutions are exempt from parking mandates and parking maximums apply to all uses except for single-family and two-family dwellings. Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: The CBD Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements, as are all buildings fronting Bridge Street between the Pine River Channel and Antrim Street. Maximum parking limits are set at 100% of the minimum requirements.

No vehicle parking is required for any use in any TOD District, except for bars, restaurants, micro-breweries, microdistilleries, micro-wineries, and live performance venues within 200 feet of a single-family residential zoning district.

On December 18, 2023, Charlottesville eliminated parking mandates citywide. The city had previously eliminated parking minimums in the city center and a special university district. There was a zoning overlay that also eliminated mandates for smaller developments and reduced mandates for larger developments.

In general, uses within the C3 Downtown District may reduce the parking requirements by 75 percent. In the event of a sizable redevelopment project within the C3 District, parking spaces shall be provided as required by the City Council. Uses permitted in existing downtown buildings will not be required to provide additional parking beyond that available on-site, but are subject to parking requirements in the event an existing building is expanded or a new building is proposed.
Allowed uses in the B-1 General Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

In the Central Business District (defined as all streets contiguous to the Village Square except Illinois Route 4, and Mulberry Street between Illinois Route 4 and the railroad tracks), each lot owner is required to provide off-street parking in accordance with the minimum requirements only if the required spaces exceed ten in number.
Since at least 2014, there have been no car parking mandates, but rather maximums for retail, multi-family, and other uses.
Chattanooga, TN has no parking requirements in the  Downtown Core.
An in lieu fee for parking may be provided instead of the required parking.

Uses in the DT district are exempt from parking mandates if the use is located within 500 feet of municipal parking facilities. Parking maximums are set at 130% of the minimums except for single-family or two-family dwellings.
Small business and office uses in the CDEP Commercial Enhancement Districts are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums citywide.

Cheyenne implemented the UDC in 2012 which eliminated parking minimums for all uses in the CBD zone district (downtown).

Cheyenne established the Urban Use Overlay (UU) as an overlay zone district which eliminated parking minimums for all uses in that zone district in March 2022. This set up a rezoning action where an entire district was rezoned from mostly LI (Light Industrial) to MUB (Mixed-use Business Emphasis) with UU overlay. The zone change was implemented in June 2022.

The area covered is roughly 250 Acres.

The total of accessory parking spaces provided for one-family, two-family or multiple-family dwellings or hotels shall not exceed those required for such use or for any equivalent new use by more than 50 percent, or four spaces, whichever number is greater, in an R-4, R-5, or R-4 or business district.

The total number of accessory parking spaces provided for a single-family, two-family or multiple-family dwelling may not exceed the requirements by more than 50 percent or four spaces, whichever number is the greater.

There are no minimum parking requirements for certain nonresidential uses within the Downtown Zoning District, which are also subject to specific maximum requirements.

In other districts (B,C, D or M), the minimum parking requirement for non-residential uses may be reduced by 50% if the property is within 1,320 feet of a CTA rail station, a Metra rail station, OR along a high frequency bus line corridor, or 2,640 feet of other specified bus line corridors that is also along a designated 'pedestrian street or a 'pedestrian retail street'.

The parking may be reduced by 100% if it is approved as a special use.

In downtown Chico, parking is no longer required for non-residential uses.

The CB-1 central business district is exempt from parking mandates.

Lots within the DE Downtown Enterprise District having less than seventy percent (70%) lot coverage are only required to provide fifteen percent (15%) of the number of parking spaces otherwise required, provided at least one (1) parking space is provided for each employee during any one business shift. For residential uses, at least one (1) off-street parking space per dwelling unit is required.
Uses located within the central business district are exempt from all off-street parking and loading requirements.
The maximum number of parking spaces provided may not exceed the minimum number of spaces and an additional twenty (20) percent of parking spaces.

Within the Central Business District (CB), all lodging, governmental facilities, and residential development must provide parking. All other uses in the CB are exempt from off-street parking requirements.

Cincinnati uses a tool known as an Urban Parking Overlay, which is a zoning overlay that removes parking minimums completely within its boundary.  Cincinnati implemented and Urban Parking Overlay-- completely removing parking requirements-- in four neighborhoods: Central Business District, Over the Rhine, Pendleton (all of which are considered the "urban core") as well we parts of the Camp Washington neighborhood.

Theaters not exceeding ten thousand (10,000) square feet and retail establishments not exceeding three thousand (3,000) of floor area in downtown Clayton with the exception of the properties facing the north side of Maryland Avenue west of Forsyth Boulevard to the west City limits are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Restaurants located in the Central Business District not exceeding three thousand (3,000) square feet of gross floor area, cafeterias and kiosks located in office buildings designed to primarily serve the tenants of the building, restaurants located in office buildings or commercial spaces which have one hundred fifty thousand (150,000) gross square feet or more of floor area and which provide parking, and restaurants in hotels or motels are also exempt.

Parking requirements for hotels, motels, and elderly housing are reduced within the CB-1 Central Business Zone. When a use abuts a City-owned parking area, up to 100% of the required number of parking spaces may be provided in the parking facility. Where it can be demonstrated that a specific use has such characteristics that the number of parking or stacking spaces required is too restrictive, the Board of Adjustment may grant a conditional use to allow up to a 50% reduction for buildings placed on the National Register of Historic Places.

Surface parking areas for multi-family, non-residential, and mixed-use development uses may not exceed 125% of the required minimum number of vehicle parking spaces. Where two or fewer dwelling units are being developed in existing buildings in the B-2H Business 2 Historic Crosstie Central Business District, the existing parking spaces may be considered for the required parking.

In the B1 Downtown Business District, there are no minimum off-street parking requirements for businesses listed as permitted or conditional uses in the B1 district. All other uses must comply with off-street parking requirements.

Commercial uses in the CC District are exempt from parking requirements. A change of use in existing buildings within the HC or CC Districts is exempt from parking requirements.

There are no parking requirements for C-1 Commercial Districts.
The Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements as well as accessory buildings in other districts.

Nonresidential uses in the RN-4, C-1, C-2 and PS districts may count on-street and public parking towards parking requirements. A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided in these districts. Parking requirements are reduced in the Mixed Use Development Overlay District.

Properties within the downtown parking district are exempt from providing up to 100 off street parking spaces that would otherwise be required. Uses in the downtown parking district that exceed the 100 space threshold shall provide off street parking in the amount required in excess of 100 spaces.

No off-street parking is required for any structure, except multiple-family residences, in the area enclosed by Patterson Street on the east; 11th Street on the south; Willow Street on the west; and 7th Street on the north. Nonresidential uses citywide may count public off-street parking towards parking requirements and all uses in the MSC Main Street Commercial District within 250 feet of a public parking lot are exempt from parking mandates.

Within the CBD District, parking requirements are half of those listed, with the exception of service stations, grocery and supermarkets, laundries, and motels and hotels. On-street parking may count towards requirements for nonresidential uses.

There are two established parking exempt districts in which there is no additional off-street parking required; Downtown/Central business district and Old Colorado City. Parking may be reduced with approval in other districts.

Colorado passed a bill in May 2024 which prohibits a county or municipality, on or after June 30, 2025, from enforcing minimum parking requirements for multifamily dwellings or adaptive reuse projects that are served by transit and within a metropolitan planning organization.
Colton California has reduced parking minimums for commercial and residential in the downtown and mixed used neighborhoods but has not completely eliminated minimum parking in any area.
Minimum parking requirements are not applicable to property in the CB Central Business District, except for residential uses which are authorized by a conditional use permit.
Properties within the Central Business District Economic Revitalization Area, as established by City Ordinance Number 984, are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

The CB-4 (central business) zoning classification is exempt from minimum parking standards. However to avoid conflicts with nearby residential uses, a plan to show employee parking on-site is required. Due to lot constraints providing spaces for all employees may be impossible therefore a specific number is not required.

The CBD, Central Business District, is established as a public off-street parking district, so that nonresidential uses are exempt from providing off-street parking spaces as otherwise required. Residential uses, including those in mixed-use buildings, must provide off-street parking as required.

Non-residential development and redevelopment in the M-DT district is exempt from minimum parking requirements. Any new residential development in the M-DT district which contains twenty (20) or fewer bedrooms is exempt from minimum parking requirements. Within any mixed use district, no off-street parking is required for any non-residential primary use on a lot smaller than ten thousand (10,000) square feet, if no portion of the front lot line of the property is located within one hundred (100) feet of a residential district.

Within the DC Downtown Commercial District, nonresidential uses in existing buildings are exempt from parking mandates. Residential uses and new buildings in the district may pay a fee in lieu of required parking.

The CBD Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
There are no parking mandates in the Central Business District. The City has simplified its parking requirements and has maximums in place for all land uses.
In 2024, Infrastructure Cook Islands proposed updating the building code to provide flexibility to the existing parking mandates when there is ample public parking.
Areas which are located within a fire district as designated on the official map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of motorcycle parking.
Parking requirements are reduced within the Downtown Commercial District.

Any nonresidential use in the C-2 District that applies to the DDA and is accepted as a member of the Municipal parking program is not required to provide parking. Multifamily dwellings in the C-2 District have reduced parking requirements.

Properties within the Downtown Parking District are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Properties within the Exempt Parking Area with Cap are exempt from the first 25 parking spaces required. Accessory dwelling units are exempted from parking mandates citywide.
Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums.

Parking requirements may be reduced for all uses through the provision of bike parking or for commercial uses by counting on-street parking or public parking toward the minimums. All uses in the C-2, C-3 and I-1 Districts have reduced parking requirements when located near public parking.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.

There are no parking mandates citywide. Parking maximums vary across four zones based on proximity to the city center and transit availability. Parking minimums applied to residential uses until 2022.
Parking requirements may be satisfied using on-street parking in front of buildings or public lots within 300 feet of primary building entrances. Parking maximums exist for all nonresidential uses.
The B-1 Central Business Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
ADUs may be exempted from parking mandates when certain criteria are met. Within the downtown area, existing buildings are exempt and a fee in-lieu of parking may be provided.

The CBD Downtown Commercial District and properties in the CI Intensive Commercial District located east of U.S. Highway 181 and Upper Broadway Street are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Within the CR Resort Commercial districts, parking requirements are reduced by 50% except for residential hotel, motel and overnight accommodation uses.
Permitted uses in the central business district with less than ten thousand (10,000) square feet do not have to provide off-street parking.
Within the C-1 Central Business District there are no parking mandates except as needed to meet other requirements.
A special parking district covering downtown has reduced parking requirements and the option of a fee in lieu of required parking.
The Corvallis City Council adopted an ordinance at its Nov 21, 2022 council meeting to not enforce parking mandates citywide starting Dec 31, 2022.
Where metered on-street parking is located within three hundred (300) feet of a commercial or business use the parking requirement for that business is reduced by fifty (50) percent.
The B-2 Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Within the Central Business District, the minimum parking requirements are waived.
Within the city center, parking requirements are reduced by 40-50% depending on zone. Elsewhere in the city, parking requirements may be reduced by 20% when located near transit.

No off-street parking is required for any use in the city's C-4 commercial district, except for residential portions of a mixed commercial-residential structure. The C-4 district covers the northern part of the city's central business district/downtown and the One Hundred Block of West Broadway historic district, as well as a small area near the Missouri River.
The C-4 Commercial district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The total number of accessory parking spaces provided for one-family, two-family or multiple-family dwellings or hotels may not exceed the minimum requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Parking minimums do not apply to any parcel less than 5,000 square feet in area or for the rehabilitation or reuse of structures existing on October 15, 2020, within locally designated historic districts. Ten of the sixteen primary districts are exempt from minimum parking requirements. In districts where parking is required, a number of uses are exempt including ADUs, townhomes, upper story residential uses, government services, medical clinics, bars, and more. Parking maximums apply citywide. Parking requirements may be reduced with on-street parking, bike parking, proximity to transit, or a use meeting certain requirements in the Hillside Stability Overlay District.
Commercial establishments in the Division of St. John do not have any off-street parking requirements.
The B-3 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Off-street parking is not required for commercial developments in the “C-1” Downtown Commercial District.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the C-1 Downtown Commercial District.
The C Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
There are no required off-street parking spaces for uses located in the CBD Central Business District.
On-street parking may count towards parking minimums in the B-1 Downtown Business District.
Off-street parking requirements do not apply to the C-3 (Downtown Commercial) Zoning District.
Parking requirements are reduced by 30% within the MC Mixed Commercial Zone.
The C-2 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for any nonresidential use, except within portions of the "B2" District.
The C-1 zone is exempt from parking minimums, but maintains recommended minimums.

For all non-residential uses in the C-2 Central Business District the number of required parking spaces shall be fifty percent (50%) of the number otherwise required. Cash in lieu of parking may be authorized by the City Council for remaining requirements in the C-2 Central Business District. In all districts, on-street parking directly in front of a lot may count toward fulfilling the parking requirement of that lot. One parking space credit may be given for every partial on-street parking space in front of the lot that is over fifty-percent (50%) of the length of the on-street parking space. In addition, an exemption of one thousand (1,000) square feet may be applied toward the calculation of required off-street parking spaces if on-street parking is provided adjacent to the proposed use.
Multi-family dwellings have a maximum parking ratio of two spaces per dwelling unit.

Parking maximums exist for most uses citywide. Minimum parking requirements may be reduced with Planning Commission approval upon the provision of bike parking, transit accessibility, valet parking, or transportation demand management plans.

There are no minimum parking or loading requirements for any commercial use in the C-1 Central Commercial District. Minimum parking and loading requirements are applicable for all residential uses, except for residential uses located on the second or higher floors of a commercial building built prior to January 1, 1990.

Within the B District, all uses except for lodging and gaming uses are exempt from parking mandates. Any non-gaming commercial business or non-commercial use located on Bennett Avenue between 5th Street and A Street is also exempt.
Off-street parking requirements do not apply to the C-3 (Downtown Commercial) Zoning District.
Minimum parking requirements are not applicable to property in the CB Central Business District, except for residential uses which are authorized by a conditional use permit.
Crosby MN has no minimums in the B1 central business district (including mixed use) for all allowed uses.

Within the MSMU Main Street Mixed Use District, the minimum parking requirements are waived. No site plan may be approved for a multi-family or nonresidential use which contains more than 120 percent of the development’s minimum number of required parking spaces, except as granted through a conditional use permit.
The C-4 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
The B-1 Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Uses within the Downtown District and Virginia Street Corridor are allowed a reduction in the required number of parking spaces to provide 70% of the required number of spaces for a similar new building or use. When meeting these provisions would constitute a hardship or make the redevelopment of properties in these districts economically impractical, the City will receive a cash contribution in lieu of on-site parking facilities. In all districts, maximum parking may not exceed 125% of the minimum standards for parking lots with fewer than 200 spaces and 115% of the minimum standards for parking lots with greater than 200 spaces.
Within the TC district, no off-street parking spaces are required for non-residential development. Parking maximums exist for most nonresidential uses in all districts.
Culver City officially adopted a zoning code amendment that abolishes all parking requirements city-wide, becoming the first in LA County to do so. Parking maximums are also being explored.
The Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking and loading requirements are reduced by 50% in the Mixed-Use Special Overlay District.
The C-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No parking is required in the B-1 Central Business District except for dwelling units constructed in conjunction with business uses.
The Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Parking minimum requirements for multifamily housing built for the elderly were reduced from 2 parking spaces per dwelling to 1 parking space per dwelling citywide. 

Parking minimum requirements for mixed-use and multifamily developments located in a special transit zone were reduced between 15-75% based on the distance from a transit stop.

Parking requirements are reduced for non-residential uses in the MU-6 downtown district by right, and for all uses citywide for bike parking, on-street parking or public parking. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.
Within the TC Town Center District, a fee-in-lieu of required parking may be provided.
A reduction in the minimum parking requirements is allowed equal to the percentage of bicycle parking spaces provided, with a 5% maximum reduction.
The “C-1” Traditional Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The Downtown Commercial Subarea is exempt from parking mandates.

Within the Central Area Districts, no parking is required of buildings which existed prior to June 26, 1967 or for ground-floor retail and personal service uses except for establishments serving alcohol or commercial amusement uses. Additionally, no parking is required for the first 5,000 square feet of ground-floor floor area for a restaurant without drive-in or drive-through service.

As of February 2024, there is a proposal to eliminate most parking minimums in the city.
There are no minimum parking requirements for residential uses town wide, there are no minimum parking requirements for any uses in the Town of Danby's Hamlet Center and Hamlet Neighborhood zones.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Within Area 1 (Old Town Retail), a portion of the required parking must be provided in municipal parking lots, for which a fee in lieu must be provided.
The C-3 central business district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Off-street parking spaces are not required for permitted business and office uses in the B-4 Zoning District. Parking requirements are reduced for shared parking.
There are no minimum parking requirements in the Primary Central Business District. Parking reductions are available in other districts based on the availability of public parking.

Nonresidential uses in the C-2 District are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Residential uses have in the district have a reduced requirement of one space per dwelling unit with one bedroom or less.
No minimum off-street parking requirements for developments in the C-E Casino Entertainment District.
A change of use in an existing building is exempt from parking mandates in the CBD Central Business District and the HC Highway Commercial District.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No requirements for on-site parking are required in the CC Central Commercial District.
No parking is required in the C1 Central Commerce District except for dwelling units.
Minimum parking requirements are exempt in the C-T Commercial Transitional District, C-1 Neighborhood Commercial District, C-D Downtown District, and C-V Village of East Davenport District.
The off-street parking requirements do not apply to uses within the C-2 Downtown Commercial District.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: In the Village Center, Village Edge, and Village Commerce Planning Areas , existing buildings and infill housing on existing lots of record may meet requirements with on-street parking and will be considered conforming. Such buildings are eligible for change of use permits for building upfits and expansion. Payments in lieu of parking may be provided for development in the Parking Overlay District. In all districts, detached, attached, mixed village, and townhouse building types may meet parking requirements with on-street parking, while parking maximums exist for all uses.
In the C-3 general commercial district, only employee parking is required.

Parking requirements may be reduced through the availability of public parking citywide. Within the C-1 Commercial Central Business District, parking requirements may be reduced for mixed-use developments.
Commercial uses zoned V-M (Village Mixed Use) are exempt from off-street parking requirements.

There are no minimum parking requirements for non-residential uses located in the central business (CBD) and urban business (UBD) zoning districts. Commercial land uses in certain districts (MGC, MNC, EGC, ENC, SGC, SNC, MX, and T) must meet minimum and maximum requirements.

No minimum off-street motor vehicle parking ratios apply to nonresidential uses in the MX1 district. In addition, nonresidential uses in the MX1 district may not provide parking in excess of 125% the minimum motor vehicle parking ratios required in other districts.
No off-street parking or loading is required in the C-2 Central Business District.
No off-street parking or loading space is required for any use located in the “C-1” Business - Central District.
The C-2 Downtown Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The DC-Downtown Commercial District is exempt from off-street parking requirements.

Studio apartments are exempt from minimum parking requirements. The total number of accessory parking spaces provided for a single-family, duplex, or multiple-family dwelling may not be more than 50% or four spaces, whichever is greater, more than the minimum number required.

The off-street parking regulations do not apply to any use of new buildings or structures, or any existing principal building or structure which is enlarged or increased in capacity, when located with the areas bounded as follows:

a. Beginning at a point where the centerline of the right-of-way of First Street crosses the centerline of the right-of-way of Oak Street; thence Easterly along said centerline of Oak Street to a point where said centerline of Oak Street crosses the centerline of Seventh Street; thence Southerly along the said centerline of Seventh Street to a point where the
said centerline of Seventh Street crosses the centerline of Grove Street; thence Westerly along said centerline of Grove Street to a point where said centerline of Grove Street crosses the centerline of Second Street; thence Northerly along said centerline of Second Street crosses the Southerly right-of-way line of the Union Pacific Railroad; thence Westerly along said Southerly right-of-way line of said railroad to a point where said Southerly right-of-way line crosses the centerline of First Street; thence Northerly along said centerline of First Street to the point of beginning.

b. Beginning at a point where the centerline of the right-of-way of First Street crosses the centerline of the right-of-way of the Union Pacific Railroad right-of-way, thence easterly along the centerline of said railroad right-of-way to a point where said centerline intersects with the centerline of Second Street, thence southerly along said centerline of Second Street to a point where it intersects with the centerline of Grove Street, thence easterly along the centerline of said Grove Street right-of-way to the intersection with the centerline of the right-of-way of Fifth Street, thence southerly along said centerline of the right-of-way of Fifth Street to a point where said centerline intersects with the centerline of the right-of-way of Franklin Street, thence westerly along said Franklin Street right-of-way centerline to the point where said centerline intersects with the centerline of the First Street right-of-way, thence northerly along said First Street centerline to the point of beginning.
Uses located in the B-1 Downtown Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The B-5 Central/Downtown Development District is exempt from parking mandates.
There are no parking mandates. Instead the Zoning Administrator or Planning Commission reviews parking based on a table of parking recommendations.
Parking maximums apply to uses with more than 50 parking spaces.
No off-street parking is required in the B-1 General Commercial District.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.

The off-street parking requirements do not apply to nonresidential uses within a mandatory parking district. For residential uses within a mandatory parking district, the parking requirements are one space per unit. In planning unit 4, in the historic overlay zone, existing and new uses in buildings built prior to January 1, 1941, are not required to provide off-street parking facilities.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums, except for single-family or two-family dwellings.
Dearborn eliminated parking requirements for all uses in the Public Parking Sector of the West Downtown District.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply in the B-5 Central Business District.

No additional parking is required for a change in use, as allowed within the zoning district, for an existing building or the use of previously unused space within an existing building within the DDPD.
The B-4 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Parking spaces are not required for commercial or industrial uses established in blocks where 50% or more of the area was occupied by such uses at the time of passage of this chapter.
Nonresidential uses in buildings less than 1,000 square feet and located on a lot in the commercial districts or the downtown districts are exempt from the requirements of providing off-street parking.
The number of required off-street parking spaces may be reduced by the number of on-street parking spaces directly in front of the subject property. Parking maximums exist for most uses.
The C-1A Decatur Square Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Off-street parking is not required in the C-3 Central Commercial Business District.
No off-street parking or loading is required in the B-1 Central Business District.
The B-2 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums citywide, except for single-family and two-family dwellings.
The CB Commercial Business Zone is exempt from parking mandates.
All business uses located within the B-4 Central Business District are exempt from off-street parking requirements.
Within the Business Commercial (BC) District, the parking requirements are waived.
The VC-2 Village Center Business District is exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums citywide.
Parking requirements are reduced by 50% within the B-2 Central Business District.
The CBD Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements and does not allow off-street parking.
Minimum parking requirements are waived in the B-3 downtown development district.
Minimum parking requirements are not applicable to property in the B-1 Central Business District, except for residential uses which are authorized by a conditional use permit.
The buildings facing the Railroad Tracks on Pennsylvania Avenue from East Street in Delmar Maryland to Grove Street in Delmar Delaware are exempt from parking mandates.

Commercial uses in the CBDO Central Business District Overlay are exempt from parking mandates where there is adjacent on-street parking, or when other public parking is nearby. No parking is required for the residential portions of mixed-use buildings in the CBDO district where there are 2 or less residential units in the building.

Parking maximums are set at 130% of the minimums except for single-family residential developments, schools, colleges, child care centers, hospitals, places of worship and assembly, single-entity owned corporate office campuses thirty (30) or more contiguous acres in size, call centers, and industrial zoned development.

The B-1 District is exempt from parking mandates, except for residential uses, churches, hotels, child care facilities, schools, funeral homes and adult care facilities. A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for these uses however.
Any use within the CBD Downtown Denison District is exempt from the off-street parking requirements.
The minimum number of required off-street parking spaces may be reduced by the number of on-street parking spaces abutting the property lines of the parcel. Maximum parking applies to most uses.

In 2004 Dennis adopted the Dennis Port Village Center Zoning District (Section 8 of Dennis ZBL) cutting minimum required parking by 50% and established a maximum parking of 5 spaces per 1000 sf. These changes applied to all uses in the Zoning District.

In 2007 the town adopted the West Dennis Village Center District extending the minimum required and maximum allowed parking to this area as well (Section 9 of Dennis ZBL).
Within the Central Business Commercial (CBC) District, parking requirements are determined by the Planning Commission, which may require a fee in lieu of parking.

Parking mandates do not apply to properties containing less than 5,000 square feet of lot area, except for single-family detached, duplex, and townhome dwelling uses, or for residential development with 10 or fewer dwelling units in the MD Mixed-Use Downtown Core district, or for non-residential development in the MD district. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums. Parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking, bike parking, transit, infill development or senior or affordable housing.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Exemptions exist for small uses near transit, affordable housing, or retail in mixed-use projects. Numerous reductions are available and parking maximums apply to most uses. The D-C, D-TD, D-CV, D-GT, D-AS-12+/20+, D-CPV-T/R/C Downtown Districts have no parking mandates.
Nonresidential uses in the Business District from the railroad crossing west to the intersection of Main Street and Fourth Street are exempt from parking mandates.
The "B-4" Central Shopping District is exempt from minimum parking requirements. Parking requirements in the "B-2A" Buckner Business District are reduced.
Parking maximums apply to certain uses depending on district.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Within the DX Downtown Districts, there are no minimum parking requirements, while the minimums for other districts are set as the maximums. Within the MX1 and MX2 Mixed-use districts, uses must provide parking equal to 60% of the minimum parking ratios and may not provide parking in excess of 120% of the minimum parking ratios. In all districts, parking requirements may be reduced for all uses through the provision of carshare parking, bikeshare facilities and motorcycle or scooter parking. Nonresidential uses may also count on-street parking spaces abutting the subject property towards the parking requirements.
Residential uses within 2,500 ft of an operational or proposed passenger rail station, or an operational bus rapid transit station in the C-3 Mixed-Use PUD zone may reduce parking requirements
Parking requirements are reduced for mixed-use developments.
A payment in lieu of parking spaces may be made for a commercial or industrial use.
Uses in the B5 and PC Districts and in any other district in the Central Business District area shall be exempt from off-street parking requirements.

Restaurants in any zoning districts except for the PRB-1 and PRB-3 Zoning Districts, with less than 2,000 square feet assigned for patron use, have no off-street parking requirements. All other commercial establishments in any district with 2,000 square feet or less assigned for patron use are also exempt.
The C-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: No minimum parking is required for developments in the CBD zoning district. Within the Village Commercial District, a fee in lieu of required parking may be provided. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums, except for single-family dwellings.

The following portion of the Central Business District is exempt from parking requirements:
The area bounded on the south by the railroad right-of-way, on the east by the center of First Avenue East, on the west by the center of Fifth Avenue West and on the north by the center of the alley between Main Street and First Street North.
The draft zoning code from March 2024 would allow for a reduction in required parking when golf cart parking is provided and would establish parking maximums at 110% of the minimums.
Any use within the DC Downtown Commercial District is exempt from the off-street parking, payment in lieu of parking, or loading requirements.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for nonresidential uses in the Core Area.

In the Central Business District, the following parking reductions are allowed:
Retail/Service      - 15% Reduction
Food and Beverage      - 15% Reduction
General Offices      - 5% Reduction
Financial Institutions   - 5% Reduction
The C-1 Commercial/Downtown district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Existing platted areas that are, or previously have been, in commercial use in the C-1 General Commercial District are exempt from parking mandates.
The B-C Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

No off-street parking or loading space is required for any use located in the DMU Downtown District or for any individual use in a space that is 2,000 square feet or smaller in any district. On-street parking may be used to meet a portion of the minimum off-street parking requirements.
No use may  provide on-site parking for more than 300 percent of the number of spaces required unless permitted by specific action of the commission.

On-street parking may count towards parking requirements. Parking requirements are reduced for most nonresidential uses located in areas designated as “core” on the Door County Comprehensive and Farmland Preservation Plan future land use maps.
The Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Property with adjacent on-street parking or within 1,000 feet of a public parking facility are exempt from parking mandates.

On August 16th, 2022, Dothan created the  'U.S Highway 84 East Overlay District' and as a part of this zoning scheme created a sub district named the 'Downtown Core' centered around Foster Street within Dothan's downtown area. This ordinance removed parking minimums for motor vehicles and added parking minimums for bicycles for residential and commercial land uses in the sub district. Parking minimums were also removed from all uses, except single-family dwellings and townhomes, within the 'Downtown Edge' district.

Within the MUI Mixed Use/Infill Development Overlay Zone off-street parking is not required where physical constraints make adherence to parking requirements infeasible. Otherwise parking must be provided.
Within the C-1 Village Center District, parking requirements are reduced for any use permitted by right.
New and existing uses within the CB-1 (Downtown Business) zoning district are exempt from off-street parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The Downtown District is exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums apply in all other districts. Parking reductions are available for uses near transit and through other means.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
There are no statutory parking requirements in Dover, NH. There are parking maximums for all uses and required off-site parking is determined on a per-case basis as part of the application process.
The "B-3" Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Commercial uses requiring one hundred (100) or more parking spaces may not provide more than four and one-half (4.5) spaces per one thousand (1,000) square feet of floor area unless otherwise approved through the special use approval process. Minimum off-street parking requirements do not apply in the DC Downtown Core District or DB Downtown Business District or the Fairview Concentrated Business District, except for residential uses, medical offices, dental or health practitioner offices, and any nonresidential uses requiring Village Council approval. Parking in all districts may be reduced through the provision of motorcycle parking, carshare service, or dedicated EV parking.
Within the TND, C-1, C-2 or C-3 Districts, a fee in lieu of required parking may be provided.

Within the Central Commercial (CC) District, the first 400 square feet of an office or retail and consumer service use is exempt from parking mandates, with uses greater than 400 square feet having reduced requirements.
Parking requirements may be reduced through covered bike parking, access to transit, transit passes or carsharing. A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided.
No off-street parking is required for commercial establishments within the B-1 Central Business District Commercial Zone.
Within the Downtown Commercial (CD) Zone, parking spaces are not required for commercial uses which are less than 900 square metres in gross leaseable area.
Storefront businesses in the C-1 Primary Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

When the application of the off-street parking provisions results in a requirement of not more than three (3) spaces on a single zoning lot in any business, office research, or industrial district, such parking spaces need not be provided where the building is unmanned; however, where two (2) or more uses are located on a single lot, only one (1) of those may be eligible for the exemption.

Within the Bridge Street District, parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking, carshare, transit proximity, showers, or TDM measures. Parking maximums apply to some uses in the district.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for uses in the TC-2 Town Center 2 District and PVD Planned Village Development District.

Within the C-4 Downtown Commercial District, off street parking is not required. New surface off street parking lots are prohibited unless approved by the city council. Underground and aboveground parking garages are allowed provided they are an integral part of a new or existing building.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Within the CBD Central Business District, off-street parking is not required for any use occupying a building that existed prior to the adoption of the current Development Code. In addition, restaurant and retail uses are exempt from minimum parking requirements within the CBD. Within all districts, the total number of spaces provided may not exceed 120% of the minimum spaces required.

On December 11, 2023, Duluth removed parking requirements citywide while parking maximums remained in place. Previously no parking was required in downtown Duluth, while most uses were exempt within the Canal Park area. Parking minimums were reduced for uses near transit.
Off-street parking requirements do not apply to the C-1 Downtown Commercial District.
Nonresidential uses in the CBD Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Buildings and uses in the B-1, Central Business District are exempt from providing off-street parking, with the exception of new residential uses. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.
A fee-in-lieu of parking may be paid towards municipal parking.
Dunwoody has no minimum parking requirements. The city converted parking minimums into parking maximums in 2019.
Parking requirements are reduced within a special parking district downtown where a fee in lieu of required parking may also be provided.
The B-1 district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Parking requirements may be reduced for mixed-use developments that provide on-street parking, for nonresidential uses that provide bike parking, for hotels that provide shuttle service to the airport, for multifamily uses in the CB Zone that provide carshare, or for large businesses that implement a TDM program. A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided in the CB Zone.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
On December 11, 2023, Durham County joined the city in ending parking mandates.

On November 20, 2023, Durham eliminated parking mandates citywide for all uses. Durham previously had a set of parking ratios, but certain districts were exempted or only required to build a percentage of the ratio. There are maximums for all uses and in all districts based on a percentage of the ratio, as well.
The area known generally as the Central Business District and more particularly described as that area within the CB District, is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Any use within the C-3 Central Business District is exempt from the off-street parking requirements.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements except for dwelling uses.
On-street parking in the CGD Cedar Grove District may count towards nonresidential parking requirements.
The B-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

scope: city center / business district,citywide,main street / special,transit oriented
summary: Existing buildings in the BD Broadway District are exempt from parking requirements. A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided in the downtown area. On-street parking along local residential streets may count towards parking minimums. Parking requirements may also be reduced for bike parking, proximity to transit, proximity to a trail, TDM, and for reduced need populations.
The B-1 central business district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Nonresidential uses and single-family dwellings are exempt from parking mandates.
The B-1 Retail Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Commercial and industrial uses are exempt from parking mandates citywide.

Within the B-1 Downtown Business District, no parking spaces are required unless the computation of total parking spaces requires ten or more additional parking spaces for the establishment. In computing whether ten additional parking places are required, all the following exemptions must first considered. Exemptions are as follows:

1. For retail stores and facilities providing personal and commercial services, the first 2,500 square feet of floor area on the first floor and the first 3,500 square feet of floor area on any other floor of an existing building are exempt from the parking requirement.
2. For business and professional offices, the first 1,500 square feet of floor area on the first floor and the first 3,000 square feet of floor area on any other floor of an existing building are exempt from the parking requirement.
3. For establishments providing for the sale and consumption on the premises of food and refreshment, the first 2,000 square feet of floor area on the first floor and the first 2,500 square feet of floor area on any other floor of an existing building are exempt from the parking requirement.
4. For educational services, the first 2,500 square feet of floor area on any floor, except the first floor of an existing building, are exempt from the parking requirement.

New developments must provide parking, however, nonresidential uses may pay a fee-in-lieu of required spaces to meet the requirements.

Establishments in any district which have paid an assessment for the provision of off-street city parking lots are exempt from off-street parking requirements. The City Planning Commission may reduce the total parking spaces required if the developer provides accommodations for transit facilities and vehicles or if the developer provides bicycle racks and bicycle access.
Certain properties in the Gaslight Village Business District are exempt from parking requirements, excluding residential and special uses.

Nonresidential uses in an existing building along Main Street are exempt from parking requirements. Nonresidential uses citywide may count on-street parking towards parking requirements and when in an existing building, may discount the first 1000 square feet. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums.
Commercial and residential uses in the Commercial Downtown One District (CD-1) have reduced parking requirements.
The Downtown Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
In instances where it is physically impossible to provide adequate off-street parking, particularly throughout the Commercial District on Baltimore Avenue, parking mandates do not apply.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The B-3 City Center Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates, and no private off-street parking may be provided. Mixed-use developments containing residential uses citywide have reduced parking requirements. Parking maximums apply to uses with 50 or more parking spaces, and to all residential uses in RA, R-1, R-2 and R-3 low density residential zones.
The Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
The B-2 Medium-Density Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The B-2 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Other than for residential and institutional uses, the number of parking spaces provided may not exceed the minimum requirements.

Nonresidential uses in the NC Neighborhood Mixed Use Commercial District are exempt from parking mandates and residential uses may count adjacent on-street parking. Uses in the C General Commercial District may count adjacent on-street parking or nearby public parking towards requirements.

Within the Main Street Overlay Districts, parking requirements are reduced by 50%, except for office uses. Additionally, nonresidential uses in existing buildings are exempt from parking mandates. A neighborhood center development may reduce parking where valet parking is provided.
No off-street parking is required for any use within the 100 and 200 blocks of West Commercial and Main Streets.
The C-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Commercial uses in the Central Business District (C-1A) are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums apply to single-family dwellings.
Nonresidential uses in the CBD Central Business District are exempt from parking mandates.

Within the Central Business (CB) District, the minimum parking requirements are waived. In all districts, no site plan may be approved for a multifamily or nonresidential use which contains more than 120% of the development's minimum number of required parking spaces.
The Central Business District (CBD) is exempt from parking mandates.
Properties within the CBD Zoning District are exempt from the off-street parking requirements. Parking maximums apply to most uses citywide.

Within the DD Downtown District, nonresidential uses requiring fewer than 7 spaces or residential uses with less than 4 dwelling units are exempt from parking mandates. Mixed-use developments within the Downtown District (DD) and Business and Entertainment District (BE) have reduced parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
Non-residential projects in the DT Downtown District, accessory dwelling units, affordable housing and small businesses with an occupancy level of 50 persons or less are exempt from parking mandates.
Parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking, bike parking, EV chargers and transit.
Parking maximums are set at 130% of the minimums except for one- or two-family dwelling units or for the approved storage of vehicles for auto repair, sales, and storage and distribution.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.

Off-street parking for nonresidential uses may not exceed the minimum number of spaces required by more than 25%, except as approved by the Commission. Various reductions are available upon approval of the Commission for bike parking, transit, etc.

Upper floor residential dwellings in the CBD Central Business District are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums except in the “O-C” Open Space Conservation District.
Eliminated parking minimums and established maximums in November 2021. (Auto repair shops require two spaces per repair bay, which is also the maximum for this use).
Eden Prairie has both parking minimums and maximums in the Transit Oriented Development (TOD) and TC Town Center Districts.
The CBD Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-1 Downtown Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

No requirements for on-site parking are required in the Central Business District (B-2), except that land uses permitted as conditional uses shall require a parking waiver from the Plan Commission following a request from the Applicant.
Uses in the C-1 Commercial District are exempt from parking or loading standards, unless specifically required by conditional use or special exception.

Parking maximums exist for apartment buildings, residential uses in the Mixed Development District, and multiresidential uses in the Planned Commercial District. Parking requirements may be reduced through the availability of frequent transit, carshare services or bike parking. However, the area which would have been occupied by the eliminated parking spaces must be devoted to pervious surfaces, stormwater facilities, tree retention or native landscaping.
Off-street loading and parking requirements do not apply in the C-1 Downtown Commercial District or the University District.
Small scale restaurants, retail uses, manufacturing plants, and furniture and appliance stores are exempt from parking mandates.
The commercial core area is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums, but may be exceeded with increased landscaping.

Minimum on-site parking requirements have been removed from Edmonton’s Zoning Bylaw, allowing developers, homeowners and businesses to decide how much on-site parking to provide on their properties based on their particular operations, activities or lifestyle.
Commercial uses in the central business district are exempt from the parking space requirements if they are located within 300 feet of a public parking lot.
No off-street parking need be provided for any uses when they are located in the B-3 Central Business District.
Parking requirements may be met through the payment of a fee-in-lieu of parking or, upon village approval, a requirement for employees to park in a village owned parking lot.
No off-street parking or loading space is required for any use located in the “C-2” Business - Central District.
The downtown plan area waives parking requirements for all development, regardless of land use.
Off-street parking requirements do not apply for uses within the Central Business District.
Exceeding the minimum parking requirements by greater than 10% is not allowed, except as approved by the Planning Commission.
Nonresidential uses in the D-1 Downtown District are exempt from parking mandates and residential uses have reduced requirements. Various nonresidential uses are exempt citywide.
The C-2 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Land uses located within the CC1 Center City District are not required to provide off street parking. Land uses located within the CC2 Center City District and within 800 feet of a municipal parking facility may be exempted by the development administrator.
Properties in the commercial district adjoining Main Street from TH 42 to the C.N.W. Railroad are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

For uses in the CBD that would require less than twenty (20) spaces, there is not any required off-street parking. Where residential uses require more than 20 spaces in the district, parking requirements are reduced.

Properties located within the Downtown Historic District are exempt from minimum parking or loading zone requirements. Any off-street parking constructed within the boundaries is limited to a maximum of six parking spaces.
Parking requirements are reduced in the Downtown (DT) district by right and may be further reduced through payment of a fee in lieu of parking.
Commercial uses in the C-3 and C-5 zones less than two thousand two hundred (2,200) square feet are exempt from parking mandates.
Permitted uses within the C-5 Downtown Mixed Use Zone are not required to provide off-street parking unless ten or more spaces are required.
Nonresidential uses in the CBD Central Business District are exempt from parking mandates.

ADUs are exempt from parking mandates if any of five conditions are met. Parking requirements may be reduced for office, commercial or industrial uses when bike facilities are provided, or for office or industrial uses when carpool spaces are provided.
Minimum parking requirements are not applicable to property in the CB Central Business District, except for residential uses which are authorized by a conditional use permit.
The B-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements. Parking maximums in all districts are set at 120% of the minimums.
Residential parking requirements are reduced in the DD Downtown District.
The C-2 General Office and Retail District is exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for breweries, brewpubs and dwelling units.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The first 3,000 square feet of gross floor area is exempted from minimum parking requirements for nonresidential uses in the Central Business District (CBD). Up to 25% of the number of public parking spaces within 400 feet of a proposed building in the CBD may be counted toward the required number of spaces. Citywide, bicycle parking may be substituted for required parking, while maximum parking is set at 130% of the minimums.

Within the B-1 Central Business District and the T-1 Transitional District, off-street parking is not required for a change of use. However, where new construction and/or expansion of existing uses occurs, parking per the standard parking requirements is required.
Uses operating within the Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

All principal permitted nonresidential uses located within four hundred feet (400') of the Central Business District (CBD) public parking corridor, are exempted from providing off street parking. Residential uses in a mixed-use building with no more than four (4) residential units located within two hundred (200) feet of the Downtown Parking Corridor are exempt from the requirement to provide off-street parking.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums in the TC District.
Within the Service Business District (B-1), public parking may substitute for required parking. Parking requirements may be reduced village-wide for bike parking and EV chargers.
In the B-2 Central Business District, the only parking required of proposed uses is one off-street parking space for every apartment.
The C-1 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Off-street parking is not required in the C1 Central Commercial Zone, except for apartment dwellings. Existing buildings in all zones are also exempt, so long as the floor area is not increased.
On-street parking on non-residential portion of side or back streets may count towards minimum parking requirements. Maximum parking requirements exist for all uses.
The C-1 commercial district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
On-street parking may count towards minimum parking requirements. Maximum parking limits apply to all uses except single family dwellings.
Because of public parking facilities, off-street parking is not required in the C-2 General Business District.

In the CBC Central Business Core District, CBOC Central Business Outer Core District, and CBOCR Central Business Outer Core Residential District accessory off-street parking is not required except for residential uses.
The Central Business District (CBD) is exempt from parking mandates.
Parking is not required in the Central Business District (CB) except for dwellings and lodging.

For off-street parking requirements in the C-1 General Commercial District, all on-street parking stalls within three-hundred feet (300’) of the entrance to such use may be counted as part of the required number of stalls.

Within the Downtown Core Overlay Zoning District parking requirements are reduced by 50%, with the exception of service stations, grocery and supermarkets, laundries, and motels and hotels. Nonresidential uses citywide may count on-street parking towards parking minimums.

Businesses within the Central Business Zoning district are not required to
provide off street parking, except for residential dwelling units that are the principal or accessory use of the site.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the availability of carshare, bike parking or on-street parking.

On street parking may count towards parking requirements citywide while public parking also counts within the Town Center (TC) District. Also in the TC District, nonresidential uses may provide a fee in lieu of required parking and parking maximums are set at 130% of the minimums.
Off-street parking may not exceed the required off-street parking by more than 25 percent.
Uses within the C-1 Central Business District and C-1A Downtown Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The B-D Business Downtown District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

There are no minimum number of parking spaces required for any use, with the exception of accessible space provisions. The maximum number of parking spaces allowed shall be ten percent (10%) more than the estimated parking demand, specified in Table 9-4.404. 

All off-street parking spaces shall be leased or sold separately from the rental or purchase fees giving potential renters or buyers the option of renting or buying a residential unit at a price lower than would be the case if there were a single price for both the residential unit and the parking space(s).

Parcels along State Highway 6 in the DMU zone are exempted from all parking minimum requirements. However, a proposed parking plan must be submitted for review and approval by the Zoning Administrator. Within the DMU Downtown Mixed-Use Zone, surface parking may not exceed 125% of the minimum parking requirement for the subject land use(s).
Within the B-C Downtown District, nonresidential uses under 4,000 square feet are exempt from parking mandates. Within the B-C or R-HO districts, a fee in lieu of parking may be provided.
Within the VZ Village Zone, a nonresidential change of use in existing buildings is exempt from parking mandates. New buildings in the district have reduced minimums.
No off-street parking facilities are required in the C-4 Central Business District.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: No parking is required for nonresidential uses in the MU-B-1 district with frontage on South Broadway. Parking requirements may be reduced for multi-family housing near transit, or through on-street parking for nonresidential uses, or through an administrative adjustment. Parking maximums are set at 140% of the minimums for nonresidential uses.
Uses within the CIO Commercial Incentive Overlay District have reduced parking requirements.
Off street parking requirements for uses located in the core commercial/residential (C-CR) district are one-half (1/2) those required of the same uses in the other zoning districts.
No off-street parking spaces are required for nonresidential uses in the B-2 Downtown Business District, except for Assembly and Educational occupancy type buildings.
Uses within the CBD Central Business District, except for residential or hotel uses, are exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of motorcycle parking.
The C1 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums.

The parking regulations for uses permitted in the A residence district shall apply to such uses when located in the C central business district. No parking space shall be required in the C central business district in any other instances.

Properties in the C-3 Central Commercial District are not be required to provide off street parking. Properties in the W-C-2, W-C-3 and C-4 zoning district are required to provide fifty percent (50%) of the parking minimums.
Parking requirements may be reduced through providing carshare, EV chargers, bike parking, or on-street parking.
In 2022, Escanaba removed parking minimums for all non-residential uses while properties located within the E3 Central Commercial District were exempted from the residential parking requirements.
ADUs are exempt from parking mandates citywide.
Off-street parking and off-street loading standards do not apply to new development and land uses in the CD Downtown Commercial zoning district.
The (GB) General Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Uses on lots less than 2500 square feet and all uses in the C1 District are exempt from parking mandates. Nonresidential uses in the C2 and I Districts have parking maximums.
On November 13, 2023, Eugene repealed all minimum parking requirements, citywide.
The B-3 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Off-street parking is not required in the C-1 Central Commercial District.
There are no parking requirements for businesses or residences in areas zoned C1, Victorian Commercial.

Parking minimums are waived for accessory dwelling units, daycares, hospitals, and parks citywide. Small residential uses, income-restricted affordable housing, and a limited number of dwelling units qualify for exemptions in various districts. For nonresidential uses, small uses are exempt as well as uses in the Downtown (DT), Downtown West (DW), Henderson Center (HC), and Hinge Industrial (HN) Districts, in the Neighborhood Market (NMO) Overlay Zone, or uses within the Parking Assessment District. A change of use is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking minimums may be reduced through frequent transit, the provision of bus passes for residents, bicycle facility proximity, carpool spaces, EV chargers, bike parking, motorcycle parking or in-lieu fees.
New buildings located in D1, D2, D3, and D4 districts can reduce parking requirements by 20% for non-residential uses.

The off-street parking requirements do not apply to nonresidential uses within a mandatory parking district established by the City. Parking requirements may be reduced for residential uses within a mandatory parking district or for elderly housing projects.

All uses permitted in the C-3 central business district are exempt from minimum parking requirements except for residential uses, nurseries, nursery schools, child care centers, hotels and motels, and special uses. In residential zoning districts within the Arts Overlay Zone, off-street parking is not required. Within the West Franklin Overlay Zone, parking requirements are reduced by 25% and may be further reduced with bike parking. Parking requirements in the Jacobsville Overlay Zone may be reduced with bike parking.
