Bike parking may substitute for automobile parking citywide. Parking maximums apply to all uses except single-family dwellings.
The total number of parking spaces provided for a single family or multifamily dwelling may not exceed that required by more than 50 percent or 4 spaces, whichever number is greater.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the Downtown Commercial District (C-1).
The Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Within the DC Downtown Commercial District, properties may pay a fee-in-lieu for required parking. Two family dwellings have a maximum parking limit of 3 spaces per unit.
For all existing and new permitted commercial uses located in the downtown commercial area, as identified by the Comprehensive Plan, no off-street parking is required.
The "C-2" Historic Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements are reduced for mixed-use developments. Parking maximums are set at 120% for all uses except single-family and two-family dwellings.
Uses located in the Commercial District, bounded by Walnut and Maple Streets, are exempt from parking mandates.
The minimum parking requirements do not apply to the C-1 Downtown Commercial District.

On September 26, 2023, Fairfax County passed an ordinance to reduce parking minimums primarily for multi-family residential uses near transit. Parking requirements are reduced in Suburban Centers, Revitalization Areas, Transit Station Areas, Transit Oriented Development (TOD), and the PTC District. Parking maximums apply in the PTC District.
No off-street parking is required in the C1 Central Business District Commercial.
The Old Town Area is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Areas which are located in a fire district as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
One- and two-family residences may not provide more than four parking spaces per unit.
Surface parking spaces may not exceed 110% of the minimums required.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the C-1 Downtown Commercial District.
Within commercial districts, public or commercial off-street parking as well as on-street parking may count towards parking requirements.
Fargo eliminated parking minimums in their DMU (downtown district) for all residential and nonresidential land uses.

Existing properties located within the CBD Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Any development or redevelopment of a cleared site within the CBD Central Business District requires the provision of on-site parking equal to one-half (½) the stalls required.
The C-1 Central Shopping District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Off-street parking is not required in the B-3 Central Business District.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.
The B-2 downtown business district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The CB Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Fayetteville, Arkansas has no minimum requirements for commercial uses. There are residential minimum reductions available if certain criteria are met. They also have several reductions for residential uses as well as parking maximums.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The DT-1 and DT-2 districts are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Parking maximums apply to restaurants except in the DT-1 and DT-2 districts. A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided in the MU Mixed-Use District.
The Central Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates.
Within the CBD, on-street and public parking may count towards requirements unless the Planning Commission decides otherwise. Parking maximums are set at 110% of minimums citywide.
The area bounded by Cavour Avenue on the north; Whitford and Friberg Avenues on the east; Washington Avenue on the south; and Vine Street on the west is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements may be reduced through bike parking for all uses and for showers installed at nonresidential uses.

In the DB-1 Zoning District, no parking spaces or loading facilities are required for existing developed sites. Any on-street parking or public parking facilities not in connection to a public building, and within 300 feet of the property may be counted toward 50% of the total parking requirement.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: The Central Business District (C-3), lots containing industrial waterfront (I-W) or waterfront mixed use (W-1) are exempt from parking minimums.

Existing buildings, except for upper level residential uses, within the CBD are exempt from parking mandates and new buildings may pay a fee in lieu of required parking. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.

The City of Ferndale has minimum parking requirements citywide, with the exception of Accessory Dwelling Units (ADUs). There are also maximum parking requirements for certain uses as stated in section 18.76.070. 

Off-street parking credits are offered to reduce requirements by 25% for certain land uses with specific circumstances
Public parking may satisfy parking requirements in the commercial districts, upon approval of the city. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums citywide.
The C-3 Downtown Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums citywide which may be exceeded through increased landscaping.
Commercial and industrial uses may not provide more than 125% of the parking minimums.
The DT Downtown District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums apply to all uses, but may be exceeded with increased landscaping.
Fitchburg has created a number of SmartCode districts in which there are no set parking mandates.

Developments over 10,000 square feet in floor area or containing 25 or more residential units that provide parking in surface parking lots may not exceed the minimum number of parking spaces by more than five percent unless provided in a parking structure.
The C1 Central Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking minimums are eliminated in the Downtown Business (DB) zoning districts, primarily on Main Street and some adjacent side streets.

Within the city center, parking requirements are reduced by 30 to 50% and cultural event sites may be exempted from parking mandates. Citywide, parking requirements may be reduced through a fee in lieu of parking, a mobility concept, or for cultural monuments.
Nonresidential uses are eligible for a ten percent reduction in required parking spaces if all spaces are located to the side or rear of the principle building.
Parking cannot exceed 20% of the required amount. New parking is not required in the downtown core. For more dense areas of the city, the "Parking Multiplier" can reduce required parking by 50%.

The area known as the Downtown Business Strip, described as businesses located on East North Avenue and West North Avenue between State Street and Sycamore Street, is exempted from minimum parking requirements.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: No parking is required in the Central Business District or the East Florence Historic District.

Within the CB - Central Business district, and the CHB - Central Historic Business district, all uses except dwellings and lodging uses are exempt from parking mandates. Dwellings in these districts have reduced requirements.
In May 2024, Florida passed a bill to eliminate county and municipal parking requirements for transit oriented development, and reduce requirements near transit and public parking.
Non-residential uses in all zoning districts may not contain more than one hundred ten percent (110%) of the minimum number of parking spaces required.

Minimum parking requirements do not apply to uses in the Central Business District (CBD), at the discretion of the planning commission, if the commission determines that the parking needs of the use are met by any combination of on-street parking, joint use parking, parking on a nearby site and municipal off-street parking.
Uses in the GB General Business and RS Retail Service districts may use adjacent on-street and public parking spaces within 200 feet, if sufficient off-street parking is not available.
The “B-1" Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Off-street parking is not required for uses in the Central Business District except for buildings constructed or used for residential living units as the principal land use. The Central Business District is defined as the area bounded by Marr Street on the east, Merrill Street on the north, the East Branch of the Fond du Lac River on the west, and Western Avenue and Fourth Street on the south.
ADUs are exempt from parking mandates if any of five conditions are met.
No site plan may be approved for a multifamily or nonresidential use that proposes more than 120 percent of the development's minimum number of required parking spaces.
The DX Downtown Mixed-Use District is exempt from parking mandates. In other districts, nonresidential uses may count on-street and public parking toward parking requirements.

Retail stores, banks, furniture and appliance stores, household equipment, or furniture repair shops under 2000 square feet are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Wholesale establishments under 4000 square feet are also exempt. The total number of parking spaces provided for one-family, two-family or multiple-family dwellings or hotels may [not] exceed the requirements for such use or for any equivalent new use by more than 50 percent, or four spaces, whichever number is greater.
Within the TCO Town Center Overlay District, the first 1500 square feet is exempt from parking mandates. In addition, on-street parking may count toward the parking requirements.

Commercial uses located east of Centennial Drive, south of 2nd Avenue NE, and north of 2nd Avenue SE, are exempt front the off-street parking requirements of this chapter. Uses with requirements for substantial parking, e.g., theaters and restaurants, are encouraged to provide off-street parking for their patrons.

There are no off street parking requirements for any newly constructed structures for permitted uses in the DBD Downtown Business District, except for those existing parking spaces required to be maintained; provided, however, that all residential uses must provide at least two (2) off street parking spaces per residential dwelling unit. Parking may be required as a condition of approval for newly constructed structures for conditional uses.
Single-family dwellings have a parking maximum of four.
Buildings erected or enlarged fronting Main Street are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-1 General Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No off-street parking is required in the Central Business District.
Within the DHMU Downtown Historic Mixed-Use Zoning District, the minimum parking requirements are waived. Maximum parking limits exist for most uses.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the C-1 Downtown Commercial District.

A change of use within an existing building is exempt from parking requirements. Within the Transit-Oriented Development (TOD) Overlay zone, twenty-five (25) percent of the square footage of gross leasable area is exempt from minimum parking requirements. Parking requirements are reduced by right within the Transit Oriented Development Overlay Zone, and may be further reduced for affordable housing, carshare, distribution of transit passes, or proximity to transit. Parking maximums apply to all uses.
Within the D-1 Downtown Core Sub-District, no parking is required except for town houses or multi-family dwellings.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: Parking minimums for the City Center and Arts and Sciences Districts have been reduced to 1 per housing unit. Nonresidential uses may be exempt depending on size and proximity to other zoning districts. Uses which are not exempt in these districts must provide 60% of the required parking

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: No parking is required in the DT zoning district, however, the Director may require parking for any nonresidential use over ten thousand (10,000) square feet. Parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking or bike parking. Parking maximums are set at 140% of the minimums for nonresidential uses.

The total number of parking spaces provided for one-family, two-family or multiple- family dwellings or hotels may not exceed the requirements by more than fifty percent (50%) or four (4) spaces, whichever number is greater.

Single family dwellings, accessory dwelling units, and businesses located in the historic or downtown district are exempt from minimum parking requirements. In all districts, on-street parking may count towards parking requirements.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking or on-street parking.
Parking requirements are waived for uses in a B-1 Mixed Use District in a block which is more than 50% covered by principal buildings.

Small lots in the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard and Veronica S. Shoemaker Boulevard Overlay District with existing commercial or residential structures and zoned for commercial uses are exempt from parking requirements. Large lots in the district may count on-street and public parking towards the minimums.
The C-1 Central Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
Downtown Fort Smith does not require any parking minimums and it is part of the Form-based Code Zoning District.  
Fort Smith reduced minimums and parking maximums city wide. 
There is reduced minimums for residential use and hotels. These are the only land uses that are exempt from parking maximums.
Nonresidential uses in the CA Central area district are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
There are no minimum off-street parking requirements for uses in the DC/Downtown Core, or DE/Downtown Edge, or for airports, community gardens, cemeteries, fairgrounds, hospitals, nature preserves, religious institutions, or schools.
In the UC/Urban Corridor districts, minimum parking requirements apply only to a new bars, taverns, dance or similar school buildings, restaurants, night clubs or similar entertainment uses, the addition of units to an existing residential structure; or the conversion of a residential structure to nonresidential use.
Parking reductions are available in the City’s nonresidential zoning districts (DC, DE, UC, C1 through C4, SC, NC, BTI, and I1 through I3) via on-street parking, bike parking, public transit access, and the use of pervious surfaces.
Parking maximums exist within the DC and DE districts, set at 50% of the minimums when provided as surface parking, or 100% of the minimums when provided in a parking structure.

For non-residential uses, there are no minimum parking requirements. Additionally, properties designated as historic and cultural landmarks are not subject to minimum off-street requirements and there are no minimum off-street requirements in the Central Business District ("H").

The maximum number of parking spaces shall not exceed 125% of the minimum parking requirement for all uses listed.
A 10% minimum reduction in the number of required parking spaces is required and a maximum allowable reduction of 50% is permitted in the TCFD Town Center Form District.
Parking requirements are reduced for mixed-use developments.
There are parking maximums for certain land uses (apartment, industrial manufacturing, medical/dental, retail/commercial/office, auditorium, automobile repair facility, automobile service station)
A change of use is exempt from parking mandates in the BC Business Center District.

For land uses located in a commercial, mixed-use, or industrial zoning district, the number of parking spaces provided in a ground surface parking lot may not exceed the minimum number of parking spaces by more than 10%. There is no limitation on the number of parking spaces when located in a parking garage or similar structure.
No parking requirements exist in the D Downtown Business District.
The B-1 Downtown Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

When the application of the off-street parking regulations results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single lot in the B1 Retail/Service District or B2 General Business District, such parking spaces need not be provided. However, where two or more uses are located on a single lot, only one of these uses is eligible for the exemption. This exemption does not apply to dwelling units. Parking maximums apply to single-family and two-family dwellings.
Parking requirements in Framingham were reduced in the Central Business District and ground floor commercial uses in the district are exempt from parking requirements.
Parking requirements may be reduced through parking lot landscaping for projects with at least 70 spaces.

When the application of the off-street parking provisions results in a requirement of not more than three (3) spaces on a single zoning lot in any business district, such parking spaces need not be provided; however, where two (2) or more uses are located on a single zoning lot, only one (1) of those uses may be eligible for the exemption.
There are slight reductions available for parking requirements for bike parking and permeable surfaces.

Within Zone IV (city center), multifamily housing has no parking mandates. Parking requirements are reduced by increasing amounts from Zones I through IV, which correspond to a greater access to transit. A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided in these zones.

Single family dwellings are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Parking requirements for all uses may be reduced with proximity to any commuter rail station or transit line. Within the C-1 Neighborhood convenience district, C-4 Commercial flex district, C-5 Commercial manufacturing district, and DT Downtown districts and with approval of the Zoning Administrator, on-street parking spaces may be counted toward the required off-street parking spaces. A fee in lieu for each credit is required for the C-4 and C-5 Districts. In addition, off-street public parking spaces may be counted toward the required off-street parking spaces. A fee in lieu is required for each credit in the C-4 and C-5 Districts, as well as for each credit above five (5) in the DT Districts.
Properties located in the MXD, Mixed-Use Downtown Center district are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Buildings located in the downtown area existing prior to the adoption of the parking standards may use available curb-side and/or street right-of-way parking instead of conforming to parking minimums.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the C-1 Downtown Commercial District.
Nonresidential uses in the CBD Central Business District, unless there is sufficient area to accommodate parking.

Off-street parking is not required for existing structures in the Downtown Commercial (C-1) District. For existing structures in the Service Commercial (C-2) District, the City may approve, through the conditional use process, uses that do not provide the minimum number of off-street parking spaces, provided that the applicant can demonstrate that the need for parking can be adequately met by alternative means.
Downtown is exempt from parking mandates.
The C-1 General Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Within the TC Town Center District, the first 400 square feet of a restaurant or office is exempt from minimum parking requirements, and the first 450 square feet of a retail use.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Within downtown, parking mandates do not apply to buildings 40,000 square feet or smaller and are reduced for larger uses. A reduction of the downtown minimums is possible for proximity to transit or a fee in lieu of parking. Parking maximums apply to most uses citywide.

The B-1 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates. Nonresidential uses in other districts have no set requirements, but are required to demonstrate that the proposed number of parking spaces is sufficient.
No parking is required in the B-1 Central Business District except for dwelling units permitted in conjunction with business uses.
Existing buildings in the C-1 Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The B-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The DBOD Downtown Business Overlay District is exempt from parking mandates.
The downtown district is exempt from parking requirements for all uses.
All businesses on Division Street between State Street and Irving Street are exempt from parking requirements as well as all single-family dwellings village-wide.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for all uses.

The Warm Springs/South Fremont Community Plan, adopted in July 2015, eliminates minimum parking requirements within the community plan area. The plan area is centered on the new Warm Springs/South Fremont BART Station.

Within the C-1 Downtown Commercial District, on-street parking and public parking may count towards parking minimums. A nonresidential change of use in existing structures is also exempt. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums citywide. This zoning code also applies to Dayton Township and Sheridan Charter Township.
Any use within the Downtown Commercial (DC) District is exempt from the off-street parking requirements.
Within the B-1 Central Business District, off-street parking is not required for non-residential uses, or for dwelling units above a business or office or for a condominium development.
Pick-up spaces for online ordering count as 1.5 spaces towards the minimum parking requirement. This does not apply to carry-out spaces at restaurants.
Nonresidential uses within the R-4A and R-4B Zone are not required to provide any off-street parking.

Downtown Districts: No parking minimums for non-residential uses. Parking minimums reduced to .5 spaces per unit.

Mixed-Use District/Commercial Main Street: Require .75 spaces for every studio/one-bedroom apartment, 1 space per two-bedroom, and 1.5 per three-bedroom, plus one per guest per four dwelling units. Commercial uses require one space per 600 square feet.

In the O-8 Transit Oriented Development Overlay District, the number of required parking stalls may be reduced by up to 50% of the number normally required. The maximum number of parking stalls may not exceed 120% of the minimum number of parking stalls required by the use in the underlying zoning district. This maximum provision does not apply to park-and-ride or other transit facilities.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Retail, personal services and restaurant uses are exempt from parking mandates in the Central Core District (CC) and within the Mixed-Use District (MU) that front West Main Street. Other uses have reduced requirements there. Parking maximums apply to residential uses citywide. Parking requirements may be reduced for EV charging facilities and on-street parking.
Parking minimums in the OTC – Original Town Commercial District are fifty (50) percent of the standard parking requirements.

In the C3 Town Center district, additional numbers of off-street parking spaces are not required to be provided, unless a new principal building or building expansion of over five thousand (5,000) square feet of total floor area is constructed or the number of dwelling units or rooming house units on the lot would be increased. Parking requirements for commercial uses in the C1 University Corridor district are reduced by fifty percent (50%).

No off-street parking is required for uses in existing buildings and reconstruction of existing buildings in the DMU zone south of Pabor Avenue (“Downtown Core”).  New buildings in the DMU zone are required to provide 50 percent of the required spaces.
ADUs are exempt from parking mandates citywide. Restaurants within the Restaurant Overlay Zone are also exempt.
Off-street parking requirements do not apply to the C1 Downtown Commercial District.
In the C-1 central business zoning district, businesses are not required to provide off-street parking.
Nonresidential uses in the B-3 and B-4 Districts are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums.
Permitted uses are exempt from the off-street parking and loading requirements in the C-1 Village Center Commercial District.
On 11/29/2022 Gainesville City Council unanimously voted to eliminate parking mandates for all uses citywide.
Gaithersburg has a moratorium on parking mandates in the Olde Towne District (downtown) until 2025. The moratorium applies to redevelopment of existing buildings or changes in land use.
There are no parking requirements in the Downtown Core zone.
The C-1 Retail Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Off-street parking is not required in the B3 Central Business District.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking.
Parking requirements are reduced for uses within the U Uptowne District.
The Urban Square Commercial District (USC) is exempt from parking mandates.

The Central Business District within the following area is exempt from off-street parking requirements: The area bounded on the north by Northeast Second Street and Main Street, on the west by the alley west of Exchange Street (extended from Commercial Street to Main Street), on the south by Commercial Street and on the East by Chester Street and North Center Avenue.
There are no parking minimums in the village, parking maximums apply to all uses instead.
The C-3 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
ADUs may be exempted from parking mandates when certain criteria are met.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
Minimum parking requirements may be reduced according to the following strategies:
1.    Downtown. In the C-1 district, any use under 2,000 square feet is exempt from any on-site parking. All other uses in the C-1 district may reduce the required on-site parking by 40 percent, in addition to all other applicable credits and shared parking reductions.
2.    On-Street Parking Credit. All on-street parking within 600 feet of any lot frontage may count towards the parking requirement at a rate of one space for every three on-street spaces.
3.    Bicycle Parking Credit. All on-site bicycle parking may reduce the required vehicle parking at a rate of one space for every four bicycle parking spaces up to a maximum of 15 percent of the required vehicle parking.
4.    Public Parking Credit. Any site within 600 feet of a public parking area may reduce the required vehicle parking at a rate of one space for every two public parking spaces.

Maximum parking is set at 120% of the minimums, but may be exceeded through mitigating strategies.
Parking maximums apply to most uses.
Within the DT Downtown District, on-street parking may be used to satisfy requirements and the provision of parking that is publicly shared allows for a reduction in requirements.
The C-1 Commercial Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for dwelling units above a store or shop, motels and hotels.
Nonresidential uses within the CU Urban Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: The area defined as the Historic District and existing storefront businesses on Windham Street that do not have off-street parking are exempt from parking mandates.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
Small retail, service and office uses are exempt from minimum parking requirements, while larger retail, service and office uses within the B5-2 District have reduced parking requirements. On lots of record as of the date of the adoption of the chapter, which are 40 feet or less in width and contain a single-family dwelling or a two-family dwelling for which there is no alley to the rear, accessory off-street parking facilities are not required.
Within the B2-2, B2-3, B4-2 and B4-3 districts, no accessory off-street parking facilities are required for any use, nor are off-street parking facilities permitted unless approved by the plan commission.
The total number of accessory parking spaces provided for a single-family, two-family, or multiple-family dwelling or hotel shall not exceed that required for such use or for an equivalent new use by more than 50 percent or four spaces, whichever number is greater.
The B-1 Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Eliminated all minimum parking requirements, except for bicycle parking. They have set street parking maximums for many land uses.
Allowed uses in the “B-1” Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking minimums and maximums exist for all uses.
A Two-Family Dwelling may not provide more than two (2) parking spaces per unit.

For all permitted and special uses, except residential uses within the D-CM Commercial Mixed-Use District and D-RSCM Residentially Scaled Commercial Mixed-Use District, the required amount of off-street parking spaces is the number of spaces that existed on the zoning lot as of July 16, 2001. All permitted and special uses, except for residential uses, established as of July 16, 2001, may be expanded without providing additional off-street parking spaces. A fee-in-lieu of required parking may be paid for new uses.

For uses within the B2 Business District and the boundaries of the Business Improvement District, spaces in municipal parking lots may be credited toward the parking requirements for newly constructed uses less than 5,000 square feet or redevelopment of an existing building 10,000 square feet or less. As an alternative to providing the required parking, a fee-in-lieu of parking may be paid to the city.
Within the Genoa Town Center Overlay District, on-street parking may count towards parking requirements. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums citywide.

When the application of the off-street parking regulations results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single zoning lot in any business district, such parking spaces need not be provided. However, where two or more uses are located on a single zoning lot, only one of these uses is eligible for this exemption. This exemption does not apply to dwelling units.

For all non-residential uses in the CBC commercial district the number of required parking spaces shall be fifty percent (50%) of the number otherwise required. Cash in lieu of parking may be authorized by the City Council for remaining requirements in the CBC District. In all districts, on-street parking directly in front of a lot may count toward fulfilling the parking requirement of that lot. One parking space credit may be given for every partial on-street parking space in front of the lot that is over fifty-percent (50%) of the length of the on-street parking space. Alternatively, an exemption of one thousand (1,000) square feet may be applied toward the calculation of required off-street parking spaces if on-street parking is provided adjacent to the proposed use.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the C-1 Downtown Commercial District.
The B-3 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-1 Downtown Commercial district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided in the Historic Commercial District.
The "B-1" Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
Minimum parking requirements may be reduced or disregarded depending on the following components:
1. Downtown / Neighborhood Commercial. In the C-1 and C-2 districts, any use under 2,000 square feet is exempt from any on-site parking. All other uses in the C-1 and C-2 districts may reduce the required on-site parking by 40 percent, in addition to all other applicable credits and shared parking reductions.
2. On-Street Parking Credit. All on-street parking within 600 feet of any lot frontage shall count towards the parking requirement at a rate of one space for every three on-street spaces.
3. Bicycle Parking Credit. All properly designed and located on-site bicycle parking may reduce the required vehicle parking at a rate of one space for every four bicycle parking spaces up to a maximum of 15 percent of the required vehicle parking.
4. Public Parking Credit. Any site within 600 feet of a public parking area may reduce the required vehicle parking at a rate of one space for every two public parking spaces.
Maximum parking limits are set at 120% of the minimums, but may be exceeded through various means.
Parking requirements may be reduced through on-street and public parking. Maximum parking limits exist for office and retail uses.

The OT Old Town District and ES Elm Street Overlay District are exempt from parking mandates except for residential uses. Parking requirements may be reduced for on-street parking, pubic parking, proximity to transit, bike parking, carshare, or providing right-of-way to a trail.
The "C-3" Core Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

On-street parking may be counted toward the visitor parking requirement for developments in the Single Family Detached (SF-D), Single Family Attached (SFA), Mixed-Use and Multi-Family zoning districts.
The C-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking and loading requirements.
No off-street parking requirements have been imposed since at least 2011.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates. Bike parking may substitute for automobile parking for all uses except single-family or two-family dwellings.
The B Residential District and the F Light Industrial District are exempt from parking mandates.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking.
Accessory off street parking is not required within the C5A core retail area.

Parking requirements for multiple family dwellings in the B-1 Central Business District and B-2 Neighborhood Shopping District are reduced. No off-street parking spaces, except such spaces as may be provided to accommodate the reasonable needs of employees, shall be required, allowed, or provided in connection with any eating place permitted in the B-1 or B-2 Districts unless such eating place is located in a shopping center.
Parking is only required for multifamily dwellings.
Parking maximums apply to some nonresidential uses.

ADUs may be exempt from parking mandates when any of five criteria are met. In the DSP Downtown Specific Plan and TOD Transit Oriented Development zones, parking requirements may be reduced through bike parking, or a fee in-lieu of parking may be provided.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the submittal of a transportation demand management plan.

Properties in the "D" and "E" Business Districts may include on-street parking spaces, when such spaces are within the commercial districts, or off-street municipal parking areas when they are within 500 feet of the property.
The portion of the city zoned central business district is exempt from off street parking requirements.
Lots less than 2500 square feet are exempt from parking mandates.
The Central Business District (CBD) is exempt from off-street parking requirements.

The total number of accessory parking spaces provided for a single-family or multiple-family dwelling may not exceed the requirements for such use or for any equivalent new use by more than 50 percent or four spaces, whichever is greater.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
Properties within the boundaries of the Glenwood Springs General Improvement District No. 1980, as well as nonresidential uses in any zoning district which contain less than five thousand (5,000) square feet of lot area, are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Where parking is required, a fee-in-lieu of parking may be provided instead. In nonresidential and mixed-use districts, uses may not provide more than 125% of the minimum off-street parking spaces required.
Any use within the DC Downtown Commercial District, with the exception of permitted ground level residential uses, is exempt from the off-street parking requirements.

When the application of the off-street parking regulations results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single lot in the B1 Limited Business or B2 General Business districts, such parking spaces need not be provided. However, where two or more uses are located on a single lot, only one of these uses may be eligible for the exemption. This exemption does not apply to dwelling units. Single family dwellings may not provide more than four spaces.
No parking is required in the BC Central Business Commercial District, except 2 spaces per unit for dwellings.
No parking is required in the C-1 Central Business District except for dwelling units permitted in conjunction with business uses.
The C-1 General Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
On May 16, 2023 Gold Hill removed minimum parking requirements.

Cocktail rooms and taprooms may reduce parking requirements when bike parking is provided. Parking maximums apply to uses in the Institutional, Office, Commercial, Light Industrial, Industrial, and Mixed Use Zoning Districts.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: Parking requirements are reduced in the Main Street, Mixed-Use, and Neighborhood Corridor Form Zones. Within the Downtown Development District, a fee in lieu of parking may be provided.

There are no parking mandates for any use in Golf. However, there are no multi-family dwellings, or commercial or industrial uses in the village. Therefore, this only applies to single-family homes and public uses.

Parking requirements are reduced in the C-MS, R-3-MU, and TND Districts by right. Citywide, parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking, transit availability, structured parking, carshare and tree preservation. Parking maximums apply to single family dwellings.
In any business or industrial districts, establishments which pay an assessment for the provision of off-street parking lots are exempted from off-street parking requirements.
Minimum parking requirements apply only to roadside stands and multi-family housing.
The C Downtown Commerce District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No off-street parking or loading space is required for any commercial use located in the C-2 Central Business District.

Parking spaces in lots owned by the village may be included in determining the required number of spaces, provided that the spaces are within 500 feet and the planning commission determines that spaces are available. Within the central business district, on-street parking spaces along the lot's frontage may also be counted towards meeting the minimum required number of spaces.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The “C” Commercial and Light Industry District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Off-street parking is not required in the CB Central Business District.

The DMU Downtown Mixed Use District is exempt from parking requirements. Residential uses in the DMU must provide evidence of the availability of off-street public in the amount of one parking space per dwelling unit within 1,000 feet of the unit. Parking maximums exist for most uses citywide.
In downtown B-1 (CBD) zoned areas, there are no minimum parking requirements for all land uses. For nonresidential land uses, there are parking maximum requirements citywide.

Within the "downtown area", defined as the area north of the railroad, south of Walnut Street, from Greg Street to the alley one-half (1/2) block east of Main Street, existing buildings are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.

Within the CB Central Business District, office, business, personal, and professional services are exempt from parking mandates when not located on the ground floor. All other uses have reduced requirements which may be further reduced through a fee in lieu, on-street parking or tuck-under parking.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.

Establishments in any district which have paid an assessment for the provision of off-street city parking lots are exempt from off-street parking requirements. The city planning and zoning commission may reduce the total parking spaces required if the developer provides accommodations for transit facilities and vehicles or if the developer provides bicycle racks and bicycle access.
ADUs are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums are set at 150% of the minimums.

Nonresidential uses in the LDR, MDR, DR, NS, CC, OS, S, E, OT, NMU, B, TI, and CB districts may count on-street parking towards parking minimums. Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums citywide.
No car parking is required in the Downtown Business District and the Four Street Business District.

Nonresidential uses are exempt from minimum parking requirements in the Redevelopment Area and Corridor Infill Area. Parking requirements may be reduced through proximity to transit, proximity to trails, and for bike parking.

On-street parking may count towards parking requirements in the Multiple-Family, Commercial, Commercial Transitional, Resort, Light Industrial, and General Industrial Districts. A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for any use.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: All uses within the Central Business District are exempt from parking requirements. Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums, except for single-family and two-family dwellings. Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking.

Non-residential uses within the Downtown Districts (DW Core Downtown Waterfront District, H61 Highway 61 Corridor District,  MU Commercial-Residential Mixed Use District) are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Existing buildings with frontage on the 300 East to 400 West blocks of Main Street are exempt from parking requirements. The total number of parking spaces provided for non-residential buildings in excess of 30,000
square feet in area may not surpass 115% of the minimum parking requirements.

Grand Rapids, MI eliminated minimum parking requirements in the TN-CC zoning district. Citywide, reductions in minimum requirements are available subject to Planning Commission approval based on special requirements. 

In April 2024, the city eliminated parking minimums for ADUs, and small residential developments in  the TN-LDR and TN-MDR Districts. Reductions were also expanded around transit.
Uses constructed in the CBD zone are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.

Grandview has eliminated parking minimums, city-wide, for all commercial and industrial zones. There are now maximums in those zones. If a developer or property owner wishes to build more than allowed, they must do so using a permeable paving/paver system to capture, filter, and release the stormwater created from the additional hard surface area.
On-street parking may count towards minimums in the form-based code districts. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums citywide.
The “C-3” Central Business and Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-2 Downtown Commerce District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
On-street parking may be used to satisfy parking requirements where the streets are designed to accommodate on-street parking.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for any use citywide.

Grants Pass removed all parking minimums in May 2024 in accordance with the Climate Friendly & Equitable Communities program. Previously, the CBD was exempt from off-street parking requirements as well as land uses within a 1/2 mile of a frequent transit route.

Any legally established use in the Main Street Retail Business District on Main Street may be changed to any other legal use without providing any additional off-street parking, provided no expansion of the existing principal structure has occurred.
Within the Village Gateway District, parking requirements are reduced for residential uses and parking maximums apply to all uses.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums, for parking lots with 50 or more spaces.
Parking requirements are reduced for uses in the CBD which have on-street parking in front of the lot.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums for nonresidential uses.
Nonresidential buildings and uses located within the CBD are exempt from providing off-street parking. Citywide, parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The Downtown District is exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums apply in all other districts. Parking requirements may be reduced through transit, small commercial uses in the C-N District and through various other means.
Non-residential uses in the Central Business (CB) Zone are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Off street parking requirements are waived in the Uptown Grayson District. The total number of parking spaces may not exceed one hundred ten (110%) percent of the minimum number of off-street parking spaces required.

The number of parking spaces provided in a ground surface parking lot may not exceed the minimum number required by more than twenty (20) percent or by ten (10) spaces, whichever is greater. In the central business core (C-4) and central business periphery (C-5) zoning districts, the number of parking spaces may be reduced below the minimums.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Nonresidential uses under 10,000 square feet are exempt from parking mandates within the General Improvement (GID) overlay district. Parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking, bike parking or public parking. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums for nonresidential uses.
Parking is not required for non-residential uses in the downtown zoning district of Green Bay, WI.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Developments in the DV-O downtown village overlay district that contain at least 50 percent commercial uses have reduced parking requirements.
The B-2 Downtown Business District is not required to provide off-street parking spaces.
Non-residential uses in the CB Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
In the (CC) Community Commercial District, off-street parking spaces are not required, but are encouraged.
Vehicle parking requirements do not apply in a block 50% or more of the area of which was occupied by business or industrial structures as of 3-5-1957.

When the application of the off-street parking regulations results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single lot in any business district, such parking spaces need not be provided. However, where two or more uses are located on a single lot, only one of these uses is eligible for the exemption. This exemption does not apply to dwelling units. Maximum parking limits apply to single family dwellings.

Commercial uses with less than five thousand (5,000) square feet of floor area in the DT District are exempt from minimum parking requirements. All other uses in the district have reduced requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The "D" (Downtown) zoning district is exempt from parking mandates. Adjacent on-street parking may count toward parking minimums and a fee in lieu of parking may be provided. Parking maximums apply to most uses.

No off-street parking is required for properties in the CB district or for the reuse or rehabilitation of a historic site or landmark. Nonresidential uses on lots with less than 60 feet of frontage are not required to provide parking unless such use exceeds 3,000 square feet. Parking requirements are reduced in the TN, MU-M, MU-H and CN districts. In the AO, NS, LIM, UMU, C-M, C-H and BP districts, mixed use and adaptive reuse projects have reduced requirements. Citywide, projects that connect with an existing or planned greenway may have reduced parking mandates.
The downtown square (one hundred block of East Main Street, North Franklin Street, East Washington Street, and North Broadway Street) is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Off-street parking is not required in the CP-3 Planned Commercial Downtown and RV-P Planned Residential Village districts.
On October 9, 2023, Greensburg removed parking requirements from the XA Downtown District.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The minimum parking ratio standards apply to all zoning districts, except the “D” (Downtown) Zoning District. The minimum parking ratios do not apply to the TND or TOD use patterns. Single-family dwellings are exempt citywide. Parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking or the payment of a fee in lieu of required parking. Maximum parking ratios apply to most uses.
Parking requirements are reduced by 80% within the DE Downtown Enterprise District.
Within the Mixed-Use Overlay District, parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking and bike parking.
There are no set requirements in the downtown area, but developers must justify less parking, and historic structures are exempt from parking requirements.
Parking requirements for all uses may be reduced through the provision of bike parking, proximity to transit, rideshare service, public parking, on-street parking or mature tree preservation.

Off-street parking requirements do not apply to uses within the C-2 General Commercial District, however all uses considered places of assembly, such as churches and halls, should provide for off-street parking.
The B-3 Heavy Commercial CBD District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements may be reduced through motorcycle parking.

Minimum parking requirements do not apply to any uses of new buildings or structures, or any existing principal building or structure which is enlarged or increased in capacity within the Downtown Business District.

Uses located within the Governors District are exempt from parking mandates, however are required to ensure practical parking provisions are provided. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums citywide.
The C-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No parking or loading is required in the C-1 Central Business District.
Within the village parking district, a fee in lieu of required parking may be provided. Within the C-1 District, parking requirements are reduced to account for on-street and public parking.
The Commercial District (C) is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Any new development in the C-1 Commercial District is exempt from parking or loading standards, unless specifically required by conditional use or special exception.
There are no off-street parking requirements in the “C-1” Central Commercial District.

The central business district of Gulfport, as shown on the official zoning map, as well as all parcels that front on the north side of 11th Street between 31st Avenue and 36th Avenue are exempt from off-street parking requirements.
The CBD Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates except for bed and breakfasts, hostels or hotel/motels. ADUs are exempt citywide.

When parking facilities are constructed for commercial, office, or industrial use over 5,000 square feet in gross floor area, except for those located in the C-5 or C-6 District and any restaurant use, the number of vehicle parking spaces provided may not exceed 115% of the required minimum.
No off-street parking is required in the C-4 Downtown Business Commercial District.
A change of use for an existing building in the B-3 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Parking mandates do not apply to uses within the Central Business District
conducted in structures existing as of December 16, 1997.
The C-2 General Office and Retail District is exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for permitted residential uses, which require two off-street parking spaces.
Single-family, two-family and semi-detached dwellings on infill lots, and uses in the CC-MU District where public parking is available are exempt from parking mandates.
No parking lot may exceed the required number of parking spaces by more than twenty (20) percent, except as approved by the village board.
Halifax removed all parking minimums in the Downtown Plan Area in 2009.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Commercial uses under 10,000 square feet are exempt from parking mandates. On-street parking may count towards parking requirements. Parking maximums apply to all uses, but only for parking reserved for specific tenants.
The B-1 Central Business Zoning District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Commercial and institutional establishments occupying existing buildings in the Central Business District and businesses which are established in former residential structures in properly zoned areas are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Parking requirements for all uses in the CBD Central Business District and for residential uses in all zones may be reduced through the availability of on-street parking. Parking maximums apply in the CBD Central Business District.

Parking requirements may be reduced through the availability of public parking or on-street parking, bike racks, mixed-use development, electric car chargers, and the reactivation of vacant commercial storefronts.
The C-3 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for hotels and convention centers. Parking maximums exist for single-family and two-family dwellings.

Within the Central Business District areas zoned MX-CBD there are no parking mandates. Portions of the Central Business District zoned other than MX-CBD may be exempt from off-street parking requirements upon proof that adequate legal public on-street parking is available. Citywide, parking requirements may be reduced through transit, pedestrian access, public parking, on-street parking, or bike parking.
In November 2023, Hampden removed parking minimums for all uses except daycare facilities. In place of minimums, a maximum impervious area was implemented.

In a B-1 Central Business District, off street parking is not required for the first ten (10) parking spaces otherwise required under this section. In addition, the following exemptions apply to existing buildings:

1. For retail stores and facilities providing personal and commercial services, the first two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet of floor area on the first floor, and the first three thousand five hundred (3,500) square feet of floor area on any other floor of an existing building are exempted from parking requirements.
2. For business and professional offices, the first one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet of floor area on the first floor, and the first three thousand (3,000) square feet of floor area on any other floor of an existing building are exempted from parking requirements.
3. For any establishment providing for the sale and consumption on the premises of food and refreshment, the first two thousand (2,000) square feet of floor area on the first floor, and the first two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet of floor area on any other floor of an existing building are exempted from parking requirements.
4. For educational services, the first two thousand (2,000) square feet of floor area on the first floor, and the first two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet of floor area on any other floor of an existing building are exempted from parking requirements.

New developments must provide parking, however, uses may pay a fee-in-lieu of required spaces to meet the requirements.

Off-street parking requirements are waived when a commercial or industrial use or use of a public nature is located in the C-CBD Central Business District Commercial District, except when said use is predominantly transportation oriented such as an automobile service station, car wash, drive-in or fast food type restaurant or transportation terminal.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Within the PH-1 and PH-2 Districts, all non-residential uses, except religious facilities, colleges/universities, schools, auditoriums and theaters are exempt for the first 5,000 square feet. In mixed-use districts, the first 3,000 square feet of pedestrian oriented ground floor commercial retail space is exempt from minimum parking requirements. On-street parking may count towards parking requirements and various other parking reductions are available. Parking maximums apply to most uses. On May 8, 2024, the city removed parking mandates from the Overlay - Coliseum Central (O-CC) District under certain conditions.
There are no parking requirements in the CBD for any use in Hamtramck, MI.
All uses and buildings within the Downtown Mixed Use (DMU) District, are exempt from the minimum parking space requirements.
Commercial uses in the E Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Within the five VC Village Center Zoning Districts, nonresidential uses may count on-street parking spaces towards satisfying off-street motor vehicle parking requirements. Further reductions are possible through a design exception.
Parking maximums are set at 130% of the minimums.
Parking requirements may be reduced for mixed-uses or the provision of public amenities, such as sidewalks, no driveway curb-cuts, etc.
Commercial uses in the C-1 and C-2 commercial districts may count public parking towards parking requirements.
A fee-in-lieu of required parking may be provided in the C-2 Central Commercial District. Parking maximums apply in all districts.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The CC City Center, TND Traditional Neighborhood Development, and TOD Transit-Oriented Development districts are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Parking maximums exist for most uses. The minimum and maximum parking requirements are reduced in the TND development type of the Mixed-Use district and in the TOD development type of the Mixed-Use district. Parking requirements are reduced for the provision of EV charging stations and for parking lots that directly connect to a greenway or bicycle path.
Off-street parking requirements do not apply to all land uses within the Downtown Center and Commercial Neighborhood Zoning Districts.
Parking requirements are reduced in the V-1 village district and V-1A village district: downtown waterfront. In the V-1A district, a fee in lieu of required parking may also be provided.
Within the C-1 Central Business District, a first floor less than 3,000 sq feet is exempt from parking minimums. A change of use in existing buildings is also exempt.
Parking maximums apply to all uses except single-family dwellings. Parking requirements may be reduced when bike parking is provided.
The minimum parking and loading space requirements do not apply to the Downtown Redevelopment District.
There are no minimum off-street parking requirements for uses in the "B-1" central business district.
The "CBD-1" Downtown Core Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

The total number of parking spaces provided for a single-family, two-family, or multiple-family dwelling may not exceed the minimum requirements by more than 50% or four spaces, whichever number is greater.
The CBD is exempt from parking minimums. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums for multi-family and nonresidential uses citywide.
The B-1 Central Business District and HD Historic District are exempt from parking mandates.
New form based zoning code with parking maximums city wide.
The “C-1” Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Within the B-1 Central Business District, parking requirements are reduced by 50%. Within the B-2 General Business District, a change of use does not require additional parking.
Minimum parking requirements are not applicable to property in the CB Central Business District, except for residential uses which are authorized by a conditional use permit.

Nonresidential uses and buildings erected, enlarged, extended or increased in a B-3 central business/mixed-use district may, upon village board approval, meet some or all of its parking requirements by using public parking available within 400 feet of the use or building. A use which uses this provision shall, upon approval by the village board, make a one-time payment equal to the documented cost of constructing, as well as maintaining, the required parking.
The (C-1) Downtown Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Spaces within parking lots and structures may include designated areas for bikeshare facilities. When a minimum of 15 bicycles are provided for rental, such bikeshare facilities may substituted for up to four automobile spaces or 5% of the required parking spaces, whichever is less. Within the B-1-RC Retail Core Sub-District and B-1-MU Mixed-Use Sub-District, residential dwelling units above the ground floor are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Parking requirements may be reduced based on a bonus point system, where after a developer accumulates ten bonus points, the required off-street parking restriction is reduced by one space. Bonus points may be earned through the provision of street trees, seating, improved sidewalk textures, bike racks, canopies over the sidewalk, covered arcades, and facades that are in keeping with the master plan design plan.
The Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

In the B-1 Neighborhood Shopping District, on-street parking spaces may be counted toward required off-street parking spaces. New on-street parking spaces may be created to count toward required off-street parking. A fee-in-lieu of providing some or all of the required number of off-street parking spaces for non-residential uses in the B-1 Neighborhood Shopping District and B-2 Central Shopping District may be granted by the village. Parking maximums exist for single-family and two-family dwellings.
On-street parking may be counted towards the minimum parking requirements for commercial, industrial, and public-civic uses. Parking maximums apply to all uses.
The maximum number of parking stalls may not exceed 20% of the minimum required unless the City Council grants an exception.

No use shall provide more than ten percent over the minimum required parking without exhausting all options for parking credits or shared parking. No site shall be permitted to provide more than 25 percent of the required parking in any circumstance.
Within the Core Commercial District, a fee in lieu of required parking may be provided.

No off-street parking is required in the B-4 Downtown Business District, although adequate on-street and off-street parking and unloading spaces must be demonstrated by the applicant for places of assembly, daycare centers, schools, and residences.
Off-street parking is not required in the C5 Downtown Commercial District.
Retail business and service uses in the C-1-A Central Shopping District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The “B-2” Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Off street parking is not required for businesses in the C-1 central business district. New or enlarged structures must be provided with off street parking.
Nonresidential uses adjacent to metered on-street parking are exempt from parking mandates.
Off-street parking provisions do not apply to the Central Business District (C-3).
Lots less than 2500 square feet are exempt from parking mandates.

The Mission Boulevard Form-based Code, adopted in 2020, removes all minimum parking requirements within the code area. The code applies to approximately 480 acres along Mission Boulevard, a major commercial corridor that traverses the length of the city. The code also establishes maximum parking requirements for residential land uses, but not non-residential uses.
All permitted, accessory or conditional land uses in the CBD Central Business Overlay District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.
There are no off-street parking requirements in the C-1 Central Business District.
The Downtown Overlay District is exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums apply to all uses except single-family homes.
Downtown Healdsburg has no parking requirements for non-residential uses for developments less than 15,000 square feet.

Parking space requirements do not apply to business uses in a block where 50 percent or more of the area was occupied by business or industrial structures at the time of the passage of the Ordinance in 1981.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: Parking requirements may be met through on-street parking in the Mixed Use Overlay, the R-2 Residential, and the C Commercial Districts.
No parking minimums apply in the Downtown District and Transitional Residential District, while parking maximums are enforced in these districts.
No off-street parking spaces are required in the central business zone.
No off-street parking spaces are required in the central business zone.
The Downtown district is exempt from parking and loading requirements.
The B-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Off-street parking facilities are not required for uses within the C-1 Central Business District except for dwelling units.
Residential uses have a maximum parking limit of four spaces per dwelling unit.
No off-street parking or loading space is required for any use located in "B-5" Central Business District.
There are no off-street parking requirements in the "C-1" General Commercial District located within the boundaries of an "HO" Historic Overland District.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.
The Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No off-street parking facilities are required in the “C-3”, Central Business District.

When the application of the off street parking regulations results in a requirement of not more than three (3) parking spaces for any commercial or business use, those parking spaces are not required. However, where two (2) or more uses are located on a single lot, only one of those uses may be eligible for the exemption. In no instances may the exemption apply to dwelling units.
Parking requirements are reduced for most commercial uses in the CBD central business district and CR commercial-residential zoning districts.
No off-street parking or loading space is required for any use located in the “B-4” Business - Primary District.
There are no minimum number of off-street parking spaces required in the C-2 General Commercial District except where the use is a conditional use.
Off-street parking requirements do not apply to uses within the C-1 Commercial Limited District.
No minimum parking requirements in Central Business District zoning district.
The "DC" Downtown Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
There are no set parking minimums in High River, each development shall consider the appropriate number of stalls to support the use.

Parking requirements in the B-5 Central Business District may be reduced for retail uses, service uses, food and beverage establishments, general offices, or financial institutions by right. In all districts, parking may be reduced through frequent transit, a carpooling program, a shuttle service, a carshare program, valet parking, and bike parking. In most districts, a fee-in-lieu of required parking may be provided.

Parking requirements may be reduced citywide through the availability of transit, designated spaces for fuel efficient vehicles or carpooling, bike parking, or on-street or public parking. A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided in the TOD or CBD Districts. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.

No off-street parking is required for buildings and uses located within the boundaries of an area enclosed by 12th Street, Walnut Street, 9th Street, and Pine Street provided they are located within 500 feet of a public parking lot.
Parking maximums exist for residential uses. Parking requirements may be reduced for senior housing, or through the provision of on-street parking or bike parking.
No off-street parking is required for housing for the elderly.
Nonresidential uses in the MN/C and CBD Zoning Districts may count public parking towards parking requirements. Nonresidential uses citywide may count on-street parking towards parking requirements.
In all districts, parking requirements may be reduced through a payment of a fee-in-lieu of required parking.

For all non-residential uses in the C-2 Central Business District the number of required parking spaces shall be fifty percent (50%) of the number otherwise required. Cash in lieu of parking may be authorized by the City Council for remaining requirements in the C-2 Central Business District. In all districts, on-street parking directly in front of a lot may count toward fulfilling the parking requirement of that lot. One parking space credit may be given for every partial on-street parking space in front of the lot that is over fifty-percent (50%) of the length of the on-street parking space. In addition, an exemption of one thousand (1,000) square feet may be applied toward the calculation of required off-street parking spaces if on-street parking is provided adjacent to the proposed use.

Parking requirements are reduced by 50% for non-residential uses in the Old Hilliard District and may be reduced for bike parking citywide for most uses. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums citywide.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: Minimum parking requirements do not apply to commercial buildings in existence at the time of adoption of the parking ordinance or to new commercial uses where it can be demonstrated that adequate public parking exists when located within the B-1 District. Additionally, minimum parking requirements are not applicable to uses located in the B-1 District on State Street from Veterans Memorial Highway north to the Village limits. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums village-wide.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply in the “C – 1” Commercial District.
The Historic and Business “G” Zoning District is exempt from parking mandates.
On-street parking spaces may be included in parking calculations in the B-2 downtown business district. Parking maximums apply to banks, retail stores and offices.
The CBD Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Within the B-2 central business district, a fee-in-lieu of required parking may be paid for the first seven spaces otherwise required. Additional spaces may be reduced through council approval of a further fee-in-lieu payment.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Retail, services, restaurants, bars, and offices are exempt from parking mandates within the CDT Central Downtown, EDT East Downtown, and CENT Centennial form-based code districts. Maker spaces in the CDT district are also exempt.
The C-1 General Commercial District is exempt from parking regulations.
All uses within the CBD (Central Business District) are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Retail, commercial, and office uses located on the first and second floor of a building on sites within DH-3 east of 21st Avenue; ND-3 south of Polk Street; PS-3 north of Van Buren Street; RC-2; and YC districts are exempt from parking requirements. Parking requirements are reduced for uses in the Regional Activity Center and Downtown and Beach Community Redevelopment Districts where parking maximums also apply.
Parking requirements within the B-1 Downtown Business District are lowered for all uses.
Parking requirements in the Town Center district are reduced by 20% and requirements for mixed-uses are reduced by 25%.
Within the C-1 Central Business District and C-2 Neighborhood Mixed-Use Commercial District, nonresidential uses are exempted or have reduced parking requirements based on size.
No use may exceed the minimum number of off-street parking spaces required by more than twenty-five percent (25%) unless otherwise approved by the Director of Economic and Community Development.
The C-1 Central Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates.
Honolulu County removed parking minimums for all uses in two of the most urbanized planning regions on Oahu, including Honolulu, and also removed parking minimums for all uses in TOD zones.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Nonresidential uses in the MX-D, RX-D, MX-TOD, and RX-TOD zones may not provide parking in excess of 125% the minimum motor vehicle parking ratios established for "all other zones." Within the MX-TOD and RX-TOD zones, non-residential uses are exempt from parking requirements, but a parking study and TDM plan is required for large uses. Minimum motor vehicle parking ratios do not apply to nonresidential uses in MX-D and RX-D zones. Off-street parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of affordable housing, the availability of a public parking lot or garage, landscaping, carshare or bikeshare services, or by providing motorcycle or scooter parking. Nonresidential uses in MX-N and RX-N zones may count on-street parking spaces towards the minimum parking requirement.
A change of use for an existing structure or building in the B-3 Central Business District does not require compliance with minimum parking requirements.
No minimum off street parking required in the business district/Downtown.
The General Commercial (GC) District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
New business uses within existing buildings located along Bridge Street from Oak Street to Third Street are exempt parking requirements.
All uses and buildings, except lodging facilities, within the Downtown are exempt from the minimum parking space requirements.

There are no minimum parking requirements within the Central Business District (CBD); There are no parking requirements within primary Transit Oriented Development (TOD) streets and a 50% reduction along secondary TOD streets. In 2019, minimum parking requirements were also removed in parts of the Midtown and Downtown East neighborhoods.
Parking requirements may be reduced for industrial or office uses which complete a trip reduction plan.
Howell has no required parking for uses in the Central Business District. New residential construction is exempt.
No off-street parking is required in the CBC Central Business Commercial District, except for dwelling units.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the Downtown Mixed Commercial District.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to uses located in the C-1 central commercial district.
No required off-street parking spaces, voted on by City's Common Council in 2019.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Within the Darrowville Commercial Corridor District and the Village Core District, on-street parking may count toward parking minimums. Historic structures in the Darrowville Commercial Corridor District are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums citywide.

All parcels in the B-3 Central Business District are exempt from the provision of off-street parking for the first 6,000 square feet of building area, except for new construction projects for which 1/2 of the normal off-street parking is required. All parcels in the B-4 Central Business District for new construction projects must provide 50% of the required off-street parking required per the land use designation. A fee in lieu of off-street parking may be accepted as an alternative to providing off-street parking in both districts.
Parking requirements are reduced by right in the CBD and on-street parking may partially fulfill requirements citywide. Parking maximums are set at 130% of the minimums.
On-street parking may count towards parking minimums.
The B-2 General Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Restaurants in the C-CBD and C-RN districts, and retail uses in the C-CBD District have reduced parking requirements.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the C-1 Downtown Commercial District.

Congregate housing and civic uses are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Within the Town Center (TC) District, existing buildings and infill housing on existing lots of record may meet requirements with on-street parking and are considered conforming as to parking. Such buildings are eligible for change of use permits, for building upfits, and for expansion.
Residential buildings may meet parking requirements with on-street parking if individual driveways are minimized and the fronting street is specifically designed to meet the parking needs of the residential buildings.

Airports, hospitals, religious institutions and schools are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Within the nonresidential zoning districts (C1 through C4, SC, NC, BTI, and I1 through I3), parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking, bike parking, transit or the use of pervious pavement.
The downtown mixed-use district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
