Within the C-D and C-P Districts, nonresidential uses in existing buildings are exempt from parking mandates. New buildings and residential uses may provide a fee in lieu of required parking.

ADUs are exempt from parking requirements when located within one-half mile walking distance of a high-quality transit corridor, or a major transit stop, or there is a car share vehicle located within one block of the project. Within the Downtown Specific Plan Area, a fee-in-lieu of parking may be paid.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
Off-street parking in the C-1 district has been reduced by 50% for nonresidential uses. Nonresidential uses within 660ft. of a public parking lot will are exempt from off-street parking requirements.
Off-street parking is not required in the Central Business C-B District.
A change of use in a building existing prior to the code adoption is exempt from parking mandates.
Minimum parking requirements are not applicable to property in the CB Central Business District, except for residential uses which are authorized by a conditional use permit.

Uses in the CBD Central Business District are exempt from providing off-street parking, except in the case of residential dwellings, hotels and motels, religious institutions, private and public schools and universities, hospitals, congregate care facilities, senior housing, convalescent or nursing homes.

Surface parking lots may not exceed 125% of the required minimum number of vehicle parking spaces. A change of use within an existing building in a business district does not require off-street parking.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The Downtown District is exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums apply in all other districts. Parking reductions are available for uses near transit or uses which meet other criteria.
Areas which are located in a fire district as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Off-street parking requirements do not apply to changes of use within existing buildings in the C-5 Downtown District. Minimum parking requirements must be met by any new residential construction projects.
Permitted uses in the C-1 Neighborhood Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Both commercial and residential uses are permitted in the district.

The “downtown” area; described as the area bounded by Chicago Northwestern Railroad on the north, Burns Street on the east, Third Street on the south, and Quimby Street on the west is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided within the downtown area.

The Local Parking Regulation Act was introduced on January 31, 2024 and would limit the ability of a unit of local government from imposing minimum parking requirements on a development project if the project is located within one-half mile of a public transportation hub.
Within the B-2, CBD District, public parking may count towards parking minimums unless the Planning Commission determines otherwise. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums citywide.
No off- street parking or loading space is required for any use in the "C-2" Central Business District.
The C-3 central business district is exempt from off-street parking and loading requirements.

No off-street parking spaces are required for the rehabilitation or reuse of existing structures within the NC Neighborhood Commercial zone. Parking requirements citywide may be reduced through carshare, EV chargers, bike parking, or on-street parking.

Nonresidential uses in the Historic Square zoning district are not required to provide off-street parking unless such uses exceed 4,000 square feet of gross floor area, in which case off-street parking must be provided for the floor area in excess of 4,000 square feet. Nonresidential uses within the Pedestrian Street Overlay district are not required to provide off-street parking unless such uses exceed 10,000 square feet of gross floor area, in which case off-street parking must be provided for the floor area in excess of 10,000 square feet.

In one-family residential districts, the number of parking spaces may not exceed three spaces per dwelling unit on lots of 12,000 square feet or less, and not more than four spaces per dwelling unit on lots of more than 12,000 square feet.

The C-3 Commercial District and residential uses which are located in the
Central Business District are exempt from parking mandates. Corner commercial uses in the C-N District under 2500 square feet are exempt from parking mandates. Other uses under 2500 square feet in the C-N District have reduced requirements.

Parking maximums exist for all uses. Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking. The minimum parking ratios are reduced by 25% by right within the Downtown Master Plan Overlay District and the Village Center Overlay District.
Commercial uses in the C-1 and C-2 districts are exempt from parking mandates.
No Off-Street Parking is required in the Mile Square Area or MU-4 District.
The C-3 Downtown Mixed-Use Zoning District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Within Zones 1 and 2, a fee in lieu of required parking may be provided. Upon approval, parking requirements may be reduced with a TDM plan for apartments or offices, or with bike parking for shops.
No parking is required in the B-1 Central Business District except for dwelling units permitted in conjunction with business uses.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Off-street parking is not required for uses in the DM Downtown Mixed-Use District. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums for commercial and industrial uses. Parking requirements may be reduced for uses within the mixed-use and downtown fringe districts (CM and DF) where there is transit access.
There are no minimum off-street parking requirements for uses located in the C-1 Central Business District.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
The CB-5 and CB-10 Zones are exempt from minimum parking requirements. In addition, parking maximums exist for the CN-1 Zone and hospitality oriented uses.
The Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The Central Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Buildings and uses located within the CBD are exempt from providing off-street parking.
The number of spaces provided shall not exceed twenty percent (20%) beyond the number required.
ADUs may be exempted from parking requirements due to state law if certain conditions are met.
Parking requirements are reduced for nonresidential uses in the TOD District when located near transit. Parking requirements are reduced for uses in the Urban Business Overlay District.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Developments located on vacant parcels on Main Street are exempt from parking mandates.

Parking requirements for Principal Uses in the CBD Central Business District are eliminated with the exception of dwelling units which must have Two (2) off-street parking spaces per unit. Conditional Uses, except for establishments selling alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises, must meet parking requirements.
The nationwide parking standards have both minimums and maximums. Uses may have only minimums, only maximums, or a range. The parking standards vary based on proximity to transit.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special,transit oriented
summary:
Ithaca New York does not require any parking for the Central Business District downtown, the West End, Cherry Street District, Newman District, Market District or Mixed Use Districts.
On July 5, 2023, the city removed parking requirements for the B-1a, B-4, B-5, and MU-2 zoning districts, which encompass parts of downtown and collegetown.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Multifamily dwellings in buildings with 4 units or less are exempt from parking mandates in the C-3 Central Commercial District. All other uses in the C-3 District have reduced requirements and parking maximums apply to all uses citywide.

The off-street parking regulations do not apply to businesses and residences located within the area bounded by Washington Street to the north, Missouri Street to the west, West Adams Street to the South, and Hope Street to the east where existing on-street public parking and shared or public parking lots are available.
The C-4 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
In October 2021 Jackson eliminated all set parking mandates in the city, projects propose on-site parking individually as part of the application process.
Places of public assembly, restaurants and retail establishments within the Shopping Center Business District (C-2) are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
There are no parking minimums anywhere in the Downtown overlay district.

Minimum parking requirements do not apply to any re-occupancy of existing buildings or structures within the following area of the B-2 Central Business District:

The area bounded on the north by the alley north of Court Street; on the east by the alley east of Mauvaisterre Street; on the south by the alley south of Morgan Street; and on the west by the alley west of Sandy Street.

A reduction in the number of required off-street parking spaces for the re-use of an existing commercial building in any district may be authorized under a special use permit.
The DT Downtown Mixed Use and CF Community and Institutional Facilities districts are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Properties located in the downtown overlay district are exempt from all off-street parking requirements.
Within the C-3 Central Business District - Downtown, there is no minimum number of off-street parking spaces required, regardless of use.
On-street parking may be counted towards fulfilling the parking requirements for businesses in the commercial downtown district.
Off-street parking spaces are not required for any uses in the Central Business District (B-2).
No off-street parking or loading is required in the B5 Central Business District.
Uses are prohibited from providing more than one hundred twenty percent (120%) of required spaces unless more spaces are approved by the Zoning Administrator.

No minimum parking is required for new or redevelopment in the B-2 Central Business District. Minimum off-street parking requirements within the Mixed-Use Overlay District are one-half (1/2) of the required spaces. In districts where one hundred (100) or more parking spaces are required for a site, additional parking spaces may not exceed fifteen percent (15%) of the minimum requirement.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The Downtown District (D) is exempt from parking mandates, except for standalone multifamily dwelling buildings. Accessory Dwelling Units are exempt from mandates citywide. Within the Urban Center District (UC), on-street parking may be counted towards parking minimums and parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums excluding dedicated residential spaces and parking structures.

Where there is a municipal parking lot within 500 feet, the parking spaces required for non-residential uses and mixed uses may be reduced by ten percent of the total spaces in the municipal lot or lots. Where on-street parking exists on a street adjacent to a new or expanded use located within the Old Town District, the required number of off street parking spaces for the new or expanded use may be reduced by one space for each 25 feet of frontage on the street, up to a maximum reduction of five spaces.
On-street parking may count towards parking requirements in the "PR-2" Planned Residential District or "PM" Planned Mixed Use District.
The CBC – Central Business Commercial District and MH – Manufactured Housing District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The parking requirements are waived within the DHMU Downtown Historic Mixed-Use Zoning District. Parking maximums exist alongside parking minimums.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The Downtown District is exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums apply to all uses except in the Downtown District. Parking requirements may be reduced through proximity to transit, mixed-uses, corner commercial uses, NRHP listings and through various other means.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Within the M2 and M3 Districts, parking requirements may be reduced when located near a bus stop or when bike parking is provided. In commercial and industrial districts, parking requirements may be reduced through proximity to transit, on-street parking, bike parking, mixed-use development, or carpool parking. Lots in the CD and CN districts that are under 10,000 square feet are exempt from the parking minimums. Parking maximums apply in non-residential districts.

The first two residential units in a mixed-use building in the TC Town Center District are exempt from parking mandates. A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided in the TC, NCR and G Districts. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
Parking maximums are set at 130% of the minimums for multifamily, mixed-use, and nonresidential uses.

When the application of off-street parking regulations results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single lot in any business or commercial district, such parking spaces need not be provided. However, where two or more uses are located on a single lot, the foregoing exemption shall apply only if the total requirement for all uses is three spaces or less. The total number of accessory parking spaces provided for a single-family, two-family or multiple-family dwelling shall not exceed that required by more than 50% or four spaces, whichever is greater.
Any private use in the C-2S Special Shopping and Service Commercial District may reduce parking requirements by twenty (20) percent.
Parking maximums apply to single-family and two-family dwellings.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special,transit oriented
summary: Jersey City has about a dozen planning districts (known as Redevelopment Plans) with no parking minimums, largely concentrated near PATH rapid transit and HBLR light rail stations. In fact, several of these districts have parking maximums. Examples include the Journal Square 2060, Colgate, Harsimus Cove Station, Grand Jersey, and Newark Ave Downtown plans.

The off street parking and loading requirements do not apply to any new buildings or structures or any existing building or structure which is enlarged or increased in capacity when those buildings or structures are located within the area bounded by Pine Street; Jefferson Street; Prairie Street; and Washington Street.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of motorcycle parking.
All uses except overnight accommodations in the C-3 Local Commercial District are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums citywide.
Parking Zone A (the inner city) is exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements are reduced in Parking Zone B which encompasses areas in proximity to transit.
The B-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Within the Central Business (CB) District, the parking requirements may be waived with the provision of a payment for common public parking areas in downtown.

Nonresidential uses are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Residential parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of frequent transit, motorcycle and scooter spaces, bike parking, or on-street parking.
The B-2 Primary Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Residential uses near transit have reduced parking requirements. Office, retail and service uses have parking maximums within the B-1 Neighborhood Business District.
Within the HOD-CC Historic Overlay District – Cambria City and the TND Traditional Neighborhood District, a change of use in an existing building is exempt from parking mandates.
All uses, except for residential uses of any kind, in the area indicated as the "Central Business District" on the Official Zoning Map are exempt from all off-street parking space requirements.
There are no minimum off-street parking requirements for uses located in the C-1 Downtown Core Commercial District.
The B-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Minimum parking requirements are waived in the B-3 downtown development district.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: No parking is required in the C-2 Central Business District. In all districts, reductions are allowed for on-street parking, bike parking, and nearby public parking. No non-residential use may provide more than 150% of the minimum required parking.
Single-family dwellings are exempt from parking mandates.
No off-street parking is required for any structure in the "CC" Commercial District except multiple-family residences and businesses over fifteen thousand (15,000) square feet of floor area.

No parking is required within the area bound by Gastineau Avenue, Fourth Street, Seward Street, Gastineau Channel, 490 South Franklin Street, and Layton Way. In the Town Center parking area, requirements are reduced and a fee in-lieu of parking may be provided instead.
The B-2 central business district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums, except for single-family dwellings.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Lots located in the Downtown Exempt Parking Area and zoned Neighborhood Node are exempt from parking requirements as well as commercial uses up to 2,000 square feet, and not located in the Community Commercial (CC) district. Parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking, and bike parking citywide and are reduced by right for lots in the Commercial Node District. Parking maximums apply to all uses.
Parking maximums are set at 15% above the minimums.

Property located within Parking District No. 3 is not required to provide any off-street parking. Parking requirements are reduced in Parking District No. 1, Parking District No. 2, and the B-3 (Core Area – Business) District. Parking requirements may be reduced for any use citywide by providing bike parking.
On May 26, 2022, Kalkaska adopted a new zoning code, which eliminated parking minimums citywide and implemented parking maximums.
The Central Business District (C-B) is exempt from parking mandates.

When the application of the off-street parking regulations results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single lot in a commercial district, such parking spaces need not be provided, although when two or more uses are located on a lot only one of the uses may be eligible for the exemption. This exemption does not apply to dwelling units.

Non-residential properties within the Downtown area zoned C-3 or properties zoned C-2 east of Washington, north of the Kankakee River, west of Indiana Avenue and south of Oak Street, as depicted in Figure 10-2, are not required to provide off-street parking. However, applications for new uses must provide the location of parking/loading spaces. Residential uses located within the Downtown are required to provide a minimum of 1 parking space per unit, irrespective of the number of bedrooms per unit.
There are no parking mandates in the downtown core and various levels of exemption for commercial and residential uses in several adjacent districts.

Parking space regulations were allowed to expire at the end of September 2023. While there are no specific requirements, a project may still be required to provide parking as part of the approval process and the state building code requires a "suitable" number of parking spaces.

The following portion of the central business district is exempt from parking requirements: the area bounded on the south by the railroad right-of-way, on the east by the center of First Avenue East, on the west by the center of Fifth Avenue West and on the north by the center of the alley between Main Street and First Street North.
Any use within the CBD, Kearney Center Mixed District is exempt from the off-street parking requirements.
On-street parking may count towards parking requirements.

Uses along Pine Avenue from Garnet Street to Emerald Street, and along South Main and J.C. Penney Drive are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Elsewhere, a fee in lieu of parking in the amount of Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) per space may be provided for up to thirty-five percent (35%) of the required spaces.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided citywide.

Nonresidential uses on the ground floor in the B Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements. The maximum number of parking spaces permitted on a lot in a residential district is the larger of three or the largest whole number (disregarding fractions) determined by dividing the total number of square feet of the lot by 3,500; provided, however, that single-family attached dwellings are permitted to have a maximum of two parking spaces per dwelling unit regardless of lot area.
Parking maximums apply to surface parking lots except in the S-I, L-I, H-I, and AH-I Districts.

When a new use commences in an existing building located in the area designated Harbourtown Centre in the Official Plan, no additional parking is required beyond that already supplied, provided that the building’s gross floor area is not increased.

Parking requirements within the B-3 Central Business District, B-4 Mixed-Use District and B-5 Downtown Mixed Use District are reduced for most uses. Within the Downtown Parking Requirement Boundary, as shown in Figure 3-2, parking requirements are waived for any uses on the first or second floors, with reduced requirements for third floor uses or above.
The C-D Commercial Downtown District is exempt from parking mandates, however, uses must still provide a parking plan.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Within the Downtown Commercial District, no off-street parking is required, except for multifamily residential development. Parking maximums apply to nonresidential development. Within the Downtown Commercial Enterprise District – West and Downtown Commercial Enterprise District – East, nonresidential parking requirements are reduced and parking maximums apply to most uses.
The B-2 Downtown Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
The C-1 Downtown Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates.
The C-3 central business district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

In the community core and tourist zone, residential units under 750 square feet are exempt from providing any parking. Community housing, restaurants and food service, the first 5,500 sf of retail use, the first 5,500 square feet of assembly use (theaters, conference centers etc.), are exempt from providing any parking in the community core and tourist zone.
Parking requirements are reduced for retail uses in the C-3 general commercial district.

The minimum parking spaces required for the Office Use Group are reduced by 15% within NC pattern districts and 30% within TC pattern districts. The minimum parking spaces required for the Commercial Use Group are reduced by 25% within NC pattern districts and 40% within TC pattern districts. Adjacent on-street parking may count towards minimum parking requirements for nonresidential uses in all districts.

When a building is erected in the Central Business District and the compliance with the regulations and requirements for off-street parking would result in impractical difficulties or undue hardship, the applicant for a permit to erect or enlarge a building may elect to pay a fee-in-lieu of required parking of $1,200 for each required parking space.
The B-3 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
There are no parking minimums for the general commercial (GC) district (Downtown Keyport). The GC district is approximately 76 acres and accounts for approximately 8% of the Borough.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Nonresidential uses are exempt from parking mandates and instead have parking maximums. A fee in lieu of parking may be provided for residential uses.
The area bounded by Avenue G, Park Street, Green Avenue and 12th Street is exempt from parking mandates.
Off-street parking is not required in the C-1 Central Business District.

Nonresidential uses with street frontages located in the following defined areas are exempted from minimum parking requirements:
(a)  Kimberly Avenue between Railroad Street and Wilson Street; and
(b)  Main Street north of Kimberly Avenue.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Parking maximums exist for all uses. Detached single-family dwellings or duplex developments on individual lots are exempt from parking requirements, however, they must maintain an area large enough to accommodate two off-street parking spaces. The minimum and maximum parking requirements do not apply to nonresidential uses in the Central Business District (CB), while parking requirements in the Walkable Center development type of the Mixed Use (MU) district are reduced by 50 percent.
The central business district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Kingston adopted a new form-based code on August 2, 2023 that included citywide elimination of off-street parking requirements, except in special districts. The new code also include parking maximums for most uses.

Citywide removal of minimums for all non-residential uses, citywide removal of minimums for affordable residential units, citywide removal of minimums for designated heritage properties. Citywide reduction in minimums for residential, with cash-in-lieu option to bring down to zero (funds used to support car-share). Citywide maximums for multi-unit residential. This went into effect in 2022.
The C-2 Community Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates.
The CP-2 Planned Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Retail stores and banks may count on-street parking within one block towards parking requirements.

Off-street parking is not required for uses permitted in the central business district. The CBD is the area defined as follows: south right-of-way line of Illinois Street, on the north; east of a line which extends parallel and 215 feet west of the centerline of Main Street, on the west; west right-of-way line of High Street, on the east; and north right-of-way line of Jefferson Street, on the south.

New buildings that are constructed with a depth of less than 24 feet and screen parking from the street are considered liner buildings. When constructed within the Downtown Master Plan Study Area, these buildings are not required to comply with the off-street parking, loading, or queuing lane requirements. Parking requirements may be reduced by up to 5% without needing an administrative waiver or variance approval for all uses, except single-family and two-family dwellings. Parking requirements are also reduced for most commercial and residential uses in the Downtown Master Plan Study Area.
Kissimmee, FL has made the Downtown district exempt from off-street parking requirements.
There are no mandates for most uses in the Urban Growth Center zones (large offices being one exemption).
Multi-family residential parking minimums vary based on distance to the city center. Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of an E-Carsharing space.

Developers are permitted to not provide parking for all land uses in the Downtown Business Zone if they pay into the parking district fund. The cost is $500 for each 1,000 square feet of gross floor area or $100 per space that would otherwise be required if expanding a use. The Downtown Business Zone is approximately 110 acres of land and are primarily commercial and public facilities.
Off-street parking is not required in the "C-4" Central Business District (CBD) for existing structures. Any new structures must comply with the parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The DK Downtown Knoxville District is exempt from required parking. Required parking may be reduced by 40% in the C-N Neighborhood Commercial District and by 20% in the C-G-2 General Commercial District and C-G-3 General Commercial District. Off-street parking requirements in any district may be reduced up to 30% from the minimum requirements, provided the development is located within one-fourth of a mile of a transit route. This reduction cannot be coupled with any other parking reduction. Parking maximums apply to all uses.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Parking requirements are reduced by 10-30% based on a zonal proximity to transit and the city center. Parking requirements may be reduced citywide through provision of extra bike parking, the implementation of a mobility concept, or a fee in lieu of parking. Within the pedestrianized zone, parking mandates may be waived for residential and retail uses. Parking maximums apply in the old town district.
Parking maximums apply to all uses except single-family and two-family dwellings. While the code uses the term suggested minimums, they are enforced as strict minimums.
Off-street parking is not required in the DC Downtown Commercial District.

Maximum parking applies to dwellings in the R-1 and R-2 districts. When the application of the off-street parking regulations results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single lot in any Commercial Zoning District, such parking spaces need not be provided. However, where two or more uses are located on a single lot, only one of these uses may be eligible for the exemption. This exemption does not apply to dwelling units.
No site plan may be approved for a multifamily residential or nonresidential use that contains more than 150% of the use's minimum number of required parking spaces, except by conditional use permit.
Retail, offices, banks, restaurants, theatres and home-based businesses in the C-1 - Business Commercial, and the C-C - Business Commercial Central districts are exempt from parking mandates.
No parking lot may exceed the minimum parking space requirements by ten percent (10%) greater than required except as approved by the Zoning Administrator.
Commercial uses in the C or CBD Districts have a reduced parking requirement.

On March 10, 2022 La Crosse eliminated parking mandates for non-residential uses in Local Business, Commercial, and Community Business zones. Previously La Crosse had no parking requirements in Industrial zones, as well as exemptions for the downtown and uptown areas. In early 2024, the city allowed ADUs without parking and a further reduction or full elimination of parking minimums is proposed.
No parking is required in the C-3 Central Business District.
Areas which are located in a fire district as designated on the official map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

The first 2,000 square feet in gross floor area for commercial uses in the C-1 Commercial Corridor Zoning District are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Commercial uses 2,000 square feet or less in gross floor area located within a shopping center configuration (i.e., a “strip mall”) are not eligible for this exemption. In addition, on-street parking spaces in the C-1 District may be counted toward required off-street parking spaces. New on-street parking spaces may be created to count toward required off-street parking.

No parking spaces or stacking spaces are required for uses in the C-1 Central Commercial District, or for uses in the C-2 Limited Service Commercial District that also are permitted as of right in the C-1 Central Commercial District, except as may be provided by the Board of Trustees as a condition to the issuance of a special use permit.
Parking maximums apply to all uses as a percentage of the minimums based on size.

Off-street parking is not required for any building constructed, converted, enlarged or re-opened in the "C-1" Commercial District. Medical and health facilities within the "C-2" Commercial District are also exempt from minimum parking requirements.
In the “C-1” Central Commercial District, there are no off-street parking requirements.

Within the CBD1 Downtown District, re-use of existing buildings that were in existence prior to the effective date of the ordinance are exempt from parking requirements. Any new non-residential buildings less than 5,000 square feet in gross floor area are not required to provide off-street parking. A fee-in-lieu of parking may be provided for larger non-residential buildings. Maximum parking applies to nonresidential uses.
There are no minimum parking requirements for commercial and industrial uses in the city center (Zone 1)

When the application of the off-street parking provisions results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single zoning lot in any Business or Industrial District, such parking spaces need not be provided where the building is unmanned. However, where two or more uses are located on a single lot, only one of those may be eligible for the exemption. In addition, all County and Township facilities are exempt from parking requirements.
The C-3 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

The number of off-street parking stalls required in the central business district area shall be 50% of the number otherwise required. The central business district is defined as bounded on the South by the North right-of-way line of the Wisconsin Central Division of the Canadian National Railroad; on the West by the East right-of-way line of West 5th St.; on the North by the South Right-of-way line of Pederson Avenue and Pederson Avenue extended; and, on the East by the West right-of-way line of East 3rd St.

Parking requirements are reduced for single-family and two-family dwellings in the OTR Old Town Residential District without alley access. A fee in lieu of parking may be provided for properties within the Old Town Urban Renewal Area.

Off-street parking is not required in a CB Central Business Zone, except for hotels, motels and newly constructed residential buildings, and except for places of public assembly as determined by the Administrative Officer (such as bingo parlors, motion picture theaters, etc.).
For nonresidential uses in NBU Neighborhood Business Zones, off-street parking spaces are limited to no more than 60% of the minimum requirements.
Buildings 5 stories or less in the D Downtown District are exempt from parking mandates. Citywide, parking requirements may be reduced for bike parking or transit availability.
Within the C-1 Central Business District, parking requirements may be reduced through public parking and bike parking.
Residential uses are exempt from minimum parking requirements. However, single-family dwellings are the only allowed residential use in the village.
Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums
Upon the adoption of a new zoning code on March 19, 2022, Lake City removed parking minimums and implemented maximums citywide.
The B-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements may be waived in the Village Mixed-Use District (VMX).
Parking requirements are reduced for most commercial uses in the B-2 Community Commercial Business District. A fee-in-lieu of required spaces may be paid in the O-1 Office and B-2 Districts.
Within the Central Business (CB) District, the minimum parking requirements are waived.

No off-street parking is required for any non-residential primary use on a lot in any mixed use district that is smaller than 5,000 square feet where no portion of the front lot line is located within 100 feet of a residential district. For parking lots required to have more than 25 vehicle parking spaces, bike parking may substitute for vehicle parking.
The B-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Uses within the C-1 Arterial Commercial District with a gross floor area of less than 10,000 square feet, and all uses within the C-2 Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking regulations.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Parking is not required for nonresidential uses in the B1 Downtown Business District. Mixed-use/upper-floor residential uses must provide evidence of the availability of off-street public or private parking within 1,000 feet of the unit however. Parking requirements for nonresidential uses may be reduced through the provision of bike parking. Parking lots in excess of 10% of the requirements are allowed only through conditional use permit.
The C1 Central Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

On-site parking is not required for non-dwelling uses or buildings located in the DC Downtown Center District, however, a fee in lieu of parking may be required. Parking maximums are set at 120% of minimums except for single-family dwellings.
No off-street parking or loading space is required for any use located in the "C-1" Business — Central District.
Off-street parking requirements do not apply within the C-1 Downtown Commercial District.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to nonresidential development or uses within the VC Village Commercial District.
The C1 Central Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

For mixed-use and nonresidential uses, any on-street parking located directly in front of the property may be counted towards on-site parking requirements. Furthermore, the number of required parking spaces may be reduced for uses providing bicycle parking at a ratio of up to one (1) off-street vehicle space reduction per two (2) bicycle spaces provided. The total number of required vehicle off-street parking spaces may not be reduced by more than five percent (5%) for any project.
Minimum parking regulations do not apply to businesses located in the Downtown area on Main Street, 3rd Street, 4th Street and 5th Street.
Most business and retail uses have reduced parking requirements when located in the B-2 Central Business District.

No use may provide more than ten (10) percent over the minimum parking requirement without incorporating certain design features. In no case may a use provide over twenty-five (25) percent more parking spaces than the requirement.
In the NC1, C1, C2, NO, and O Districts, the parking requirements for nonresidential uses may be reduced through on-street parking or public parking.
In Commercial, Office and Manufacturing Districts the number of parking spaces provided may not exceed the required number of spaces by more than fifty percent (50%).
Within the C-CBD Commercial-Central Business District, on-street parking stalls directly abutting a parcel may be counted in satisfaction of the number of spaces required.
Parking requirements may be reduced for mixed uses, and for providing sidewalks or other benefits.
All nonresidential uses below the third floor in the B-2 zoning district are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums apply to all uses and vary by district. Parking requirements may be reduced through motorcycle or scooter parking.
Existing buildings in existing business districts are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums exist for most uses.
The C-4 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Commercial buildings in the B-1 Local Business District and B-2 Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements as well as places of public assembly when located in a B-1 District. All Public schools and Graceland College are also exempt from parking requirements.
The C-2 Downtown Commerce district is exempt from parking requirements.

ADUs may be exempted from parking mandates when certain criteria are met. Since 2016, nonresidential uses within the C Commercial District determine their own parking needs, but must provide justification acceptable to the director of development services and/or the planning commission. Most uses are exempt from having to provide justification when located near transit.
Within the (CBD) Central Business District, bike parking may substitute for car parking. Parking maximums apply to all uses citywide.

Lancaster PA has no minimum requirements for parking in the Central Business District and the surrounding Central Business 1 District, about a 0.25 square miles (~6%) of the historic 4 square miles of the city.

Existing buildings constructed before the adoption of parking minimums are exempt from parking requirements when a change of use occurs, however, the parking requirements apply insofar as any parking that can reasonably be provided on the lot must be provided.

On-street parking may be counted toward the parking requirements for residential uses. Minimum required parking may be reduced where fully enclosed bicycle lockers are provided on a one-for-one exchange ratio, except for single family detached dwellings. Parking maximums exist for most uses.
In the Main Street (MS) District, existing buildings that were legally constructed as of January 1, 2016 without on-site parking are considered conforming. Such buildings are eligible for change of use permits, and for building up-fits. A fee-in-lieu of parking may be paid in order to reduce parking requirements.
Within the city center, a fee in lieu of required parking may be paid for most uses, but is not possible for new buildings.
Parking requirements are reduced by 25% for nonresidential uses in the Historic District.

Within the TOD Transit Oriented Design Overlay District, parking requirements are reduced by 10% and on-street parking may be counted towards the minimums. Within the Professional Office and Specialty Restaurant Conservation Overlay District, the first 400 feet of certain commercial uses are exempt from parking mandates. Within the Downtown Business Overlay District, there are no parking mandates for buildings under 20,000 square feet. Retail and restaurant uses within 500 feet of a public parking lot are exempt from parking mandates.
Adjacent on-street parking may count towards parking requirements.

The City of Lansing has a new zoning code passed and implemented that removes parking minimums from the downtown core and reduces the minimums in the downtown edge and commercial/transit corridors. There is also a city-wide provision that can be envoked to reduce the minimum of any development by up to 20%. The parking reductions follow the zoning districts rather than the land use.

On May 16, 2024, Lansing removed all parking minimums citywide and replaced them with recommended parking guidelines. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the recommended minimums, but may be exceeded through several mitigation strategies. Previously, there were limited exemptions in the downtown and reductions available for bike parking, on-street parking or public parking.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to property located within the CBD-1 Central Business District. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums citywide.
Parking maximums apply in all non-residential districts.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Commercial uses within the DC Downtown Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Multi-family residential development in the DC District is exempt if less than 10 spaces are required. All other residential development must provide parking at a reduced rate in the district. Maximum parking standards for commercial and industrial uses in all districts are set at 125% of the parking minimums.
Uses located within the Central Business District and the Arts and Entertainment District are exempt from parking mandates.
In all areas other than Urban Districts and Growth Management Areas, there are no parking mandates, but rather recommended parking standards.
No off-street parking or loading space is required for any use located in the C-3 Central Business District.

Adjacent on-street parking can be used for up to 25% of the minimum parking requirement.
Two trees planted may replace one parking stall for up to a 10% reduction of the minimum parking requirements. 
Four bicycle spaces may replace one parking stall for up to a 10% reduction of the minimum parking requirements. 
A ten percent reduction of the minimum parking requirements is granted if in a parking structure that is two stories or more.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Within downtown Las Vegas, the first 2000 square feet of a nonresidential use is exempt from parking mandates. Parking minimums are reduced and parking maximums apply in downtown.
On-street parking or public parking within 500 feet of a religious, hospital, educational, charitable, commercial, or professional building use may be counted towards the parking minimums.
The M-X-T Mixed-Use Transportation-Oriented District is exempt from parking mandates.
The C-4 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Parking requirements for retail establishments in the NC, CBD and HC commercial districts are reduced. A fee-in-lieu of required parking may be used for any use citywide.
The "C-1" General Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

The City of Laval eliminated minimum parking requirements for certain zones city wide. It also established parking maximums and it greatly reduced parking minimums across many zone types (for example, some commercial zones now only need 1 parking space per 75 square meters, sometimes even less in more central zones, while it used to be 1 space per 10 sq.m).
For commercial uses, excluding new and used vehicle sales, maximum parking limits are set at 20% above the minimum requirements.
Commercial development in downtown has no parking mandates.

The minimum number of required parking spaces may be reduced, if approved by the Director of Planning and Development, based on the provision of EV charging stations, or where peak attendance of a use will be at night or on Sundays.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Land uses within the CBD Central Business District are exempt from providing off-street parking.

The downtown area is exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements are reduced within the Fairmont Area. Parking reductions are available citywide for additional landscaping, bike parking and motorcycle parking.

In the C-2 Central Business District that encompasses primarily the Cody Road right-of-way from Byron Street to May Street, customer parking is not required, however, employee parking is still required.
Off-street parking and loading requirements are not required for any use in the “B-3” Central Business District, except residential dwellings, which must provide one parking space per dwelling unit.
Businesses that are a use by right in existing buildings in the TC zone and in portions of the RC zone are not required to provide off-street parking. ADUs are exempt from parking mandates citywide.
Off-street parking and loading requirements do not apply in the CBD (central business district) or on existing structures or uses at the time of passage of the regulations.
Parking requirements are reduced by 50% in the Central Business (CB) District.

Within the Central Business District, parking requirements are reduced by 75%. For the remaining required spaces, a fee-in-lieu of required parking may be paid into a public parking fund. Parking maximums apply in all districts, but may be exceeded with increased landscaping.

There are no parking mandates within the CBD Central Business District except for three of more dwelling units or a hotel. Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of motorcycle parking.

There are no parking requirements within the industrial land uses. The City of Leduc reduced minimum parking requirements for nonresidential uses in the downtown as part of the Land Use Bylaw. Two-thirds of the normal parking minimum is required. In two overlays of the downtown, parking minimums may be waived altogether for non-residential uses

Within the downtown area, the parking requirement calculation for each non-residential use is based on the minimum requirements, or five spaces per 1,000 square feet of gross floor area, whichever requires the fewer number of spaces. However, existing buildings need not provide parking for a change of use. The requirements for additional parking may be waived in the downtown area if sufficient available public parking is located on the same block or within 300 feet for residential or 500 feet for non-residential uses.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements are reduced for commercial uses which share parking.
Nonresidential uses in the C-2 Central Business District are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums citywide.
No parking is required for any use. Parking maximums apply to all uses.
Single-family dwellings and a change of use in an existing building are exempt from parking mandates. A fee in lieu of required parking may be paid in the central business district area.
There is no minimum parking requirement for land uses on lots one-half acre or less in the Downtown District. Parking maximums are set at 140% of the minimums.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking for nonresidential and mixed uses, or on-street or public parking availability in the mixed-use districts.
Within the Commercial "A" Central Business District, public parking may count towards parking minimums.
Minimum parking requirements are not applicable to property in the CB Central Business District, except for residential uses which are authorized by a conditional use permit.
The C-1 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Existing buildings in the C-1 Village Commercial District are exempt from parking mandates.
Within the C-B, C-O and C-M Zoning Districts, a fee in lieu of parking may be provided.
No off-street parking is required for uses located within the Town Center, Town Center (Historic), and Cultural/Historic Zoning Districts.
Permitted uses in the Central Business District (“CBD”) are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

On August 15, 2023, Lewisburg eliminated all parking requirements in the Downtown Commercial District and nonresidential requirements in all districts. Residential requirements were lowered to 1 space/dwelling unit and bike parking may now substitute for automobile parking.
Exemptions from off street parking are provided for in the B-1 Central Business District.

No off-street parking is required when uses of new buildings or structures or an enlargement or increase in the capacity of any existing principal building or structure is proposed within the following described area: properties within the area bounded on the east by the alley between Pine Street and Center Street, bounded on the south by a line approximately 120 feet south of the south line of Main Street and bounded on the west and north by an irregular line along Benson Street, Main Street, the alley between West Street and Vine Street and Walnut Street.

On August 25th, 2022 The Planning Commission for Lexington-Fayette County (merged Urban-County Government unanimously approved 8-0 a Zoning Ordinance Text Amendment to eliminate minimum parking requirements, establish bicycle parking standards, mitigate environmental impacts of parking lots with an increase in required tree canopy, lighting restrictions, and increased buffering/screening meant to discourage the over provision of parking without instituting parking maximums.

Final action by the Urban-County Council was taken on October 27th, 2022. The regulations were adopted by a 14-0 vote.

Buildings and uses located within the CBD - Central Business District are exempt from providing off-street parking. However, in no case may a building or use be expanded to remove off-street parking established before the effective date of the Zoning Ordinance.
The "C-3" Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Prior to June 19, 2023, Libby had no residential parking mandates.
No parking is required in the C-3 Central Business District, except as a condition of a special use permit.

There are no off-street parking requirements in the CBD Central Business District and MU Mixed-Use District. The maximum number of off-street parking spaces permitted may not exceed one hundred fifty (150) per cent of the required parking in any district.
The first 2,400 square feet of a restaurant, retail use, bank or wholesale business are exempt from parking mandates.
The CC Core Commercial Zone is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

The first one hundred (100) square feet of floor area within any new building and the first one hundred (100) square feet of any new floor area added to any separately owned portion of any existing building in the C-1 Downtown Core Commercial District is exempt from the requirements for parking spaces and stacking spaces, unless otherwise specifically required by the board of trustees as a condition to the issuance of a special use permit. A fee-in-lieu of required spaces may be paid in the district.
Parking spaces are not required for the reuse of existing structures in the central business district, labeled CB.
The first 2,000 square feet of a commercial use in exempt from parking mandates. On-street parking may be counted towards parking requirements for nonresidential uses.
Parking maximums exist for most uses.
Parking mandates only apply to multi-family dwellings, and to uses in industrial and the highway commercial districts.

When the application of off-street parking regulations results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single lot in any commercial district, such parking spaces need not be provided.  However, where two or more uses are located on a single lot, only one of these uses is eligible for the exemption.  This exemption does not apply to dwelling units.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: There are six districts in the city which are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
Off-street parking is not required in the B-1 Downtown Mixed Use District.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the downtown area bounded by Pekin, Hamilton, Clinton and Logan Streets.
The CBD District is exempt from minimum parking requirements. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums for multi-family and nonresidential uses throughout the village.
The C-2 General Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

The O-1 Office District and B-4 Lincoln Center Business District are exempt from parking mandates. Multiple districts have reduced parking requirements. There is a proposal to eliminate parking mandates from most commercial and industrial uses citywide.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the payment of a fee-in-lieu of providing required parking spaces.
Parking requirements are reduced in the city center, along bus routes, and for public housing projects. A fee in lieu of required parking may also be provided.
Buildings and uses located within the Central Business District (CBD) are exempt from providing off-street parking.

The number of off-street parking spaces provided for a building in the CBD Central Business District, which was constructed prior to the enactment of parking requirements, shall satisfy the requirement for a retail store, business or professional office, or similar use.

Minimum off-street parking requirements do not apply in the B-3A Central Retail Core District, except for all household living uses, medical offices, and any nonresidential uses which require a special use permit. However, nonresidential uses may count on-street parking spaces abutting the property towards satisfying off-street parking requirements.

Commercial and business structures in the Central Business District are exempt from parking requirements. The Central Business District consists of the area as follows: Bounded on the north by Fourth Street; on the east by a line one hundred fifty feet (150’) east of and parallel to Marshall Avenue; on the south by Depot Street; and the west by a line one hundred fifty feet (150’) west of and parallel to Ramsey Avenue.
Within the Downtown Overlay District, parking requirements are reduced by 70 to 90 percent. Citywide, on-street parking may count towards parking requirements.
All uses located within the "1980 Parking Lot District" inside the Central Business District B-1 Zoning District are exempt from off-street parking requirements.
Parking minimums have been repealed in the UU (urban use district), or the Central Business District/Downtown LR. It is implemented and applies to all uses.
Parking requirements are reduced for commercial uses and places of worship in the Town Center Mixed-Use (TCMU) and the Town Center Residential (TCR) Districts.

Parking requirements may be reduced for uses near transit. Within the downtown districts, parking requirements are reduced by right and may be further reduced for EV charging stations, proximity to transit, transit pass provision, ridesharing, on-street parking, bike parking, shuttle service to transit, or tuck-under parking. Parking maximums apply to all uses except single-family dwellings.

In the Central Business District Zone commercial uses are required to have only fifty (50) percent of the parking space requirements in the Table of Minimum Standards. Apartment units in the Central Business District must meet the minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
The CBD Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.

No accessory off-street parking spaces are required for retail and service uses, industrial and office uses, community service uses, and places of assembly, when located in existing structures in the C-4 Downtown Commercial District. In addition, residential parking requirements are reduced to 1.25 parking spaces per unit.

In the Town Center District, existing buildings which were constructed without the provision of on-site parking and infill housing on existing lots of record may meet requirements with on-street parking and will be considered conforming. Such buildings are eligible for change of use permits to building unfits and expansion. In all districts, residential buildings may meet parking requirements with on-street parking if individual driveways are minimized and the fronting street is specifically designed to meet the parking needs of the residential buildings. Civic uses are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No accessory off-street parking is required in the C-2 Central Business District, except for dwelling units located above the ground floor of permitted uses.
The B-1 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Properties within the B-2 Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Maximum parking limits in the district are set at 50% of the normal minimums. Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of motorcycle parking.
Off-street parking and loading requirements are waived in the CBD district.
The B-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements for nonresidential uses in the B5 Central Business District are reduced by 50 percent.
Buildings in existence prior to the effective date of the parking ordinance are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Beginning in 2004 and in the following couple years, every borough of London eliminated parking minimums and implemented parking maximums.

No parking minimums in: Downtown district, Transit Village, Rapid Transit Corridors, and around the Main Street area.

Reduced parking minimums in all other parts of the city.

Increased minimum bicycle parking requirements across the city.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.

ADUs are exempt from parking mandates under certain conditions. Long Beach has reduced parking minimums for transit-oriented off street parking for residential and hospital use reducing parking from 25% to 50%. Long Beach has proposed eliminating mandates for businesses when there is a change of use.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
There are no off street parking requirements in the Old Town Zone, except for hotels and motels.

Within the B1 Historic Business District, parking requirements are reduced to 5 parking spaces for every 1,000 square feet of net floor area of any new building or of net floor area added to any existing building. Parking may be further reduced through a fee-in-lieu for required spaces. Restaurants in the district may further reduce parking requirements by instituting and maintaining a continuous, personalized shuttle or valet parking service or contracting with a local agency to provide those services.
Parking maximums apply to all uses except single-family or two-family dwellings.

Parking minimums were removed in May 2024. Previously, parking minimums only applied to residential and educational uses. Commercial and industrial land uses have had no minimum parking requirements since 2014, with a set of maximum requirements instead. Multi-family residential in Mixed Use Downtown (MU-D) and Mixed Use Corridor (MU-C) zoning districts were exempted in 2022, and now have parking maximums.
No minimum parking is required in CB, Central Business District.
In lieu of providing required parking, a property owner may purchase parking credits from a fund established by the City to provide municipal parking.
Off-street parking is not required in the C-1 Central Business District.

The minimum parking space requirements may not be exceeded by more than ten percent (10%), unless approved by the City Council, as part of concept plan review, or the Planning Commission, as part of final plan review, or if the parking spaces are located within a multi-level parking structure.
The Cornfield Arroyo Specific Plan, passed in 2012, has no minimum parking requirements for projects in the area.

Within the TOD-MU Zone, parking requirements are reduced by right for residential uses, and on-street parking may count towards the requirements for all uses. Parking maximums apply to nonresidential uses in the zone.
The downtown area is exempt from parking mandates.
No off-street parking or loading space is required for any use in the "C-2" Central Business District.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Parking requirements are reduced in Downtown Louisville by right, while on-street parking and in lieu fees may further reduce requirements. The first 999 square feet of a building are exempt and parking maximums apply to one bedroom units in the district.

There are no minimum or maximum parking requirements for all uses in the Central Business District. There are maximum parking requirements for certain uses. There are opportunities to reduce the minimum parking required outside of the CBD if specific criteria are met.
There are no off-street parking requirements in the B-3 General Business District.
Parking maximums are set at 150% of the minimums, but may be exceeded through increased landscaping.

Nonresidential and mixed-use development that is located within the boundaries of General Improvement District #1 is exempt from parking requirements. Parking reductions are available for on-street parking, affordable housing, age-restricted housing, and other factors.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to existing commercial buildings within the C Commercial District.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.

Lowell removed set parking minimums for all uses except multi-family development on April 19, 2022. However, the parking requirements for all developments are still determined during the planning approval process.
Off-street parking is not required in the TC Town Center District.

The city council passed an ordinance eliminating parking minimums for up to 10 units of housing in the downtown mixed use zone (DMU). Lowell already didn't require parking minimums for non-residential uses in the DMU.

In the C-2 District and the MU District, on-street or off-street public parking may be counted toward the minimum parking requirement. Parking requirements may be reduced citywide through the provision of bike parking.

On-street parking may be counted toward the parking requirements for residential uses. Minimum required parking may be reduced where fully enclosed bicycle lockers are provided on a one-for-one exchange ratio, except for single family detached dwellings. Parking maximums exist for most uses.
In the Main Street (MS) District, existing buildings that were legally constructed as of January 1, 2016 without on-site parking are considered conforming. Such buildings are eligible for change of use permits, and for building up-fits. A fee-in-lieu of parking may be paid in order to reduce parking requirements.
Nearby community parking spaces or garages may be counted towards required parking spaces.
Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums.
Parking and loading space requirements do not apply in a Base Mixed-Use District.
Parking maximums apply to all uses based on applicant-submitted parking data from appropriate standards.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
A change of use within the C-1 Old Town Business District is exempt from parking requirements.
No off-street parking spaces are required for the rehabilitation or reuse of existing structures within the NC Neighborhood Commercial zone.
The DM Downtown Mixed District is exempt from parking mandates.
In September, 2021, the Town of Lunenburg’s new Municipal Planning Strategy, Land Use Bylaw and Subdivision Bylaw went into effect. The new documents remove all minimum parking requirements.
Nonresidential uses in the CBD Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No minimum parking requirements in the B-4 District which includes the entire Central Business District, the historic 5th Street Corridor and select high density nodes
No off-street parking or loading space is required for any use located in the "C-1" Business - Central District.

For any use categorized as a "commercial" or "industrial" use, off-street vehicle parking spaces may not be provided in an amount that is more than one hundred twenty five percent (125%) of the minimum requirements. If application of the maximum parking standard would result in less than six parking spaces, the development may be allowed six parking spaces.
On-street parking may count towards minimums in the CD Commercial Downtown district. Commercial uses on Main Street between Third Avenue and Fifth Avenue are exempt from parking mandates.
Cars have been banned in Mackinac Island (the city) since 1898 and on the full island since 1901, hence there are no parking mandates.

All structures in the B-4 district, except those structures or portions thereof which are used for private residence, are exempt from off-street parking requirements. Public parking may be counted towards parking requirements in the B-3 District except for residential or hotel uses.

Parking requirements are reduced within the TND Traditional Neighborhood Development districts with an additional reduction available in the CD Core Downtown Zone where on-street parking is available for multifamily dwellings. Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums in the TND districts.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to any use in the downtown, including the area bounded by Campbell, Calhoun, McArthur, and Jefferson Streets.
Single-family dwellings may not exceed four parking spaces per dwelling unit.
Nonresidential uses in the CBD-1 Central Business District have reduced parking requirements.
A fee in lieu of parking may be provided in the TC Town Center District.
Properties and uses in the B-1 Downtown District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Properties within the Historic Preservation District Overlay are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Parking maximums apply to all uses citywide.
The Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: There is no parking required in the Central District of Madison and in several other mixed-use and TOD districts. Some other districts waive parking requirements for new developments smaller than 10,000 square feet.
Madras no longer has parking minimums in the Downtown Core Zoning District. They also have parking maximums of no more than 20% above minimum parking requirements.
The C-1 Central Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

The minimum number of required off-street parking spaces associated with a pedestrian oriented development may be reduced by the number of on-street parking spaces abutting the parcel.  An applicant may reduce the number of required parking spaces up to a maximum of five percent (5%) for the installation of interior landscaping in excess of the required interior landscaping for parking lots. Up to an additional five percent (5%) is permitted where an area which would otherwise be devoted to parking cannot be used in order to preserve an existing tree or trees with a diameter of six (6) caliper inches or more.
Parking maximums exist for most nonresidential uses.
Maine eliminated parking requirements for Accessory Dwelling Units and also limits parking minimums for affordable housing developments in growth centers to no more than 2 space for every 3 units
The CBD District is exempt from minimum parking and loading requirements.
Parking requirements within the Central Business District are half of the requirements in other commercial districts.
The C-2 Downtown Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Commercial, institutional, or industrial uses may provide a fee in lieu of required parking. Parking requirements are reduced for shared parking.

Parking requirements in the Intensive Business District are waived due to existing public parking provided and the nature of the Intensive Business District. This condition applies to all commercial establishments located north of Third Street, west of Factory Street, east of the railroad siding and south of the Little Wolf River.
There are no parking requirements in the Village of Mancelona. The Village also has parking maximums in place.
Any use within the CBD Downtown Manchester District is exempt from the off-street parking requirements.
Buildings and uses located within the CBD Central Business District are exempt from providing off-street parking.
Off-street parking is not required within the AMX, B-1 and CDBG Districts. However, a parking plan is required to be developed for each property and shall be submitted to the Planning Board.
New development within the DMU district and within the Downtown Center is not required to provide off-street parking or loading.
A portion of the CB Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates, however properties may be assessed for municipal parking.
Within the B-3 Old Mandeville Business District, on-street parking may count towards parking minimums and a fee in lieu of required parking may be provided.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special
