Nonresidential uses, except for schools, do not have specified parking minimums. Instead, they must provide a parking demand needs assessment (PDNA) to be approved by the township.
No off-street parking spaces are required for nonresidential uses within the CBD Central Business District.

Permitted and special uses in the P-D District are exempt from minimum parking requirements except hotels, marinas, and places of public assembly. Permitted and special uses in the C-3 District are exempt from minimum parking requirements except hotels and motels. Parking maximums are set at 150% of the minimums except for single-family, two-family and mobile homes.
Nonresidential uses in the B-1 Restricted Business District have reduced requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums for surface parking.
In the Central Business District, accessory off-street parking spaces are not required, except for buildings containing dwelling units or lodging rooms.

Uses and buildings located in the CBD-C, Central Business District-Core, are exempt from the minimum parking requirements. However, the City Council may require off-street parking to be provided for conditional uses in the CBD-C.
The C-1 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No off-street parking is required in the C-2 Central Business Commercial District.
The central business core of the C-2 Highway Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Within the Central Business District, nonresidential new construction has reduced parking requirements and a nonresidential change of use in an existing building is exempt from parking mandates.
The FB-1 Route 50 corridor district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Uses located in the central business district (CBD) are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

In commercial districts, all business uses in structures erected prior to 1940 are exempt from parking mandates unless they are enlarged more than 50% of the current floor area. On-street parking may count towards minimums for all uses in the village.
Properties in the B-1 Central Business District on Main Street between County Line Road and Liberty Street are exempt from parking mandates.
The C-2 Central Business Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Within the M-U Mixed Use District, on-street parking may count towards parking requirements for commercial or mixed use developments. Retail uses may reduce requirements if a transit shelter is provided. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums for surface parking.
Off-street parking requirements do not apply to existing commercial buildings in the B-2 Central Business District.
Parking maximums exist for most uses.
Parking maximums are set at 200% of the minimums, except for single-family and two-family dwellings.
Commercial uses are exempt from parking minimums. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums except for single-family and two-family dwellings.
The Central Retail District is exempt from parking mandates.
The Central Business District, and all residential districts (R1-R3) are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements may be reduced for nonresidential uses through the provision of bike parking, or for adaptive reuse projects in the Trail/Rail/River and Market Zoning Districts.
Within the Nautical Mile District, uses in the Special Parking Area A are exempt from parking mandates and uses in the Special Parking Area B have requirements reduced by 50%.
The C-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the Central Core District.
The C-3 Central Core District is exempt from parking mandates.
The B-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-1 General Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Commercial buildings within 300 feet of a municipal parking lot or with adjacent on-street parking may reduce the amount of required off-street parking by subtracting from their total required off-street parking, one (1) parking space for each seven hundred fifty (750) gross square feet of floor area. All other commercial buildings may reduce the amount of required off-street parking by subtracting from their total required off-street parking, one (1) parking space for each fifteen hundred (1,500) square feet of gross floor area.
Off-street parking is not required for uses in the DT Downtown Overlay District.
The C-2 General Office and Retail District is exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for dwelling units, hotels, motels and bed and breakfast establishments.
Parking space requirements for principal uses in the CBD apply only to residential uses, and all other principal uses in the CBD are exempt from parking space requirements.
Accessory apartments in the B2 General Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
All uses located within the limits of the downtown district are exempt from the required number of parking spaces requirements.
Off-street parking is not required in the C-1 Central Business District.
Areas which are located in a fire district as designated on the official map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Parking minimums and maximums exist for most uses. However, the Urban Core (UC) district is exempt from parking minimums. Day cares, bus and train terminals, golf courses, parks and various other uses are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

On-street parking may be counted toward the parking requirements for residential uses. Minimum required parking may be reduced where fully enclosed bicycle lockers are provided on a one-for-one exchange ratio, except for single family detached dwellings. Parking maximums exist for most uses.
In the Main Street (MS) District, existing buildings that were legally constructed without on-site parking are considered conforming. Such buildings are eligible for change of use permits, and for building up-fits. A fee-in-lieu of parking may be paid in order to reduce parking requirements.
In the Historic Uptown Commercial core district, minimum parking requirements have been eliminated for nonresidential land uses.
Bicycle parking may substitute for up to 10 percent of required parking. For every five bicycle parking spaces, the motor vehicle parking requirement is reduced by one space.
No off-street parking is required in the portion of the C-2 General Business District bounded by Fifth, Vine, Second and Buchanan Streets.
The "DC" downtown commercial district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Retail and office developments have maximum parking entitlements and no minimum parking requirements.
Uses that would otherwise require 20 parking spaces or less are exempt from parking requirements when located in the C-1 Central Business District.
The B-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements are reduced for uses in the special off-street parking lot taxing district established by Resolution No. 8-1964.
Nonresidential uses in the General Commercial District are exempt from parking mandates.
Parking maximums apply to single family dwellings.

For all nonresidential uses in the HUC downtown core district fronting Trade Street, John Street, or Matthews Station Street where the building is located at the front property line, or less than the maximum build-to line, no off-street parking is required. For retail, financial institution, office, and restaurant uses in the HUC district and not meeting the above requirements, the parking requirements are reduced. In all districts, parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of motorcycle parking and dedicated carpool parking.

Minimum parking regulations do not apply to lots located in a block within the C3 Service Commercial District which, at the time of passage of this zoning chapter, was occupied by structures used for commercial purposes totaling 50% or more of the area of the block.

Maumee replaced all parking minimums with parking maximums in October 2020. Previously, properties within the C-3 Uptown Commercial District were exempt from parking minimums unless the Zoning Administrator determined otherwise.
Within the central business (CB) district, the parking requirements may be waived or modified by the plan commission, which may impose a fee-in-lieu of parking spaces.

Within the Central Business Commercial District (B-3) no parking is required for a change of use in an existing building, except for a change of use from a single-family/multifamily residential dwelling to non-residential use. When parking is required in the Main Street area parking district, a fee-in-lieu of parking may be paid to the city.
The D-1 Downtown Business District, A-1 Transition District, and A-2 Agricultural District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
The B-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

In the C-1 Local Commercial Zoning District, all commercial uses are exempt from minimum parking requirements. In the C-2 Pedestrian-Oriented Commercial District, the first two-thousand (2,000) square feet in gross floor area for nonresidential uses are exempt from minimum parking requirements. This does not apply to a multi-tenant structure. In addition, on-street parking spaces in the C-2 District may be counted toward required off-street parking spaces. New on-street parking spaces may be created to count toward required off-street parking. A reduction in the required number of off-street parking spaces for non-residential uses in the C-2 District may be granted by the Village Board through the payment of a fee-in-lieu of providing the required parking spaces. Changes in use within existing buildings shall not require payment of a fee-in-lieu.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums apply to single-family and two-family dwellings.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
Off-street parking and loading requirements are not applicable to any use located in the CBD Central Business District, or the TND center portion of a TND Traditional Neighborhood Development, except for multi-family uses, hotels, churches and motels located in such areas.
On-street parking may be used to satisfy some of the off-street parking that otherwise is required for a particular use. Parking maximums are set at 150% of the minimums and may be exceeded with the granting of a special exception by the Board of Adjustment.
Within the central business district, commercial uses may pay the city a fee in lieu of meeting the minimum parking requirements.
Uses within the Downtown Parking Overlay District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Minimum parking requirements have been eliminated in current and former urban renewal areas. The majority of the area is the Central Business District

A reduction of required parking spaces for commercial uses may be allowed by the Planning and Development Department when the reduction would result in the preservation of a significant tree with a trunk of twelve (12) inches in diameter or greater.

The Central Business District (CB) is exempt from minimum off-street parking and loading requirements.

No off street parking or loading is required for individual uses located entirely within the C-4 Downtown Commercial District.

Within the Historic Core and Downtown Core Character Districts, nonresidential uses are exempt from parking requirements and residential uses have reduced requirements. All commercial uses are exempt from parking mandates. Nonresidential uses in the DPH and MU-3 districts are exempt from parking mandates except for uses where the number of employees, visitors, and patrons totaled together is expected to routinely exceed 30 at one time.

The “C-2” Central Business Commercial District and “C-1” General Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Minimum off-street parking space requirement shall not be exceeded by more than twenty percent (20%) unless good cause can be shown by the applicant and approved by the Planning Commission.  Single Family Dwellings and Two Family Dwellings are exempt from this provision.

Shared or joint use of up to fifty percent (50%) of required parking spaces may be permitted for two (2)  or more uses if justified to the Planning Director
ADUs in the CB-OZ and the Eau Gallie art overlay zone are exempt from parking requirements. Within these zones, a fee-in-lieu of parking may be paid.

No minimum off-street parking spaces are required in the CBD District or the SCBID District. Reduced parking ratios apply in the Uptown District and the Medical Overlay District. Within the University District Overlay, nonresidential uses are exempt from parking requirements, while residential uses have reduced requirements.
Parking requirements may be reduced for a variety of uses when located near transit, on-street parking, or public parking. Other reductions are available for bike parking, tree preservation, and pedestrian accessibility.
The C-B Central Business District is exempt from all off-street parking and loading requirements.
Nonresidential uses within the B-1  Downtown Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No off-street parking is required in the C-2 Central Business District, except where multi-family development is the principal use.

No off-street parking is required in the BC Business Commercial District.

In the designated downtown historic district, retail, commercial or similar businesses are exempt to the extent that they are not required to provide the first 20 parking spaces as otherwise required. Residential units may be exempt provided that land adjacent or contiguous to the building and owned by the building owner may be used for residential parking for that building and that any excess residential parking may occur in municipal parking lots within the downtown historic district.
The B-1 General Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking.

Within the C-1 Commercial Town Center District, a change of use in an existing building is exempt from parking mandates. Residential parking requirements in the district are reduced when part of a mixed-use development.

The downtown core area of the Central Business District (bounded on the north by 10th Street, on the east by 18th Avenue, on the south by the railroad and on the west by 26th Avenue) is exempt from off-street parking requirements.

Areas which are located in a fire district as designated on the official map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Parking in lieu program that allow developers in the city center parking zone to pay fees to the city to enable them to build without parking spaces for other uses.

In the Main Street (MS) and Old Midland (OM) Districts, existing buildings that were constructed without on-site parking, and infill housing on existing lots may meet requirements with on-street parking, if available, and will be considered conforming. scope: city center / business district,main street / special

Montgomery County has several parking districts in which parking mandates are waived if a tax to support district parking is paid. scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: No parking minimum requirements in the Historic Core, part of the Historic Urban Neighborhood (HU-B1A) and Central Business District. Also exempt, in Historic Urban Neighborhood Districts: 1) all single-family and two-family dwellings on lots 30 feet or less. 2) a single-family or two-family dwelling on a blockface where 40% of those existing dwellings have no off-street parking. Also exempt: the first 3,000 square feet in gross floor area for commercial uses in the HMC-2 district, and the first 5,000 square feet in gross floor area for commercial uses in HU-B1, HU-MU and MU-1 Districts, except for shopping center configurations. Nonresidential uses in the C-Commercial District are exempt from parking mandates.

NYC consists of 5 boroughs with over 8 million people. NYC has no parking minimums in most of Manhattan, and reduced requirements (with no requirement for certain types of housing) in several other dense neighborhoods around the city. 

In the Manhattan Core (Community Districts 1-8), no off-street parking is required. The maximum amount of off-street parking allowable is determined by the proposed use and Community District. 

On September 21, 2023, Mayor Adams proposed removing minimum parking requirements for housing citywide. In order for the change to take effect, it will have to pass the Uniform Land Use Review Procedure and would not become law until at least fall 2024.

The National Policy Statement - Urban Development (NPS UD) required councils to remove provisions for a minimum number of on-site car parks from district plans through a non-notified process, to allow more intensive urban development with less space taken up by car parks, leading to better utilisation of urban land.

Affordable dwelling units  built using Tax Increment Financing and/or Low Income Housing Tax Credits are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Parking requirements for all uses in the BB Central Business District are reduced.
No parking is required for residential and non-residential land uses within a 1,200-foot radius of a light rail, PATH train or NJ Transit train station.
The DC Downtown District is exempt from parking mandates.
Nonresidential uses in the B-1 Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking is not required within Mixed-Use districts.

The total number of parking spaces provided for one-family, two-family or multiple- family dwellings or hotels may not exceed the requirements by more than fifty percent (50%) or four (4) spaces, whichever number is greater.
Newport News repealed all parking mandates on October 22, 2024. Previously, no minimum parking was required for residential uses in the C3 Regional Business District.
Parking requirements are reduced in the GI General Industry District and GB General Business District.

In the MX-1 District, on-street parking spaces that are adjacent to the parcel that the parking is being calculated for may be included in the calculation. The maximum number of off-street parking spaces permitted may not exceed one space per 250 square feet for office or retail uses, except in the case of restaurants which may be allowed one space per 200 square feet if shared parking facilities are not available.
Parking maximums apply to some uses.
Within the C-1 Central Business District there are no parking minimums except as needed to meet other requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: There is no minimum parking requirement for non-residential uses. However, the applicant must provide a statement or parking analysis indicating how they will provide adequate parking for the proposed non-residential use to succeed without negatively impacting adjacent properties or creating or compounding a dangerous traffic condition. Residential uses require parking, except in the C-3 Central Business District. Reductions for residential parking are available through motorcycle, scooter and bike parking. On-street parking may be counted towards the parking minimums. Parking maximums exist for all non-residential uses.
On-street parking may count towards parking requirements.
There are no parking requirements for retail uses in the South Plaza Commercial Parking District.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

The downtown area bounded by Cedar Street on the South, the St. Joseph River on the West, Sycamore Street on the North and Fifth Street on the East and the area West of Front Street, East of the St. Joseph River and South of Cass Street, are exempt from off-street parking and loading requirements. Within the City Center Overlay District covering a wider swath of downtown, parking requirements are reduced for retail and restaurant uses.
The B-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for special uses and residential uses.
Uses in the Core Central Business District (CCBD) are exempt from parking ratio requirements.

Minimum parking requirements may not be exceeded by more than 125% of the minimums, unless approved by the Community Development Director. Parking requirements may be reduced with the approval of the Community Development Director based on the proximity to public parking, bus stops, or a carsharing or vanpool program.
No off-street parking or loading space is required for any use of land located in the C-2 Central Business District and R-T Tiny House District.

Norfolk eliminated minimum off-street parking requirements for all non-residential uses and residential development of 24 multi-family dwelling units or less for properties within the Norfolk and Western Historic Overlay district.

Permitted business and office uses in the B-2 Central Business District are exempt from off-street parking requirements. This exemption does not apply to residential dwelling uses. Parking maximums apply to single-family and two-family dwellings.

In early November 2021, Norman replaced "Spaces Required" with "Spaces Recommended" in zoning code for all land uses except for single family homes, duplexes, fraternity houses, and mobile home parks.
The TC Town Center and TCII Town Center II districts are exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements may be reduced for mixed-use developments and for uses located near transit.
Parking requirements are reduced for mixed-use developments.
Parking requirements may be reduced for uses requiring 20 or more spaces when EV chargers are provided.
Within the CBD District, parking is not required. Parking requirements may be reduced through bike parking citywide.
On August 21, 2023, the city replaced parking requirements with recommended parking for nonresidential uses citywide. There are no parking mandates for residential uses in the Main Street Districts.

The number of parking spaces required for all uses, except residential, may be reduced by fifty percent (50%) for properties adjacent to Sheridan Road, 10th Street or Martin Luther King Jr. Drive within the URO Urban Redevelopment Overlay District. Parking requirements for apartments with two or three bedrooms are reduced within the URO District to one space per unit plus guest parking.

Parking requirements are reduced by right for restaurants and retail uses in the GC and VC Districts and for multi-family dwellings in the GC District. A change of use in both districts is exempt from parking mandates and all uses there may provide a fee in lieu of required parking. Public libraries, museums, art galleries and community centers may have reduced requirements when transit or pedestrian access is available.
The "Downtown Business District"  is exempt from the minimum parking requirements. This area is designated as the Downtown Parking Overlay District as depicted on the North East Borough Zoning Map.
Within the B-1 Business District, off-street parking is not required.
The General Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
The total number of parking spaces for residential uses in residential districts may not exceed the minimums by more than 50% or four spaces, whichever is greater.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: No on-site parking is required in the C-2 Downtown Business zoning district, except for any residential uses. Other districts may reduce required parking through bike parking and public or on-street parking. In addition, no non-residential use may provide more than one hundred fifty (150) percent of the minimum required parking without documented evidence of actual parking demand based on studies of similar uses in similar contexts. Any parking permitted over one hundred fifteen (115) percent of the minimum shall require mitigating potential impacts of more parking through various strategies.
Business uses may count on-street parking towards the parking requirements.

Parking requirements for residential development within the R-A Redevelopment Area District are reduced by right, with additional reductions possible for all uses in the district through on-street parking.
A change of use in a building existing prior to the code adoption is exempt from parking mandates.
The C-5 (downtown) district is exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for churches.
Off-street parking areas are not required for individual lots in the Central Business District if on-street or public parking is available.
Commercial properties having frontage on the 200 block of Belgrade Avenue are exempt from off-street parking and loading requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.

The minimum parking space requirements may not be exceeded by more than 20%, unless approved by the reviewing authority as part of development plan review or if the parking spaces are located within a multi-level parking structure.
Single-family and two-family dwellings are exempt from parking mandates.
No off-street parking spaces are required in the B-3 Downtown Commercial District.
The B-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums apply to single-family and two-family dwellings.

The minimum amount of required parking for all non-single-family residential uses may be reduced by up to 10% for the provision of bicycle parking. A reduction of one vehicle parking space is allowed for every six additional bicycle parking spaces installed beyond the required amount.
Off street parking in the C-1 central business district is not required.

Parking requirements may be reduced for nonresidential uses through on-street parking or the use of an existing building. Nonresidential uses in an existing building fronting Main or Walnut streets in the CBD are exempt from parking mandates.
Parking requirements may be reduced for a captive market, public transit availability, complimentary uses, EV chargers, or bike parking.
On-street parking space in non-residential zoning districts may be counted toward off-street parking space requirements. In addition, Northfield maintains parking maximums.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Properties smaller than 5000 square feet are exempt from parking mandates except for single-family, two-family and manufactured homes. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums except for residential uses. Upon approval, parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking, proximity to transit or EV charging stations.
Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums.
Within the Central Business District, parking requirements are reduced by right, and may be further reduced for a change of use or through a fee in lieu of required parking.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Norwalk passed a new zoning code on December 13, 2023 (Effective February 19, 2024) which eliminated parking requirements in the Urban Zones CD-4 and CD-4W, reduced parking requirements near transit and for townhomes, and added parking maximums citywide.
The B-2 Downtown Business District is exempt from parking mandates.

Subject to the approval of the zoning board of appeals, all or part of the required off-street parking in all districts may be waived subject to the applicant's election to contribute a predevelopment fee to the city in lieu of the number of spaces waived. The zoning board of appeals may allow for the contribution to the fund only if the applicant can demonstrate that (1) off-site parking will be impossible or constitute an undue hardship, or (2) a contribution to the fund under the particular circumstances of the application will be more beneficial to the city.
Chelsea Central District does not have parking minimums and all retail/shopping centers have parking maximums.

In the Central Business District parking mandates are 50% of elsewhere and if a project would require less than 20 parking spaces, the requirement is waived. In General Business, and Limited Business districts, projects which would require less than 5 spaces are considered waived. On-street parking counts toward requirements.
There are no parking requirements, citywide for retail and office uses or single family homes. Parking requirements for other uses are relatively low.
Within the TC Town Center District, on-street parking may count towards parking minimums.
Uses in Zone 1 (city center) require 80% of the otherwise required parking spaces. A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided citywide.

Within the Downtown District, non-residential uses in existing buildings are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Nor is any parking required for existing or re-developed second story dwelling units located within existing buildings in the Downtown District. For construction of a new building with more than two dwelling units, parking must be provided.

Off-street parking requirements are not applicable to any existing commercial use in the C-1 Central Business District, provided that any such existing use is not expanded through addition of floor space. When a new building replaces an existing building, the off-street parking requirement is only for any floor area developed which is in excess of the floor area of the existing building which is removed.
Commercial uses in Performance District 1 are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No parking lot may exceed the required number of parking spaces by more than 20%, except as approved by Community Development Director.

The total number of accessory parking spaces provided for a single-family, two-family or multiple-family dwelling may not exceed the requirements for such use or for an equivalent new use by more than fifty percent (50%) or four (4) spaces, whichever number is greater.

Non-residential uses of 2,500 square feet or less are exempt from parking requirements. In commercial districts, on-street parking spaces may be counted toward required off-street parking spaces for commercial uses. In the DT-1 Downtown Central Sub-District, parking requirements are reduced. 

In all districts, all uses located within one-half mile of a transit station (trains only) have reduced parking requirements. Furthermore, the Zoning Administrator may authorize greater reductions through the provision of a transportation management plan, the use of off-peak work schedules, or the provision of cash or in-kind financial incentives for employees commuting by carpool, car sharing, vanpool, and transit. At the discretion of the Village, a one-time fee may be paid in lieu of providing a portion of the required off-street parking.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
Commercial uses must limit the total number of off-street parking spaces provided to not more than 150 percent of the minimum parking spaces required.
The B-1 Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Oakland has no required parking in CBD, S-2, and D-LM zones.  There are parking maximums in those zones.
No off-street parking is required for any use located in the Central Business District.
Off-street parking and loading requirements do not apply to any use located in the Central Business Area (CBA).
Mixed-use developments have reduced parking requirements.
Oakville, Ontario has no minimum parkings in the downtown and reduced minimums in some reduction in parking in mixed-used zones.
Public parking within 300 feet of a use may be counted towards parking requirements.
No off street parking is required for uses in the CB Central Business District.

No off-street parking or loading is required for individual uses located entirely within the C-1 Commercial District and that are also located entirely within the area bounded by Lorain, Pleasant, Vine and Professor Streets.
Parking requirements are reduced for mixed-use developments.
The CMX-2 commercial district is allowed to provide half of the minimum number of required spaces required in other districts.
ADUs may be exempted from parking mandates when certain criteria are met. A fee in-lieu of required parking may be paid in the D Downtown District.
Parking requirements are reduced citywide for bike parking or when a fee in lieu of parking is paid. Within the city center, dwelling units with underground parking have reduced requirements.

Properties zoned mixed commercial (MC) are exempt from off-street parking requirements. For any use categorized as “Commercial” or “Industrial” in the “Off Street Parking Requirements” table, off-street parking spaces may not be provided in an amount that is more than 125 percent of the minimum requirements.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for motels, hotels and funeral homes.

Off street parking facilities required for churches may be reduced by fifty percent (50%) where churches are located in nonresidential districts and within three hundred feet (300') of usable public or private off street parking areas.

Off-street parking facilities are not required in a block frontage in a B-2 or I-2 District in which the ground floor area of business or industrial structures, including their accessory buildings, existing at the time of passage of the ordinance establishing the Zoning Code, equaled 50% or more of the entire area of the block frontage.
The C-2 Downtown Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates, except for conditional uses.
The C-3 downtown commercial district is exempt from parking mandates.

The erection, expansion or use of any principal building or secondary structure located in the following districts does not require off-street parking:

A.Fringe Parking Overlay District.
B.NB Neighborhood Business District.
C.DBD Downtown Business District.
D.DTD-1 Downtown Transitional District Limited.
E.DTD-2 Downtown Transitional District General.
F.C-CBD Central Business District.
G.NC Neighborhood Conservation District, Tract 5
H.UD Urban Design Overlay, except west of North Classen Boulevard and in the Lincoln Boulevard Corridor Subdistrict.
I.BC Bricktown Core.
J.The Farmers Market District of the Scenic River Overlay Design District (SRODD).
The C-1 Central Business Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates.
The “C” Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The B-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-3 central business district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

The total number of accessory parking spaces provided for one-family, two-family or multifamily dwellings or hotels shall not exceed those required for such use or for any equivalent new use by more than fifty (50) percent or four (4) spaces, whichever number is greater.

Olympia enacted specific zone district requirements, eliminating residential parking minimums as well as minimums for all existing commercial buildings, and new commercial construction or expansion totaling under 3,000 square feet within the Downtown Exempt Parking Area. Non-residential uses may receive credit for on-street parking in all districts.
Permitted uses in the C-2 Central Business District are exempt from parking mandates.

Minimum parking requirements have been eliminated for all land uses in the central business district (CBD) and neighborhood business districts (NBD). 

For TOD-1, there are no minimum parking requirements.
For TOD-2, TOD-3, TOD-4 the minimum number of required parking spaces is 50 percent of the specified minimum requirements.
No off-street parking is required in the BC Central Business Commercial District.
Parking maximums are set at 150% of the minimums.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.

Within the MU-1 (Downtown Mixed Use) district, off-street parking is not required for existing buildings having a floor area of less than 10,000 square feet. ADUs may be exempt from parking mandates when located near transit, carshare is available or other factors.
No parking lot shall exceed the minimum parking space requirements by ten percent (10%) greater than required.
Off-street parking is not required for uses in the DOD Downtown Overlay District. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums for commercial and industrial uses.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
Within the DMU District, sites with less than 20,000 square feet in land area have no minimum
parking requirements. Parking requirements are reduced for sites larger than 20,000 square feet, which may also pay a fee in-lieu of required parking. Parking maximums apply in the district.
The C-1 General Commercial and C-2 Highway Commercial districts are exempt from minimum parking and loading requirements.
ADUs are exempt from parking mandates when certain criteria are met. Uses in the Downtown Plaza District have reduced requirements and may pay a fee in-lieu of required parking.

Within the Riverfront Commercial District, a change of use is exempt from minimum parking requirements. Additionally, requirements may be reduced if the proposed development substantially conforms to the parking plan and standards provided for in each development district as described in the Riverfront Master Plan element of the city's comprehensive plan. A fee-in-lieu of required parking may be provided in the district.

In July 2022, Oregon's Land Conservation and Development Committee adopted permanent rules which required 61 cities in the state's 8 metro regions to eliminate parking mandates near high frequency transit service by 1/1/2023. Additional rules will require more comprehensive reforms in following years. 

HB2001, passed in 2019,  legalized “missing middle” housing types – such as duplexes, fourplexes, and townhomes – in medium and large cities statewide. The new rules implementing the law “hold mandatory parking ratios at or below one parking space per home.”

HB2001 rules apply to any city with a population greater than 10,000 people and to any city in a metro area with more than 1,000 people. Approximately 58 Oregon cities fall under this definition.

Medium cities had to comply by 6/30/2021 and large cities by 6/30/2022.

Additionally, ADUs are legal, statewide, and cities may not require parking for ADUs.

No site plan may be approved, for a multi-family or non-residential use, which contains more than 120% of the development’s minimum number of required parking spaces, except as granted through a conditional use permit. Within the Central Business (CB) District, the parking requirements are waived.
Single-family and two-family dwellings are exempt from parking mandates.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Uses within the Downtown Parking Zone A are exempt from parking requirements. Uses within the Downtown Parking Zone B have reduced requirements. Parking maximums apply to most uses.
Public parking and on-street parking may count towards requirements in the Place-Based Code Overlay.
Within the D – Downtown District, parking requirements are reduced and existing building space is exempt from parking requirements.
The maximum number of spaces constructed for a use or building may not exceed one hundred ten percent (110%) of the minimum parking amounts.
Commercial uses within the C-1 Downtown Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
There is no minimum required number of off-street parking stalls in the B-1 General Business District.

Within the State Street Business & Neighborhood District, a portion of the district is exempt from parking mandates as shown on the map. Lots that are not exempt have minimum and maximum requirements. Within the MU, Mixed-Use (B-1 and B-2 Overlay District), parking maximums apply in addition to the minimums.
Oshawa exempts non-residential uses from parking mandates in the city center. Also in this district, residential developments with fewer than 10 homes have no parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Within the CMU district and Parking Requirement Exemption Overlay District, the minimum parking requirements are waived for non-residential uses. Residential uses may count parking within 1000 feet towards the minimum requirement. Parking maximums apply to most uses citywide.

Within the Village Overlay District, on-street parking may count towards parking minimums. Parking requirements may be reduced citywide for frontage roads or cross parking arrangements. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.
Any use within the DC downtown commercial district other than downtown residential is exempt from the off-street parking requirements.
Allowed uses in the B-1 General Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Nonresidential uses in the D-1 District are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums apply to most uses while most minimums were reduced in May 2024.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums for parking lots with 50 or more spaces.
No off-street parking facilities are required in the C-4 Central Business District.
Ottawa has zero parking requirements in the city center and no residential parking requirements for buildings less than 4 stories. Remaining parking requirements are relatively low.
The C-1 Local Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Any use within the C-4 downtown mixed-use district is exempt from the off-street parking requirements.
No off‐street parking or loading space is required for any use located in the "C‐1" Commercial District.
On-street parking spaces located adjacent to the site may be counted towards off-street parking requirements. A maximum of 50% of the required parking may be provided on-street.
Parking mandates do not apply in the AG Agricultural District, B-1 Central Business District or QP Quasi-Public District.
Parking requirements may be reduced for business uses when motorcycle parking is provided.

Off street parking is not required in the (HC) Historic Core Overlay District, (DT-C) Downtown Core Overlay District, (RF-C) Riverfront Core Overlay District, (RF-X) Riverfront Crossing Overlay District, or (RF-E) Riverfront Edge Overlay District.
The C-3 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The central business district is exempt from parking mandates, except for residential uses.
Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums.
The C-1 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Allowed uses in the HUCN—Historic urban center district, except for residential uses built after July 2017, are exempt from parking mandates where nearby on-street or public parking exists. Parking requirements are reduced for uses zoned TND Traditional Neighborhood Development. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: In the UP District, all uses are exempt from parking requirements. All non-residential uses in the RO District are exempt from parking requirements. Within the R-3 District, parking requirements may be reduced through the proximity of transit, bike parking, proximity to Miami University, and adjacent on-street parking. The maximum number of spaces for all uses is limited to no more than one hundred fifty percent (150%) of the minimum unless approved by Conditional Use Permit. Single, Two and Three-Family uses on individual lots are exempt from the maximum.
Nonresidential uses in the C-3 Central Business District are exempt from parking mandates.
ADUs may be exempted from parking requirements based on any of 5 conditions.
The "C-4" Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Any nonresidential use within the B-2 Downtown Business Zone, B-2-T Downtown Business Townlift Zone and H-1 Historical-Commercial Zone is exempt from off-street parking requirements.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of motorcycle parking or RV parking.
Parking maximums for commercial and industrial uses are set at 125% of the minimums.
ADUs may be exempted from parking mandates when certain criteria are met.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the C-1 Downtown Commercial District.
A nonresidential change of use in an existing building within the CD Commercial Downtown District is exempt from parking mandates.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums for commercial and industrial uses.

The area that would have been used to meet the minimum parking requirements may be used for building purposes in the B1 Central Business District, provided all other applicable bulk requirements are met.
Panama City removed all parking minimum requirements on lots less than 10,000 sq. ft., buildings built before 1945, and all new construction less than 5 stories.
In the D Downtown District, required parking may be reduced through the provision of on-street parking spaces, parking around Park Square, and City lot parking.
The TWN Town Square District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking.
Any use within the CBD Central Business District is exempt from the off-street parking requirements.
Parking requirements are reduced in the downtown special parking district. A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided to further reduce requirements.
The C-3 Central Business District does not require off street parking.
The D-4 downtown commercial district is exempt from minimum parking requirements. Parking maximums apply to residential uses.

Minimum parking requirements do not apply to non-residential uses in existing buildings within the Downtown area, considered for the purposes of this exemption to be the area within the boundaries of Lakewood Boulevard to the north, Orchard Drive to the west, Indianwood Boulevard to the South, and Forest Boulevard to the east.
Parking requirements may be reduced for non-residential uses that are located within one-half mile of a commuter rail station, within one-quarter mile of a public transit bus stop, or within 400 feet of a municipally-owned parking lot. Parking requirements may be reduced for all uses in all districts by providing EV charging stations or through the payment of a fee-in-lieu of required parking. Multi-family dwellings that reserve car-share parking spaces may further reduce the total number of required parking spaces.
No use may provide parking spaces in excess of 125 percent of the required minimum parking amount, except for residential uses in residential districts, and uses with a requirement of less than ten spaces.

Commercial land uses in any commercial zoning district that are one thousand (1,000) square feet or less in gross floor area are exempt from the parking standards. Commercial land uses in the B-4 District are exempt from the parking standards.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Within the Greater Downtown Districts, the first 3000 square feet of a nonresidential use is exempt from parking mandates, while parking minimums are reduced and parking maximums apply. Mandates may be further reduced through TDM strategies.
Minimum parking requirements are not applicable to property in the B-1 Central Business District.

Employee parking in Commercial and Manufacturing Districts is required at the rate of one (1) space per employee in addition to the customer spaces. However, the B-1 Commercial District is exempt from the employee parking requirements.
A change of use from residential to commercial is exempt from parking mandates in the C-2 General Commercial District.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
No use may provide more than fifteen percent (15%) above the minimum required parking without incorporating mitigating strategies. Furthermore, multiple opportunities exist for reducing parking. In the downtown area, bounded on the north by 3rd Street, on the east by the White Aloe Creek, on the south by the railroad tracks, and on the west by West Street, no residential parking is required for two (2) or fewer dwelling units on a lot. For non-residential uses, no parking is required for buildings and uses under one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet. In all districts and for all uses, parking requirements may be reduced with the following strategies:
1. On-street parking within six hundred (600) feet of any lot frontage may count towards the parking requirement at a rate of one (1) space for every two (2) on-street spaces.
2. All bicycle parking may reduce the required vehicle parking at a rate of one (1) space for every four (4) bicycle parking spaces up to a maximum of fifteen percent (15%) of the required vehicle parking.
3. Any site within six hundred (600) feet of a public parking area may reduce the required vehicle parking at a rate of one (1) space for every two (2) public parking spaces.

In one-family residential districts, the number of parking spaces provided may not exceed three spaces per dwelling unit on lots of 12,000 square feet or less, and not more than four spaces per dwelling unit on lots of more than 12,000 square feet.
The Neighborhood Commercial, Mixed Use District (CX1) is exempt from parking mandates.
No parking is required in the C-2 Central Business District except for dwelling units permitted in conjunction with business uses.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: ADUs are exempt from parking requirements when certain conditions are met. Parking mandates are reduced for Transit Oriented Development, and within the CD-1 Old Pasadena and CD-4 Pasadena Playhouse Districts. Parking maximums apply near transit.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The DT Downtown District is exempt from parking mandates. On-street parking may count towards parking requirements in the Neighborhood Commercial (NC), Community Commercial (CC), Gateway Commercial (GC), or Waterfront Mixed-Use (WMU) districts. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums for commercial uses citywide.
The City of Pasco does not require off-street parking in the Central Business District or Downtown Pasco Overlay District.
Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums for commercial and mixed-use properties.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be paid within the area shown on the map. Entertainment venues and some restaurants are excluded.
Permitted uses in the DB Downtown Business District are exempt from parking mandates.

In the B‐1 and B‐2 Districts, lots 25 feet or less in width existing at the date of the adoption of the Zoning Ordinance are exempt from non‐residential parking requirements. Parking requirements are reduced in the B-4 District.
Retail and office uses in the C-1 Central Business District are exempt from parking mandates.
Land uses within the CBD central business district are exempt from parking requirements.
Any use within the TC (Town Center) District is exempt from the off-street parking requirements.
Single-family and two-family dwellings have a parking maximum of four.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
Within the CT Conant Thread District, there are no parking mandates, while parking maximums apply to office, retail, professional service and restaurant uses. The CD Commercial Downtown District is exempt from parking mandates and requirements are reduced 50% for uses in the Mill Building Reuse District (MBRD). 

Business uses citywide may count adjacent on-street parking toward parking requirements. Personal services, museums, libraries and art galleries, which are operated in storefronts or as home occupations, and which do not exceed 1,000 square feet, are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums apply to retail, personal services, office, and other commercial uses, and eating and drinking establishments.
Parking requirements may be reduced for nonresidential and mixed-uses through the provision of bike parking, and through on-street parking or public parking in the MNB and DT Zoning Districts.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Within the area determined by the Plan Commission to be the Central Business District the parking regulations do not apply. The first 2000 square feet of retail stores, banks, furniture and appliance stores, household equipment or furniture repair shops is exempt from minimum parking requirements, as well as the first 4000 square feet of wholesale establishments. The total number of accessory parking spaces provided for one-, two-, or multiple-family dwellings or hotels may not exceed the requirements by more than 50%, or four spaces, whichever number is greater.
Parking maximums exist for all uses.
There are no minimum parking requirements except for multi-family dwellings.
Existing buildings in the Old Townsite District have reduced parking requirements.
Off-street parking and loading spaces are not required for any use located in the "C-2" Central Business District.
The ED-1 Zone is exempt from minimum parking requirements. The requirements for other districts serve solely as a guideline for the ED-1 district.
Any use within the CBD Central Business District, other than residential, is exempt from the requirement to provide off-street parking.
The Historic Village Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
A change of use in an existing building is exempt from parking mandates.
The C-1 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
In the Urban Core Zone, no parking is required for retail/office/or light manufacturing.
Parking requirements are reduced for most uses in the Transit Oriented Development (TOD) Overlay District.

Off-street parking is not required in the HC-1, or HC-2 district, or in the dense business area for residential land uses. Buildings within the South Palafox business district or the C-2A district may be exempted depending on size. Parking requirements may be reduced when bike parking is provided.
No minimum parking or loading is required in commercial zones C5 and C6. City wide parking minimums can be reduced by 1 space, per 5 bicycle parking, and 1 space for a fee of $13,000.
Nonresidential uses in the C-3 Central Business District are exempt from parking mandates while residential uses in the district along Hancock Street have reduced requirements.

When parking regulations would result in a requirement of not more than three (3) parking spaces for a nonresidential use in a RCC Rural Community Conservation District, no off-street parking spaces need be provided.
Parking requirements for residential uses which include on-street parking are reduced.

The city removed parking minimum requirements for most non-residential developments in 2015. Zoning lots less than 12,000 square feet in land area in the Warehouse District and 7,500 square feet in the other Form Districts have no minimum parking requirements. No parking requirements exist for any use in the B1Downtown Commercial District. Parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.

In lieu of required parking spaces in the D-C Downtown Commercial District, a payment may be made to the City parking fund. The determination to allow a payment in-lieu of required parking will be made by the Council and shall be based on available municipal parking facilities within five hundred (500) feet of the use and the total City parking system in general.
Businesses which lack front or side setbacks are exempt from parking mandates.
The BC Central Business Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The GB General Business District and DB Downtown Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-2 (Central Business) District is exempt from parking mandates.

There is no minimum parking space requirement for any Commercial, Industrial, or Institutional property. Instead, individual developers are expected to consider their parking needs and design accordingly.
All uses are exempt from parking mandates, except for residential uses in approximately half the city. Parking maximums apply to all uses citywide with variations based on districts or street type.
Off-street car parking is not required for any use located in the C-3 central business district.

Buildings in a municipal parking assessment district are exempt from parking requirements. City also has SmartCode which recommends elimination of requirements on a case by case basis if the developer waives the right to protest the formation of a parking district.
Parking Districts 1 and 2 cover the city center of Petersburg and allow for a 60% and 30% reduction in parking minimums respectively.
There is no requirement for off-street parking for the C-1 Commercial 1 District.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The Central Business Parking Exempt District is exempted from minimum parking requirements. Parking maximums apply to all uses citywide. Off-street parking requirements in the B2-A Transitional Business District are no less than 75 percent of the minimum parking requirements. Off-street parking requirements in the B2-B Mixed Use Corridor are no less than 75 percent and no more than 90 percent of the minimum parking requirements.
There are no parking mandates. Instead, the Zoning Administrator reviews the parking proposed with regard to a table of suggested parking.

There are no minimum parking requirements for residential land uses in certain residential districts (RSA-4/5/6 and RM-1). There are no minimum parking requirements for residential, office, and retail land uses in certain commercial zoning districts (CMX-2/2.5, CMX-3, CMX-4/5).
The C-1 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from providing parking spaces for uses allowed within the district.

No car parking is required for non-residential uses in the Downtown and Warehouse districts. Reductions for residential and commercial parking requirements are automatic near light rail stations. Parking maximums are in place for most uses, but there are ample opportunities to increase them.

Phoenixville PA had the zoning ordinance rewritten to remove parking requirements for specific blocks of the downtown, and all other parking is required to be based on a parking demand analysis, not specific standards.
The C-2 Downtown Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates.
The CBD Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for residential uses.
Within the Olde Pickerington Village Overlay District, a fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for all uses except single-family dwellings.
There are no off-street parking requirements for commercial uses in existing buildings in the C-3 District.

The requirements for off-street parking do not apply to Blocks six (6), Seven (7), Eight (8) and Nine (9), Original plat and Blocks one (1) and two (2), First Railway Addition, all in the City of Pierre.
Permitted uses in the C-1 Community Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements in the CBD (C-3) District are reduced for residential uses.
Parking minimums do not apply to the ML Mount Lemmon zone or the RVC Rural Village Center zone adjacent to the ML zone.
Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums.
Storefront businesses in the C-1 Primary Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

If commercial businesses on adjacent parcels in the M-13 Corridor Overlay Zone provide a contiguous parking area, parking requirements are reduced by 20%. Parking requirements are reduced for mixed uses.
No minimum off-street parking is required in the B-5 Central Business District.
The CBD Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for dwelling, lodging and day care uses.
No on-site parking is required in the Downtown Parking Zone. This zone generally consists of C-1 Zones from Pine Creek to Bridger Avenue.

Within the Downtown Core (DC) Zoning District, parking and loading requirements are waived for developments consisting of majority ground floor commercial office/retail with residential dwelling units above. In addition, uses in the district are permitted to count adjacent on-street parking towards off street parking requirements. Historically designated properties are exempt from parking requirements so long as historic designation is maintained on the property and upheld by Charlotte-Mecklenburg Historic Landmark Commission or similar.

There are no specified parking minimums. Instead, projects must submit a Transportation Management Plan (TMP) which determines how much parking is required. The parking requirements of the TMP may be met on site, or through public parking. No project may provided more than 100% of the estimated parking demand.
Within the OTBD Old Town Business District, required parking areas are reduced by one half (1/2) the normal requirements.

In designated "Parking Exempt Areas", minimum parking requirements have been reduced by percentages ranging from 50% - 100% specified in the Pittsburgh zoning code. Land uses within these boundaries may not exceed the minimum parking requirements otherwise stated in the zoning code. As of September 2024, the city is proposing a repeal of parking mandates to boost housing affordability.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
Permitted stores and other retail establishments in the B-2 Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Within the Downtown Creative District, no parking is required for the adaptive reuse of buildings listed or eligible for listing on the National or State Register of Historic Places or for ground floor uses on a Principal or Secondary Street. Parking requirements are reduced for uses in the TS Tyler Street Overlay District and the Smart Growth Overlay District.
The  Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Parking maximums apply to any use with a parking lot larger than 20 spaces.

There are no parking minimums townwide. Parking is "market based" where the applicant proposes a number of parking spaces and this can include parking spots in proximity (its "parkingshed") but not under its actual control.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Small residential and business land uses within the Downtown Parking Zone (DPZ) are exempt from the minimum parking requirements. However, If a commercial land use has a gross floor area of five thousand (5,000) square feet or more, then the standards apply. If parking is required of a particular use, nearby on-street parking spaces and municipal parking lots may count towards off-street parking spaces. Commercial establishments within the DPZ shall not provide a number of off-street parking spaces that is greater than one hundred (100) percent of the parking requirement for that particular establishment's land use.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Any use within the CD Downtown District is exempt from off-street parking requirements.

The total number of accessory parking spaces, open to the sky, provided for one-family or two-family dwellings shall not exceed that required for such use by more than fifty percent (50%) or four (4) spaces, per zoning lot, whichever number is greater. Multiple-family dwellings shall not exceed that required by this title by more than fifty percent (50%).

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
The BG Downtown Business/Government District is exempt from minimum parking requirements. Maximum parking is set at the minimum number of required off-street parking spaces plus 10%, which may be exceeded if conditions are met. Up to 10% of required parking may be permanently set aside for stormwater quality or quantity improvements provided that the minimum required parking is 100 spaces or greater. 
Parking requirements for infill nonresidential uses may have reduced requirements, and a change of use may be exempted after the passage of Zoning Case 2023-027 on January 8, 2024.

Parking stalls are not required to be provided for uses in existing buildings in the B-2 Central Business District, and are reduced for new uses or buildings in the district. Parking requirements are reduced in the CBT Central Business Transition District. In both districts, a fee-in-lieu of parking may be paid.
Any use within the CB (central business) district is exempt from the off-street parking
Within the C Commercial District, parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking. Parking requirements may be reduced citywide for commercial uses near municipal parking.
The C-2 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Residential uses in the MUV Mixed-Use Village Residential District may count on-street parking towards parking requirements.
Within the B-2 central business district, parking requirements are reduced by right, and may be further reduced for mixed-use developments or through the payment of a fee in lieu of required parking.
Uses in the B-2 General Business District and CB Central Business District are exempt from parking requirements when the use of an existing building is changed.
Minimum parking regulations do not apply in the C-1 Downtown Commercial District.
Parking requirements for all permitted uses are waived in the Central Commercial Zoning District and Warehouse Historic District.
The B-1 Shopping District is exempt from parking mandates.
Retail shops, offices, restaurants (except fast food restaurants) and similar low-intensity uses in the “C-TS” Town Square Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Nonresidential uses other than churches or places of public assembly are exempt from parking mandates.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking or through a documented case study.

The Downtown Pomona Specific Plan, adopted August 5, 2019, removes minimum parking requirements for most existing buildings and many new ones. 

Specifically, the code states that "Parking requirements do not apply to the first two floors of any proposed development within the MU-CBD or MU-I districts. Moreover, the first two floors of any existing development within said boundaries are also not subject to parking requirements."

Since most of downtown Pomona's existing buildings are only one or two stories high, this provision removes minimum parking requirements for them. New one and two-story buildings are also exempt from parking minimums. Taller new buildings still have minimum parking requirements applied to the upper floors.

The plan also establishes maximum parking requirements, although this limit does not apply to parking spaces that are provided in parking structures. 

ADUs are exempt from parking mandates citywide.
Businesses in the CBD district are exempt from off street parking requirements.
The OT Old Town District is exempt from off-street parking requirements.

Within the Central Business District, uses may be relieved from providing the normally required on-site parking. The city council may authorize the payment of a fee in lieu of providing the normally required on-site parking spaces, in the amount of $1,000.00 to the city for each parking space not provided.

The C-2 central business district is exempt from minimum parking requirements. The maximum amount of off-street parking permitted for any use citywide may not exceed two hundred percent (200%) of the minimum parking requirements. This requirement does not apply to single-family or two-family dwellings.
The C-3 Central Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements within the Central Business (CB) District are waived, unless the Zoning Administrator notes otherwise.
Parking requirements are reduced by 25% for mixed-use developments.
Within the DMU Downtown Mixed-Use District, nonresidential uses have a reduced parking requirement by right. Citywide, on-street parking may count towards parking minimums.

Non-residential uses in the B-1 zoning district and having frontage on Lake Street between State Street and West Spring Street; or on West Spring Street between Arch Street and Lake Street are not required to provide off-street parking.
There are no off-street parking requirements in the Central Business District (C2 Main Street Business District), with the exception of certain land uses (cabarets, catering/events, and theaters).
Parcels located in the Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The B-1 Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Uses within the CBD Central Business District may utilize public parking to fulfill parking minimums.
Within the CBD Central Business District, municipal parking lots within a reasonable walking distance for commercial uses may be counted towards the requirements.
On-street parking may count towards parking requirements for residential uses.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Maximum parking requirements exist citywide. Previously, all uses located on floors above the ground floor within the C-I, C-II, C-II(H), C-I/MU and C-II/MU zoning districts were exempt from parking mandates. On March 4, 2024, the city adopted an interim zoning ordinance over which parking requirements are instead recommendations while the city studies a permanent ordinance. This interim ordinance was extended until March 15, 2025.
Business uses in the B-4 Central Business District are exempt from the parking space requirement.

All surface parking in the CR CM and CC downtown districts shall be shared parking. Because parking shall be provided by the city, private off-street parking is prohibited unless it existed prior to the establishment of these guidelines or is granted approval by the development review committee.
Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums for parking lots with 100 or more spaces.
Parking space requirements are waived within the B-2 downtown district, except for developments exceeding 40,000 square feet.

Portland eliminated all parking mandates and implemented parking maximums on November 4, 2024. Previously, the city had exemptions for projects within 1/4 mile of fixed route transit, ADUs, or 3 or fewer homes in low-density residential zones.
On-street and off-street public parking may count towards the minimums in the C-1, central business district. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums citywide.

Portland has no parking mandates citywide for any uses. Prior to July 2023, the city maintained mandates that were only in effect in rare instances. As part of Oregon's Climate Friendly and Equitable Cities policy, the city purged the mandates from the code effective June 30, 2023.
Uses north of Jacoby Creek and fronting on Route 611 in the B District or RS District are exempt from parking mandates.
No minimum number of parking spaces are required.  However, if parking is provided, there are standards, such as providing pedestrian-ways.
No off-street parking is required in the C-1 Central Business District, except for hotels, motels and funeral homes.
The C-1 central business district is exempt from parking mandates except for conditional uses.
Nonresidential uses in the Downtown District are exempt from parking mandates as well as existing residential uses.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-3 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.

No off-street parking or loading spaces are required for any property that is both zoned B-1 Downtown Commercial and addressed in the North 200, North 100, or South 100 blocks of Main Street. No site plan may be approved for a multi-family residential or non-residential use that contains more than 125 percent of the development’s minimum number of required parking spaces, except by conditional use permit.
Uses within the Central Business District are exempted from the minimum parking requirements.

No Site Plan may be approved for a Multi-Family residential or non-residential use, which contains more than 120 percent of the development’s minimum number of required parking spaces, except through a Conditional Use Permit.
The C-1 Central Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Off-street parking is not required in the C-3 Central Business District for indoor retail businesses.
The (C-1) Downtown Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Most uses in the core RTO and LTO Zones are exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums apply to commercial and mixed-use developments. Parking requirements may be reduced for TDM strategies.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for any use citywide.

A payment may be made in lieu of providing parking spaces in the North and South Downtown Business Districts, subject to the approval of the plan commission and the city council. The north business district includes lots abutting Main Street from the railroad tracks to the north and Warren Street to the south. The south business district includes lots abutting Main Street from Central Street to the north and the southern portion of courthouse square to the south.
A change of use in an existing building is exempt from parking mandates.
The C-1 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-1 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Prompton has no zoning and therefore has no parking mandates.
The B-1 Retail Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The Downtown District is exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums apply in all other districts. Parking reductions are available for uses near transit or which meet other criteria.

There are no minimum parking requirements for the D-1 District land use and the “neighborhood commercial establishment” use.

TOD overlay districts have no minimum parking requirements, with maximums for residential land uses. For non-residential land uses, the first 5,000 GFA is exempt from minimum parking requirements, with maximums.

Commercial and office projects exceeding 20,000 GFA must comply with a parking maximum (may not exceed 135% of the minimum parking requirements).

Parking requirements may be reduced by 50% in the M-MU-90 Sub-District.

Non-residential land uses that provide cyclists shower and locker facilities may reduce parking by four spaces. Non-residential use provides 120% or more additional bicycle parking spaces may reduce parking by up to 10%. When 10 or more bicycles are provided for a bike-share facility, there may be a 5% reduction of required parking spaces.
In the Town Center Commercial (TCC) non-residential uses are exempt from parking requirements.

Provo City currently has city code which grants an automatic 25% parking reduction for most of the Downtown zones (DT1, DT2, ITOD) and Mixed-Use zones (MU, NMU) which is over 300 acres of land. Additional parking reductions are available for commercial, industrial, public facilities or multi-family housing zones throughout the city which is over 7,700 acres of land that could use this reduction if granted by the Planning Commission.  1) A Transportation Demant Management (TDM) program and a Parking County Justification Study, 2) Providing Increased Bicycle Parking Spaces.
Pryor Creek eliminated parking mandates for nonresidential uses in December 2018.

No off-street parking is required for any existing building or use, unless said building or use is enlarged, in which case the parking provisions apply only to the enlarged portion of the building or use.

Within the City Center Zoning District, the city has established a Parking Exemption area. In this area, buildings with a footprint below 10,000 square feet are not required to provide parking for uses on site.
Permitted uses in the T-C Town Center Commercial District are exempt from parking mandates.
Commercial uses in the TC Town Center Zoning District are exempt from parking mandates.
Parking maximums apply to shopping centers.

In all downtown zoning districts (D1, D2, D3, D4 and D5), off-street parking requirements may be reduced to 50% of the parking spaces otherwise required; provided the property is located within 600 feet of a municipal parking lot which is primarily available for public parking. Existing buildings not in compliance with the off street parking requirements may be remodeled, repaired, and structurally altered and may change use without complying with the minimum off street parking standards, except for a change in use to a nightclub or cabaret.
Parking requirements are reduced in the Quincy Center Districts and Transit Oriented Development Districts.

All uses in the CBD Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements, and all uses in the RLB Residential-Limited Business District are only required to provide half of the number of spaces otherwise required.
On-street parking may count towards minimum parking requirements.

In the B4 central business district, for the purpose of minimizing disruptive curb cuts and driveways and to encourage the consolidation of parking space in appropriate locations, accessory off-street parking is not required.

On 3/15/2022 Raleigh City Council voted 7-1 to eliminate parking mandates citywide and impose parking maximums on many uses. Raleigh previously had no parking minimum requirements in the Downtown District and in the Transportation Overlay District.
All uses within the TC Town Center District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
ADUs are exempt from parking mandates if one of five criteria are met.
Areas which are located in a fire district as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-1 General Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
On-street parking may count toward parking requirements in the CFDD Carrie Furnace Development District.
