On-street parking may be counted toward the parking requirements for residential uses. Minimum required parking may be reduced where fully enclosed bicycle lockers are provided on a one-for-one exchange ratio, except for single family detached dwellings. Parking maximums exist for most uses.
In the Main Street (MS) District, existing buildings that were legally constructed as of January 1, 2016 without on-site parking are considered conforming. Such buildings are eligible for change of use permits, and for building up-fits. A fee-in-lieu of parking may be paid in order to reduce parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at four spaces per dwelling unit for single-family homes.
The central business district (CBD) is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
There are no off-street parking and loading requirements in the C-1 Central Business District.
The area bounded by Spruce Street on the North, Second Street on the East, Sixth Street on the West and Front Street on the South is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Single-family and two-family dwellings and accessory buildings as well as multi-family dwellings on upper floors of retail structures are exempt from minimum parking requirements within the Central Business District (CBD).
No off-street parking spaces need be provided for property located in the Town Square Overlay District.
Within the B-2 Central Business District, public parking spaces may be counted toward the required parking spaces for nonresidential uses.
Off-street parking spaces are not required in the Downtown Mixed Use Overlay District, provided on street parking and public parking areas are available within the district.
No off-street parking is required for nonresidential uses in the C-C Commercial Core and C-R Commercial Residential Zoning Districts.
Any use within the TC Town Center Commercial District other than Downtown Residential is exempt from off-street parking requirements.
On-street parking directly in front of the zoning lot may count toward fulfilling the parking requirement of that lot.

Minimum parking regulations do not apply to the present C-1 Commercial District areas indicated on the atlas and described as follows: blocks two and three, seven and eight, nine and ten, Champagne and Dow’s Additions, and that part of block three of original town site within the boundaries of C-1, and the east half of block 51 west half of block 52 of Kretzschmar’s Addition.
Development and uses located in the Central Business District (C-4) are exempt from the minimum parking requirements.
The C-3 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Developments in the B-3 Central Business District and the Civic District are exempt from the provisions of providing off-street parking

There are no minimum parking requirements in the Downtown Core District, but if parking is provided it must be provided in accordance with the requirements of Redding Zoning Code. There are also minimum parking reductions in the Mixed Use District, and opportunities to apply for reductions citywide if shared parking is pursued, if the property is in proximity to transit, or if bicycle parking is present.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the Central Commercial District (C-2).

Within the TDO Traditional Downtown Overlay District, parking requirements are reduced for nonresidential uses and residential uses which are part of a mixed-use development. Nonresidential uses in the district may utilize public parking or a fee in lieu of parking as necessary.
Properties existing prior to adoption of the UDO and located within the B-4, the Central Business District are exempt from parking requirements.
The B1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Offices and industrial uses may reduce parking requirements citywide if transit passes are provided, while bike parking in Zone 1 (city center) may reduce requirements there. Minimums for multi-family housing may be reduced through the provision of an electric carsharing service, e-bikes, transit passes, or when a neighborhood store is located nearby. Residential uses in zone 1, and most nonresidential uses citywide may pay a fee in lieu of parking when the property is found to have insufficient space for parking.

The City of Regina removed all minimum parking requirements within the Downtown on June 17, 2019. If any parking is voluntarily provided by a development any parking in excess of one stall per 50 square metres must be contained within a structured parking facility. 
Parking mandates were replaced with recommended parking citywide in February 2024.

No parking is required for medical, dental and legal offices less than 10,000 square feet, or for food establishments, restaurants or catering, which have less than 10,000 square feet of gross floor area. All retail stores, service shops, cafes or restaurants fronting only on the Boardwalk are also exempt.
The “C-1” Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

There is no minimum parking requirement in the Mixed-Use Downtown (MD-) districts. Properties that are partly or entirely located within ¼ mile of Mixed-Use Downtown (MD-) districts or the centerline of the Virginia Street or Fourth Street bus rapid transit routes (measured in a direct line) may provide parking at 60 percent of the Level 1 parking district minimum.
The B-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Ground floor uses under 3000 square feet are exempt from parking mandates in the Olde Reynoldsburg Commercial District (ORD-C). Parking requirements may be reduced for carshare spaces, bike facilities or transit proximity citywide.

No off-street parking or loading spaces are required for any property that is both zoned B-2 Central Business and addressed in the North 10, 100, or 200 blocks of Brown Street; South 10 or 100 blocks of Brown Street; West 10, 100 or blocks of Rives Street; 10 or 100 block of Davenport Street; West 10 block of King Street; South 100 block of Anderson Street; South 100 block of Stevens Street; west side of 10 block of South Stevens Street. The area covered by the exemption was expanded in 2022.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for any use.
The Central Business District (CBD) is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Parking maximums exist for all uses between 110 and 120 percent, but may be exceeded if the additional parking does not increase the impervious surface. Parking requirements may be reduced through bike parking, frequent transit, on-street parking and the provision of a transit plaza.
Uses located within the Central Business District are exempt from all off-street parking and loading requirements.
The TWN District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Public parking may count towards parking requirements.
The Village Core Overlay District is exempt from parking mandates.
Parking requirements are reduced by 50% in the CD District for commercial uses in existing buildings and may be reduced citywide through the provision of motorcycle parking.

Parking requirements for all non-residential uses in the CB Central Business District are fifty percent (50%) of the number otherwise required. In all districts, on-street parking directly fronting a lot may count toward fulfilling the parking requirement of that lot.
No off-street parking is required in the NC Neighborhood Commercial and CB Central Business districts.
Parking maximums are set at 133% of the minimums except for single-family and two-family dwellings.
On April 24, 2023 the Richmond, VA city council voted unanimously to eliminate parking mandates citywide.
No parking lot may exceed the required number of parking spaces by more than twenty (20) percent.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: No off-street parking requirements in central mixed use district or the downtown transition area for non-residential establishments on lots less than 15,000 square feet.
Mixed-use developments, excluding restaurants, have reduced parking requirements in the West Jackson Street Overlay District.
Within the C-2 Central Business District, parking requirements are determined by the Planning Commission which may require a fee in lieu of parking.
No off-street parking is required for housing for the elderly.

Within the DS Downtown Service District, on-street parking may count towards the minimums. Within the HB Historic Business District, parking minimums are reduced and a fee in-lieu of required parking may be provided.
The C-1 District is exempt from parking mandates. On-street parking may count towards parking requirements citywide.
The first five thousand (5,000) gross square feet of a nonresidential use is exempt from all off-street parking and loading requirements in the Central Business District.
The C-2 General Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

In 2019, the city removed a mandate for a minimum of one space per housing unit for buildings within 800 meters of transit, and replaced it with a maximum of one parking space for every four residential units.  It is also now mandatory to offer bike parking facilities at a minimum of one space per housing unit.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to any building in the MSB-1 Main Street Business District, whether existing or erected within 300 feet of a municipal parking lot.
Residential uses in the C1 Neighborhood Commercial and C2 Central Business Districts have reduced parking requirements.

Service retail establishments within the C-3 Central Commercial District, located in an area bounded by Lathrop Avenue, Lake Street, Park Avenue and a line one-half block south of and parallel to Lake Street, are not required to provide any off street parking.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Businesses containing cultural and religious uses, recreational and entertainment uses, and retail and service uses, which are under one thousand (1,000) square feet in gross floor area in the R4, C1 and C2 districts are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Businesses under one thousand (1,000) square feet in gross floor area located within a shopping center configuration (i.e., a "strip mall") are not eligible for this exemption. In the R3, R4, C1 and C2 Districts, on-street parking spaces may be counted toward required off street parking spaces. New on-street parking spaces may be created to count toward required off street parking. Single-family dwellings may not provide more than four spaces.
River Rouge has no minimum parking requirements and has parking maximums in place.

When the application of the off-street parking provisions results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single zoning lot in any business or industrial district, such parking spaces need not be provided; however, where two or more uses are located on a single zoning lot, only one of those uses may be eligible for the exemption. There are no minimum parking requirements for the B-1 community shopping zoning district.

ADUs are exempt from parking mandates. A change of use within an existing structure in a nonresidential zone, which is designated as a historic resource or a contributor to a historic district, is exempt from parking requirements. Parking requirements may be reduced by implementing TDM strategies to reduce VMT.
No off-street parking is required in the C-1 Central Business Commercial District.

In the B2 Central Business District, existing buildings are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Nonresidential uses of 3,000 square feet or less of gross floor area do not require parking in the B1-C Business Subdistrict - Commercial, B1-TC Business Subdistrict - Transitional Commercial, B1-TOD Business Subdistrict - Transit-Oriented Development or B2 District.
Parking requirements may be reduced to 1 space per dwelling unit for residential uses in transit-oriented areas, including the B2 District and B1-TOD subdistrict, as well as dwellings above the ground floor of a mixed-use development in the B1-C and B1-TC. This parking reduction may also apply to other residential uses in the B1-TC subdistrict. Nonresidential uses may apply a maximum 20% parking reduction to their parking requirements in transit-oriented areas, including the B2 districts and B1-TOD subdistrict. A further reduction in the required number of off street parking spaces for nonresidential uses in the B2 District and B-1 TOD may be granted by the Planning and Zoning Commission conditioned upon payment of a fee in lieu of providing the required parking spaces. Changes in use within existing buildings do not require payment into the Parking Fund.
Minimum parking and loading space requirements do not apply to the General Retail District (C-1).
There are no minimum parking requirements citywide. There are also parking maximums. They retain minimum parking calculations for the purpose of implementing the cap on parking (maximum parking).
Parking requirements are reduced in the DD-1 Downtown District and DD-2 Downtown Transition and Transit District.

There are no parking mandates, instead there is a suggested minimum parking guide that a development is desired to follow. Depending on if it is a new or existing building and the location of property there may be some flexibility as to whether it will be approved with less parking.
Residential and business land uses are exempt in the downtown area. In addition, parking maximums exist equivalent to the minimums outside of downtown.
Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums except for single-family or two-family dwellings.
In all non-residential zoned areas, a fee in lieu of required parking may be provided.

The following uses do not require off-street parking:
  1. The adaptive reuse of a building in any Mixed Use district
  2. Small ground-floor restaurant or retail uses
  3. Development in the Medical Campus District.
Parking maximums apply to most uses citywide.

There are no parking requirements in the Center City District (CCD). All applicants proposing to construct surface parking submit a parking demand analysis defining the number of spaces, why the off-street parking is required, and methods to accommodate potential deficiencies.
The C-3 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements unless noted as a requirement of a conditional use permit.
The Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The B-2 Community Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Parking requirements within the Downtown Parking Management Plan District may be reduced if the city agrees to allow public parking spaces nearby to count towards minimum requirements. Non-residential parking requirements in Old Town are reduced as long as the project is located in an area where it can expected that 20% of the use’s customers will walk or bike to the use, or parking may be shared between uses. On-street parking may meet a portion of the minimum off-street parking requirements for projects that construct new roads and have a mix of uses. All public or commercial uses, except for business office uses, may not provide more than 125% of the minimum parking requirements.
The B-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The B-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking regulations. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
Parking requirements may be reduced for commercial uses located in the general commercial district, if angle parking exists or is constructed adjacent to the property.
The (C-1) Downtown Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The (C-1) General Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Minimum parking requirements are advisory only in the C-C Central Commercial District.
No parking is required in the C-4, Urban Mixed-Use District except for Sexually-Oriented Businesses.
The C-0 Downtown Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Within the MXTD and MXCD zones, the number of parking spaces to be provided is limited to no more than the minimum standard. This maximum may be exceeded with permeable pavement, a parking structure, or a car-share service.
The Central Commercial District (C-1) is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Uses located in the B-2 Central Business District are exempt from providing off-street parking, loading, and storage spaces.

Parking maximums exist for most non-residential uses. The Planning Commission may approve a development plan with up to a 50% reduction in the requirements for non-residential uses in the CBD Central Business Mixed Use District.
Rogers City has implemented the removal of parking minimum standards for the B-2 district, the downtown area. This is primarily commercial and mixed use with a couple of residential lots.

On July 23, 2024, Rogers eliminated all parking mandates. Previously, there were no minimum parking requirements for non-residential uses in the C-3 Neighborhood Commercial District, the COR, COM, IA downtown Rogers zones, and the U-COR, U-COM, U-ENT uptown Rogers zones.
In the Downtown Zoning District, on-street parking stalls within 500 feet of the proposed use may be counted towards required parking minimums at a rate of 40%.
There are no parking requirements in the CC Center City District, except for new construction where sufficient land area exists to allow the provision of adequate parking.

When application of the off-street parking provisions results in a requirement of three spaces or less on a single lot in any commercial or manufacturing district, the minimum parking standards do not apply.
Maximum parking exists for all uses citywide. However, maximums may be exceeded by providing more landscaping.
Within the CBD Central Business District, on-street parking may count towards parking minimums, which are reduced by right.

The total number of parking spaces provided for one-family, two-family or multiple family dwellings may not exceed the minimum requirements by more than fifty percent (50%) or four spaces, whichever number is greater.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.

Off-street parking requirements are not applied in the C-1 Downtown Commercial District. In parking lots with 25 or more parking spaces, bicycle parking spaces may be substituted for automobile parking spaces.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
All commercial uses are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No additional parking is required for changes of commercial uses in an existing structure within the Town Center District (B-3).
Uses constructed in the DT downtown district are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
A fee in lieu of required parking is possible citywide.

All permitted uses within the historic district (HD) or central business district (CBD), with the exception of community assembly, colleges and universities, are exempt from parking mandates. ADUs may be exempted citywide when certain criteria are met.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking in the B-1, B-2, B-3, and OS Districts.

Parking requirements may be reduced through frequent transit service, on-street parking or a travel demand management plan. In addition, parking maximums exist for all uses, but may be exceeded if the parking does not create additional impervious surfaces.
The C-3 Core Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements are reduced in Zones 1-3 as shown on the map. Parking requirements may be further reduced through a fee in lieu of parking or a mobility concept/TDM plan.
There are no minimum parking requirements in Roswell's C-3 (downtown) district.

When the application of the off-street parking provisions results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single zoning lot in any business district, such parking spaces need not be provided; however, when two or more uses are located on a single zoning lot, only one of those uses may be eligible for the exemption.

When the application of off-street parking provisions results in a requirement of not more than three (3) spaces on a single zoning lot in any business district, such parking spaces need not be provided; however, where two (2) or more uses are located on a single zoning lot, only one (1) of those uses may be eligible for the exemption.

When the application of the off-street parking provisions results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single zoning lot in any business district, such parking spaces need not be provided; however, where two or more uses are located on a single zoning lot, only one of those uses may be eligible for the exemption.

Within the CBD Central Business District, parking requirements are reduced for commercial uses and a commercial or retail change of use in an existing building is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

The provision of off-street parking is not required in the Central Business District Zone, except in the case of residential dwellings, hotels and motels, religious institutions, private and public schools and universities, hospitals, congregate care facilities, senior housing, convalescent or nursing homes. Residential uses have reduced requirements.
Permitted uses in "C-1" Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Within the CB Central Business District, commercial uses and up to two dwelling units in existing buildings near public parking lots are exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements are reduced in the ARU Adaptive Reuse Overlay District.
The B-1 Central Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The B-2 General Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for conditional uses.
Properties located within the Central Business District (CBD) without dwelling units are not required to provide off-street parking.
Within the C-2 Downtown Commercial District, a fee-in-lieu of parking may be provided.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

The Central Business District, Downtown Crossing Zone, and Prairie Creek Zone are exempt from minimum parking requirements. The College Hill Zone is only required to provide one half (1/2) of required parking for residential dwellings. For non-residential uses, there is no minimum number of spaces required. However, the applicant must provide a statement or parking analysis indicating how they will provide adequate parking for the proposed non-residential use to succeed without negatively impacting adjacent properties or creating or compounding a dangerous traffic condition.
The B-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: No parking is required in the Core Downtown district except for residential land uses where one parking space per unit is required. On-street parking may be counted towards 20 percent of the minimums. Except for restaurant uses, no use may provide more than 125 percent of the required parking.
Off-street parking requirements do not apply to the (C-1) Downtown Commercial District.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the C-1 Downtown Commercial District.

There are currently no minimum parking requirements in the Central Business & Arts/Entertainment District for all land uses. In this district, commercial land uses have parking maximums.

The city adopted a housing plan in 2021 which called for further eliminating city-mandated parking minimums and explore instituting parking maximums along established transit corridors. The General Plan passed in February 2024 and implemented in March 2024 will require the city to update the zoning code to eliminate parking minimums citywide. Although the zoning code has yet to be updated, the general plan policy of no minimums will prevail in the interim.
Parking requirements may be reduced with a shared driveway or other public benefits.

The minimum parking requirements in the Riverfront Mixed Use District may be reduced by one motor vehicle parking space for every two bicycle parking spaces. Motor vehicle parking spaces may not be reduced by more than 10% of the total number of required motor vehicle parking spaces.
The City has implemented the elimination of parking space minimums in the City Center/Business Zoning District.

Since at least 2008, the city has implemented a parking exemption for every use in some sectors, except for residential units. The exemption is applied by zones and they are mostly within the old pre-war downtown area.
Also, anywhere else in the city and for every uses, the parking requirement can be reduced by a maximum of 30% of the required number of spaces with a monetary compensation of 7500$ per missing spot. The city council decides if the reduction is accepted totally, partially or declined.
Places of worship and schools other than State College are exempt from parking requirements citywide, while nonresidential uses in the B5 Central Development District are also exempt.
Salem City Council repealed parking mandates citywide by a vote of 7-2 on April 10, 2023. Parking maximums apply to all uses.
Minimum parking requirements are not applicable to property in the CB central business district, except for residential uses which are authorized by a conditional use permit.
Existing buildings in the Central Business District (C-2) are exempt from parking mandates. Commercial uses in the Central Business Economic Overlay (CBEO) may pay a fee in lieu of required parking.

No off-street parking is required for any structure in the C-4 central business district except residences. Citywide, the total number of parking spaces provided for a single-family, a two-family or multiple-family dwelling may not exceed the requirements by more than fifty (50) percent or four (4) spaces, whichever number is greater.

ADUs may be exempted when certain criteria are met. Uses located in the new urbanism (NU) districts, mixed use (MU) districts, central city overlay (downtown core area) district, or focused growth overlay district may count on-street parking towards the requirements. Nonresidential uses in a parking district may pay a fee in-lieu of required parking.

Within the Downtown Core (D-1) District, when less than 25 parking spaces would be required based on parking minimums, the use is exempt from providing any new parking. For uses that exceed this parking exemption, the parking requirements are reduced by 25 spaces and a fee in lieu of required parking may be paid.
Required off-street parking spaces were reduced and required bike parking were passed in 2018.
Off-street parking is not required in the C-1 Business District.

All uses located within the DMX Downtown Mixed-Use, LI Light Industrial, and HI Heavy Industrial districts are exempt from minimum parking requirements. In all districts, on-street parking spaces adjoining the development site may count toward the minimum parking requirement. This provision does not apply for single-family dwellings. Parking maximums exist for most uses.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the Central Business District (CB).

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Parking minimums were reduced in 2021 for a variety of uses. There are also parking maximums city-wide. The city also included bike parking requirements. Parking minimums do not apply to most uses within the transit context (zones D-1, D-3, D-4, G-MU, TSA-C, UI, FB-UN2, FB-UN3, FB-SC, and R-MU)
Parking minimums eliminated for Central Business District.
The Downtown "D" District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Parking minimum requirements were reduced for the Transit-Oriented Development Overlay District, and bicycle parking minimums were introduced. Parking requirements may be further reduced with unbundled parking and in-lieu fees. The development code noted that as the transit system matures, they are looking to reduce or eliminate parking minimums. A 2017 Accessory Dwelling Unit Amendment reduced minimum parking requirements for ADUs, and prohibits minimums in certain qualified locations.

Residential developments within 1/2 mile of a current or planned major transit stop are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Any provided parking in market-rate developments with more than 4 units must be rented or leased separately (unbundled) from the dwelling unit. Commercial uses are exempt from requirements in transit priority areas and commercial neighborhoods citywide.
There are no parking mandates in the city of San Francisco for any use except Mortuary (8 spaces mandated). There are parking maximums for most uses.
The City of San Jose removed parking minimums for all uses citywide. The changes went into effect in March 2023.
No project may exceed 2,500 parking spaces.

Parking requirements are reduced for eating and drinking establishments in the C-N neighborhood-commercial zone and for all uses in the C-D downtown-commercial zone. There is also a pathway to reduced parking in any zone, though approval must be explicitly given.

The City of San Marcos has an implemented parking reform in the Central Business Area (CBD) which exempts all properties in the CBD from parking requirements with the exception of new multifamily development. If there are 5 or fewer multifamily units on the property, the owner can request a Conditional Use Permit at PZ to exempt them from the parking requirements.
In December 2021, parking minimums were replaced with parking maximums citywide.
Parking requirements are eliminated in the downtown core. Parking minimums are reduced by 20% for developments with affordable housing.
There are no parking minimums except for manufactured homes. Parking maximums exist for all uses.
There are no off-street parking requirements for all land uses in the Central Business District (CDB).

Nonresidential uses within the CBD-1 and CBD-2 Districts are exempt from minimum parking requirements. However, any parking existing on November 1, 2007 must be maintained. Residential parking requirements in these districts are reduced.

Parking minimums do not apply to any uses within both the Perimeter Center and City Springs District. Instead, parking maximums apply to those areas. Parking reductions are available through the provision of frequent transit, affordable housing, senior living or a carshare program.
ADUs may be exempted from parking requirements based on five conditions. A change of use may be exempted in certain circumstances.

Parking reductions provided for affordable/senior housing and mixed-use development, the CBD, carsharing and bicycle parking. Small Residential Unit Reduction (July 2013): only 1 space is required per unit 600 sq. feet or less, with no required guest parking. https://www.santabarbaraca.gov/services/planning/mpe/aud_program/default.asp.

No parking is required for any use within one-half mile of a major transit stop. Retail/Flex and Community/Civic uses within the Patrick Henry Specific Plan area are exempt from parking requirements as well as ADUs citywide.
ADUs are exempted from parking requirements when certain criteria are met as required by state law.

The off-street parking requirements may be reduced if the property owner grants the city the right to use a portion of the property for a transit facility. Parking requirements in the BCD District are reduced for residential and commercial uses.
No parking mandates in the Downtown Community Plan Area, maximums for most uses.

In Fall 2020, the Santa Rosa City Council adopted a new Downtown Station Area Specific Plan that revised Downtown parking policy to eliminate minimum parking requirements within the Downtown Station Area boundary. This policy was codified and went into effect on January 1, 2021.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: There are no minimum parking requirements for Subarea 1 of downtown. Mixed-use developments in subareas 2 and 3 have reduced parking requirements. All mixed-use developments in the downtown have parking maximums.

There are no minimum parking requirements anywhere in the Village, including business districts. There are design standards for parking areas that are proposed for all new non-single family dwelling developments.

Accessory dwelling units and accessory nonresidential uses are not required to provide off-street parking in the RTD-9 District. Certain uses in the downtown districts are exempt as well. Numerous reductions are available depending on the district, size of project and other factors.

There are no minimum off-street parking requirements in the Transect-6 district. No use may provide parking quantities greater than 20% over the minimum requirements unless waived by the Planning Board.

Public parking spaces, one-half or more of which are immediately adjacent to a property, may be counted toward satisfaction of the number of parking spaces required. Minimum parking requirements do not apply to a change of use in an existing building.
Within the C-3 Central Business District, no parking and off-street loading areas are required except for motels and hotels.
Saskatoon eliminated parking mandates citywide on July 31, 2024. Previously, no off-street parking was required in the B6 District or for most uses within the CR-1 and CR-2 districts.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided. The fee amount varies by location.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.
The C-1 City Center Commercial, C-2 Water Street Commercial, C- 2 Water Street East, C-1 Water Street North, and C-2 Water Street South districts are exempt from parking mandates.

No on-site parking is required for nonresidential uses in the Central Commercial District, unless specifically imposed as a condition of approval associated with a unique or unusual use or situation, as determined by the Village Board.

Commercial uses under 1,000 square feet in gross floor area in the C-1 district are exempt from parking requirements. Uses under 1,000 square feet in gross floor area located within a shopping center configuration (i.e., a strip mall) are not eligible for this exemption and must provide the required parking.

Within the developed central business area, being the area zoned B-2 on the zoning district map, the provisions of parking spaces for nonresidential uses as required may be reduced by one-half (½) the minimum required spaces.

When a new use commences in an existing building located in the downtown, or the traditional commercial zone (C1), no additional parking is required beyond that already supplied, provided that the building’s gross floor area is not increased.
The B-1 Retail Business district is exempt from parking requirements for all uses.

Within the Downtown Savannah Parking District, the city center is exempt from parking mandates. Additionally, properties on the edge of downtown as well as in the Victorian and Streetcar Parking District have reduced parking requirements. Parking requirements may be reduced citywide through the provision of bicycle or motorcycle parking.
No off-street parking or loading space is required for any use located in the "C-2" Central Commercial District.

For projects involving site plan approvals or site plan amendments, the number of parking spaces provided may not exceed ten percent (10%) of the minimum number of parking spaces required or three (3) plus the number of parking spaces required by this section, whichever is greater, unless otherwise approved by the village board. The maximum parking requirement does not apply to office, residential, or hospital uses. Parking requirements may be reduced with approval through frequent transit, in-lieu fees or transportation demand management.

Schenectady's zoning code does not have a minimum parking requirement for commercial properties in the downtown area. Parking maximums in this area should not exceed 110%-120% of the minimum requirements outside the downtown area.  Shared parking is accepted if an applicant demonstrates that adjacent land uses have different hours of operation.
Parking requirements may be reduced where on-street parking is available. Single-family and two-family dwellings are subject to maximum parking limits in addition to minimum parking requirements.
Off-street parking facilities are not required for lots which are 33 feet or less in width, which are to be improved with a single-family dwelling, and for which there is no alley to the rear.
Land uses within the CBD: Central business district are exempt from parking requirements. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
Any use within the CBD Central Business District is exempt from the off-street parking requirements.
The C-1 District is exempt from parking mandates.

Within the Main Street Business District, the first 500 square feet of a commercial use is exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements for all uses in the district may be reduced through on-street parking or bike parking.
Parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums.
Parking maximums apply to commercial and public/semi-public uses.
The portion of the C-1 District bounded by Grant Street, Mulberry Street, Broadway Street, and Market Street is exempt from parking mandates.
No off-street parking spaces are required for dwelling units or residential uses in the Central Business District (C-1) District.

Parking requirements are reduced in the downtown area. On-street parking may count towards parking minimums outside the downtown area. Within the Downtown Overlay District (DO) and the Downtown District (D), a fee in-lieu of required parking may be provided.
The D – City Downtown Mixed Use District is exempt from off-street parking requirements.
Seabrook, NH has no minimum parking requirements and has parking maximums in commercial and industrial districts. Planning Board has have discretion of uses not specifically specified in the code.
The C-1 Downtown Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special,transit oriented
summary:
Parking is currently not required for any non-hospital uses in designated Urban Centers and Station Overlay Areas, plus any properties within 1/4 mile of a frequent transit stop that lie inside Urban Village boundaries.

For commercial and multifamily residential zones outside of Urban Villages, parking requirements are reduced by 50% within 1/4 mile of frequent transit stops.

Map: https://www.seattle.gov/Documents/Departments/OPCD/Vault/RegulatoryReform/ParkingFlexibilityAreasMap.pdf. Dark and light grey areas have no parking requirements (except for hospitals), and yellow areas have 50% parking reductions.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: In commercial and industrial districts, parking requirements are reduced for mixed-uses and public parking may count towards requirements.
All uses in the C-2 general business district, except for one-family or two-family dwellings, are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Off-street parking is not required in the "C-l" Central Business District for existing structures. Any new structures must have at least one (1) parking spot for each five hundred (500) square feet or fraction thereof of floor space.
The Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Within the BC Borough Core District, a change of use in an existing building is exempt from parking mandates and a fee in lieu of required parking may be provided.
Commercial uses are exempt from parking mandates.

The downtown area of the C-3 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates. This area is defined as west of the railroad tracks, south of College Street, east of Ward Street, north of Tate Street, and east of Highway 51 on Main Street.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The downtown parking zone (DPZ) approximates an area that historically has been the village's downtown and also includes the area around village hall. Small residential and business land uses within the DPZ are exempt from the minimum parking requirements of this section. However, if a commercial land use has a gross floor area of five thousand (5,000) square feet or more, then the standards apply. If parking is required of a particular use in the DPZ, all on-street parking spaces within one hundred fifty feet (150') and any parking spaces within municipal parking lots within three hundred feet (300') may count towards the required number of off street parking spaces. Commercial establishments within the DPZ may not provide a number of off street parking spaces that is greater than one hundred percent (100%) of the parking requirement for that particular establishment's land use.
The C-1 Downtown Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the BGC Central General Business District.

The B-2 Primary Business District is exempt from parking mandates. All uses except multi-family dwellings are exempt in the B-1 Secondary Business District, although public parking may be used to satisfy requirements.
Within the Town Core and Multi-Use Development Nodes, parking requirements are reduced and on-street parking may count towards the minimums.
Businesses in the CB Central Business and HC Harbor Commercial Districts are exempt from parking mandates.
Any use within the CBD Downtown Seward District is exempt from off-street parking requirements.
Nonresidential uses less than 12,000 square feet in the OMU Ohio River Boulevard Mixed Use District are exempt from parking mandates.
Off-street parking is not required in the B-1 Central Business District.

Some or all of the requirements for off-street parking spaces may be met by the provision of on-street spaces. In commercial districts or office districts all business uses in structures erected prior to the date of the Zoning Ordinance are exempt from the parking requirements. 
When the application of off-street parking regulations results in a requirement of three (3) or fewer spaces on a single zoning lot in a business district, such off-street parking spaces need not be provided. This exemption does not apply to dwelling units.
The Central Business (B-3) Zone is exempt from off-street parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Nonresidential uses in the C-1 and C-1A Downtown Commercial Districts are exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements may be reduced through bike parking, transit proximity or counting on-street parking. Parking maximums range from 120% to 135% of the minimums depending on parking lot size.
The B-1 central business district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

No application may propose more than twenty-five percent (25%) of the spaces required unless good cause can be shown by the applicant and approved by the BZA through the variance process. Single-family dwellings and two-family dwellings are exempt from this provision.
The H Hamlet District is exempt from parking mandates.
The DMU Downtown Mixed Use District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

The DT-C Downtown Core District is exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements are reduced by 50% in the MU Mixed-Use District, the DT-E Downtown Edge and DT-T Downtown Transition District. Parking requirements may be reduced citywide through on-street parking, public parking, structured parking, infill development, increased landscaping, pervious paving, EV chargers. Prior to 2024, the C-4 central business district was exempted.
The Central Commercial (CC) District and the Central Parking Waiver Area (defined by Jefferson Avenue to Ontario Avenue and 7th to 9th Streets) are both exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums except for single-family and two-family dwellings.

Parking Space Requirements do not apply in a block where 50% or more of the area was occupied by business or industrial structures prior to these regulations unless the area is cleared and new structures erected.
Uses in the Town Center Zoning District are exempt from off-street parking requirements.
In the C-2 General Business District, on-street and public parking may count towards minimums. Citywide, bike parking may substitute for car parking.
No off street parking and loading spaces are required in the Central Business District.
The B-2 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Business uses are exempt from parking mandates in a block where 50 percent or more of the area was occupied by business or industrial structures prior to the adoption of the zoning code.
Maximum parking requirements apply to nonresidential uses.
All commercial uses located within the Business Commercial (BC) District are exempt from off-street parking requirements.
The C-1 Central Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for first floor residential uses.
Establishments in any business or industrial districts which have paid an assessment for the provision of off-street city parking lots are exempt from off-street parking requirements.
No off-street parking is required in most areas of the Downtown.
In the B-1 and B-2 business districts, parking requirements are reduced, and on-street parking may be used to satisfy the remaining requirements.
Single-family dwellings are exempt from parking mandates.
Minimum parking requirements are not applicable to property in the CB Central Business District, except for residential uses which are authorized by a conditional use permit.
Uses within the C-4 Office District may pay a fee-in-lieu of providing the additional parking spaces necessary to satisfy the parking requirements.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Commercial uses in the Neighborhood Commercial (N-C) District are exempt from off-street parking mandates.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The Downtown District is exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums apply to all other districts. Parking reductions are available for uses near transit or which meet other criteria.

Parking requirements may be reduced through transit service or transportation demand management, however, proof that the otherwise required parking could be provided must be submitted. Parking maximums are set at the minimum requirements.

The total number of accessory parking spaces provided for single-family, two-family or multiple-family dwellings may not exceed the requirements by more than fifty percent (50%) or four (4) spaces, whichever is greater.
Shorewood, WI reduced parking minimums on new construction to 1:1 - Smart Code standard.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
The D-1 District and the use "neighborhood commercial establishment" are exempt from all parking requirements. Lots of 5,000 square feet or less in lot area in the R-UC District, and non-residential uses of 2,500 square feet or less in the C-1, C-UC, and I-MU Districts are exempt from parking requirements. Existing non-residential structures that are 60 years of age or older as of the effective date of the Code that currently do not provide the required amount of parking on the lot to accommodate parking are exempt from parking requirements regardless of any change in use or intensity of use.
Parking requirements may be reduced through motorcycle parking or bikeshare facilities. Parking maximums are set at 115% of the minimums for nonresidential uses excluding restaurants over 15,000 square feet.
The C-2 Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
On-street parking may be used to satisfy a portion of the off street parking requirements.
In the C-1 Central Business District Zone, off-street parking spaces are required only for residences, hotels and motels.
Property abutting a public right-of-way with adjacent on-street parking or within 1,000 feet of a public parking facility is not required to provide off-street parking.
Parking requirements may be reduced through bike parking, carpool parking, extra ADA accessible parking, or on-street parking.
Off-street parking requirements are not applicable to land development in the downtown parking district.
Buildings in the Silver City Historic District are not required to provide off-street parking. Bicycle parking may substitute for vehicle parking in other districts.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to allowed uses in the B-1 Central Business District.

Parking requirements are reduced for uses in the Town Core and may be further reduced through on-street parking or a fee in lieu of required parking. Parking requirements may be reduced for bike parking citywide and for commercial or educational uses near transit.
ADUs may be exempted from parking mandates when certain criteria are met.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Zone 4 is exempt from parking mandates while requirements vary across zones 1-3 which are based on location and transit availability. Parking maximums apply to most uses.
Parking requirements are reduced for residential and office uses in the D-1 Downtown District.
The MU - Downtown Mixed-Use District is exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for residential uses.
The Downtown Commercial (DC), Historic Area - 4th Street (HA-4), and Historic Area - Pearl Street (HA-P) districts are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Minimum parking requirements may be reduced for mixed use projects, for encouraging transit use, or for providing bike parking.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

In the B-1, B-2 and B-3 districts, the number of parking spaces required by this section is reduced by a credit of three spaces. In the B-3 district, the number of residential parking spaces required by this section is reduced by a credit of one space. A fee-in-lieu of required parking may be paid in any district. Formerly, the B-3 District was exempt for a period of four years.

Multifamily dwellings with 3 or more units and upper story residences as part of mixed-use developments have reduced parking requirements in the B3 Business District, NX Neighborhood Mixed-Use District, TX Transit Mixed-Use District, and CX Core Mixed-Use District.
Parking requirements for nonresidential uses in the B6 Downtown Science and Technology district are reduced by 15% from the otherwise required number. Within the B4 Regional Shopping district, parking requirements may be reduced if a transit station serving at least 4 routes exists on-site.
Reduced parking requirements apply in the CX Core Mixed-Use District. However, no parking is required for existing structures or buildings in the district. No parking is required for new construction and building additions for consumer goods, food establishments, health and personal care, professional offices, and food services uses when the total gross floor area after the addition is less than 8,000 square feet.
Within a the NX, TX and CX districts, a fee-in-lieu of required parking may be made for nonresidential uses and guest parking for residential uses.
No parking is required for commercial uses in the B-2 Central Business District, which are less than 12,000 square feet in area.
The C-3 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
A fee in lieu of parking may be provided for all uses.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the Central Business District (CB).
The C-1 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
On-street parking may count towards parking requirements within the Putnam Pike/Esmond Street Planned Development District.
Commercial uses within the TC Town Center District are exempt from parking mandates.
No off-street parking or loading spaces are required in the B-2 Uptown Business District.
No off-street parking or loading space is required for any use located in the "B-4" Central Business District.
There is no minimum number of required off-street parking spaces in the central commercial (CC) district, irrespective of the use of the property.

Nonresidential establishments under 3,000 square feet in floor area, except restaurants, are not required to provide vehicle parking unless located on a lot that contains another use or establishment. Passenger terminals are also exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The B-1 Downtown Shopping District is exempt from parking mandates.
A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided citywide. Parking maximums apply to multi-family, mixed-use and commercial districts.
Nonresidential uses in the C-2 Central Commercial District are exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements are reduced for large mixed-use projects.
The C-1 Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Within the Downtown Special Parking Overlay District, all development and changes in use are exempt from off-street parking requirements.

There are no minimum requirements for residential uses within 0.5 miles of an MBTA T station. Every commercial use within 0.25 miles of an MBTA T station has a parking maximum. The radius and parking maximum ratios change based on the location/land use.

Nonresidential uses in the B-1 District have reduced parking requirements. Cash in lieu of parking may be provided in the district. Citywide, on-street parking allows for reduced parking requirements.
Restaurants, retail and office uses in the C-3 Commercial-Downtown Core District have reduced parking requirements. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
There are no off-street parking spaces mandated for any uses in South Bend, IN.

South Burlington has no minimum vehicle parking requirements city-wide, except in the case of requirements for multi-family residential use (0.75-1.5 spaces per dwelling unit depending on number of bedrooms).
The C-8 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking Requirements are reduced in the TCR Town Center Redevelopment Zoning District.
On-street parking may count towards parking requirements citywide. Parking requirements in the C-1 Neighborhood Commercial District are reduced by 50%.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The minimum parking requirements do not apply to non-residential uses in the VC Village Center District. In all districts, parking requirements may be reduced through proximity to a bus stop, proximity to a municipal parking lot, the payment of a fee-in-lieu, or the provision of EV charging stations, carshare parking or bike parking. No use may provide parking spaces in excess of 125% of the required minimum parking amount except for residential uses in residential districts or where the required parking is less than 10 spaces.
Parking maximums apply to all uses but may be exceeded through increased landscaping or pervious paving.
The Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Within the CD - Commercial Downtown District, parking requirements are reduced by fifty percent.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
No off-street parking is required in the C-3 Central Business Zone.
The B-1a Business and Commercial District and the R-1 Single-Family Dwelling District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Within the Centre Zone, parking maximums apply to residential uses.
On-street parking spaces may be counted towards the minimum parking requirement. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.

Permitted uses in all commercial and mixed-use zoning districts are exempt from minimum parking requirements if they are going into a new construction commercial space that is up to 7,500 in size or an existing commercial space that is up to 15,000 square feet in size. For larger permitted uses, industrial uses, uses that require a conditional use permit, and institutional uses that are located in residential zoning districts, the property owner can submit a parking and circulation plan to the Planning Commission and City Council for review. The City Council can waive some or all of the use's "default" parking requirement if the property owner can demonstrate that they can partially or fully serve their building's transportation needs with nearby on-street parking, shared parking, bicycle parking, transit, pedestrian connectivity, etc.
Those properties within the downtown area as designated on the map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Single-family and two-family dwellings are exempt from parking mandates.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
Public parking may be counted towards parking requirements where a lot has insufficient space to provide parking.

Minimum off street parking requirements do not apply to any uses of any buildings or structures of any existing main building or structure which is enlarged or increased in capacity located in the B-1 Central Business District.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums for parking lots with 50 or more spaces.
No off-street parking is required in the B-1 downtown business district, except for dwelling units located above the ground floor existing prior to the update to the ordinance.
For commercial uses, excluding new and used vehicle sales, minimum amounts of off-street parking facilities may be exceeded by only twenty (20) percent.
The CBD Zoning District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Allowed uses in the B-1 Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The (C-1) General Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Maximum parking limits apply citywide. On July 17, 2023, Spokane passed an interim zoning ordinance which removed parking minimums for housing located within 1/2 mile walking distance of transit stops. All uses citywide, except those in the CA-4 District, were exempted from parking mandates on August 12, 2024.

Commercial, professional, or office uses in the DC Downtown Commercial District may count on-street parking towards parking requirements. Parking requirements may be reduced for shared parking citywide.
The B-1 Village Retail Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Nonresidential uses in the C and CBD districts may count on-street and public parking towards parking minimums.
Off-street parking regulations are not applicable to commercial establishments located as of November 20, 1984, on Spring Street.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the official map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 150% of the minimums. Parking requirements may be reduced through bike parking, or the availability of on-street parking.
Within the C-3 Downtown District, a first floor less than 3,000 sq feet is exempt from parking minimums. A change of use in existing buildings is also exempt.
Developments may provide the required number of spaces or up to 10 percent less as of right.
The S-3 central shopping district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The Central Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No off-street parking is required within the Business C District for non-residential uses.
All business uses in the C-1 Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The CC Center City District, the GI Government and Institutional Use District, and the COM-1 Commercial Street District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The UPOD Unified Plan Overlay District is exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements may be reduced through improved stormwater management.
On November 20, 2023 Springfield removed all minimum parking requirements, citywide. Parking maximums apply to most uses.

The required off-street parking for a particular use may be reduced by its proportionate share of any publicly-owned parking lot within three hundred (300) feet of street travel, or for which it has been assessed.
The BC Business Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to the B-3 Community Business District.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply to existing MU-BR Mixed Use - Business Residential District uses as long as the general use and purpose for which the property is used is continued.
The Downtown Parking Exemption (2013) exempts downtown developments from car parking mandates.

All uses allowed in the CBD-1 and CBD-2 Districts, except for Public Service Facilities, Motor Vehicle Rental, and Drive-through Facilities are exempt from the requirement to provide off-street parking spaces, if the lot is located within a Special Service Area and a public parking facility is located nearby. When parking is required, on-street parking spaces located within three hundred (300) feet of the use may be credited to meet up to twenty-five percent (25%) of the requirement for off-street parking for non-residential uses.
Uses fronting on S. Saginaw Street between M-52 and Hosmer Street are exempt from parking mandates. Parking reductions are available for mixed-uses, and other conditions.

A covered bike rack providing a minimum of five bike parking spaces may be used in lieu of one vehicle parking space. Only one such reduction may be utilized per project. Each designated carpool space counts as two required standard parking spaces. The number of carpool parking spaces may not exceed ten percent of the total required parking spaces on a property.
Within the C-2 Commercial District, parking mandates may be waived if certain conditions are met.
The C-4 Central Business Zoning district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

In any commercial or industrial district, an establishment that has paid a special assessment for the provision of off-street City parking is exempt from providing the required off-street parking. The “Central Business District,” as defined in this Code, is exempt from providing off-street parking, so long as municipal off-street parking is provided to serve the area.
The general commercial district (B-1) is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums for surface parking lots are set at 125% of the minimums.
Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums for surface parking.
No off-street parking is required in the central business district (CBD).
No off street parking is required in the B-3 General Business District.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums, but may be exceeded with permeable paving.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
Elimination of parking minimums city-wide: 
The city of St. John's eliminated minimum off-street parking requirements for the following three commercial land uses (if the gross floor area is 200 m2 or less): Restaurant, Retail, and Service Shop.

Elimination of parking minimums in select downtown areas:
The city of St. John's eliminated minimum off-street parking requirements for residential developments on Water Street or Duckworth Street having 5 Dwelling Units or less. Additionally, for all new change of use applications from non-residential to another non-residential use in the downtown parking area (where the floor area remains constant), the applicant will be exempt from all the minimum and maximum parking requirements in parking ratio table Section 8.3. 

Implementation of parking maximums city-wide:
The city of St. John's also has maximum off-street parking requirements for all land uses. 

Reduction of parking requirements in select downtown areas:
On May 27th 2022, the city of St. John's reduced minimum and maximum parking requirements by 50 percent for new non-residential developments in the downtown parking area.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements except for dwelling units permitted in conjunction with business uses.
The CBD Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Parking maximums are set at 150% of the minimums.
The U: university district is exempt from parking mandates.
Within the D Downtown District, only lodging/accommodation uses and residential uses require parking. Parking requirements for residential uses are reduced.
The C-2 Downtown Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Parking requirements may be reduced through the availability of frequent transit service, on-street parking or a travel demand management plan. Parking maximums exist for all uses in the MX-2 Neighborhood Mixed Use District and for shopping centers and retail stores in all districts.
Mixed-use development has reduced parking requirements.

Implemented in Downtown District: No Minimum Parking Requirement in Downtown St. Louis: In roughly 4 square miles in and around downtown St. Louis, St. Louis has never had a minimum parking requirement. This was most recently codified by the 1947 zoning code. The "I" Central Business District, "No parking regulations shall be required for this district". All land uses.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: The Downtown District is exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums apply to all uses except those in the Downtown District. Parking requirements may be reduced through proximity to transit and other criteria.
All business uses located within the B-2 Central Business District are exempt from off-street parking requirements.
Within the CC, MC, SLC, and HR Districts, a fee in lieu of parking may be provided.
Uses within the B-1 district are exempt from minimum parking requirements with the exception of residential uses in commercial buildings.

There are no requirements for a minimum number of parking spaces. Parking maximums apply to surface lots exceeding 15 spaces. 

Facilities that exceed 15 spaces shall not be created unless a demonstration of need. 

Projects exceeding 40,000 square feet are required to submit a TDM Plan (TDMP) for City Review. 

There are minimum bike parking requirements for all land uses.

Uses in the B-1 Central Business District are exempt from off-street parking requirements, except for those permitted or conditional uses that involve large assemblies or overnight parking, such as churches, motels, hotels, auditoriums, and residential uses.

Non-residential properties located in walkable areas are entitled to a 10% reduction to the total required off-street parking. Walkable areas must abut either Gulf Boulevard from 35th Avenue to 75th Avenue or Blind Pass Road from 75th Avenue to 81st Avenue.
The C-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

In 2022. St. Petersburg eliminated minimum parking requirements for residential housing units in the downtown core that have 750 square feet or less.

They also reduced minimum parking requirements by 10% for affordable housing units, ADUs, and other properties located within 660 feet of a high-frequency transit route.
Adjacent on-street parking may apply toward parking requirements in the TND-1 and TND-2 Traditional Neighborhood Development districts.

On-street parking may be counted toward the parking requirements for residential uses. Minimum required parking may be reduced where fully enclosed bicycle lockers are provided on a one-for-one exchange ratio, except for single family detached dwellings. Parking maximums exist for most uses.
In the Town Center (TC) District, existing buildings that were legally constructed as of January 1, 2016 without on-site parking are considered conforming. Such buildings are eligible for change of use permits, and for building up-fits. A fee-in-lieu of parking may be paid in order to reduce parking requirements.
Parking requirements may be reduced through a carshare program. Residential parking requirements are reduced within and near to the city center.
In the Central Business (CB) zoning district only, on-street parking directly in front of the lot may count toward fulfillment of the parking requirement for that lot.
No parking spaces are required for business or industrial uses. Residences within the Business District must provide parking however.
Off-street parking is not required in the Central Business District.
On-street parking may count towards the minimums in the C-1 Central Business District. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums citywide.
In the C-2 General Retail District, parking is only required for residential uses, kindergartens, and commercial amusements.
Areas which are located within a fire district as designated on the official map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Commercial buildings in the Commercial/Community Facilities Zone may count on-street parking towards 25% of the minimum requirements.
Establishments in any business or industrial district which have paid an assessment for the provision of off-street City parking lots may be exempted from off-street parking requirements.

A ten percent (10%) reduction in the number of required parking spaces is allowed for commercial uses with a main entrance within a walking distance of thirteen hundred and twenty (1,320) feet of an operating transit stop. This reduction does not apply to form-based districts. Within a commercial use district, form-based district, or multiple dwelling unit districts, the overall parking space requirements can be reduced by two spaces if bicycle parking is provided.
The C-1 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Within the C General Commercial District and the CID Commercial Incentive District, the first 30,000 square feet of a nonresidential use, or a theatre with nearby public parking are exempt from parking mandates. Cafes or restaurants within the UV Urban Village District may be exempted upon certain conditions. Citywide, parking requirements for housing for the elderly may be reduced when located near transit, public parking or under other conditions.
Nonresidential uses are exempt from off-street parking requirements in the Central Business District.
The "C-2" Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking minimums may be reduced through the removal of existing curb cuts, proximity to transit, or the payment of a fee in-lieu of parking.

The total number of accessory parking spaces provided for one-family, two-family or multiple-family dwellings or hotels shall not exceed the requirement for such use or for any equivalent new use by more than 50 percent or four spaces, whichever number is greater.
Existing central business districts of municipalities are exempt from off-street parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Parking is not required for non-residential uses in the DB, downtown business district. Parking requirements for nonresidential uses may be reduced through the provision of bike parking. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.
No parking is required in the B-2 Central Business District except for dwelling units constructed in conjunction with business uses.

In the C-1 Highway Commercial District and C-2 Downtown Commercial District, on-street parking within 400 feet of the use may be included in the total required off-street parking, except for multiple-family dwellings or apartments.
The "B-1" Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.

No parking minimums in the Central Business District. Parking reductions based on transit availability, provision of structured parking, car-sharing, and tree preservation. Parking cannot exceed 150% of required parking (unless its on a pervious surface or underground).

In the C-2 District, on-street or off-street public parking spaces may be counted toward the minimum parking requirement. For buildings and uses with 20 or more off-street parking spaces, bike parking may substitute for car parking citywide.

For new uses of less than 2,000 net square feet in the C-1 Commercial District and for new uses of less than 1,000 net square feet in the C-2 Limited Commercial District, there is no off-street parking requirement.
For all existing and new permitted commercial uses located in the B-1 Central Business District as identified by the Official Zoning Map, no off-street parking is required.

Existing buildings in the CB Commercial Business District are exempt from parking mandates where public parking is available within 1,320 feet, while new buildings have reduced requirements. Parking requirements may be reduced citywide for mixed-use developments, motorcycle parking or proximity to transit.

Within the City Centre and Mirrabooka Town Centre, parking maximums apply to nonresidential uses. Parking requirements may be reduced through motorcycle parking or a fee in lieu of parking. Nonresidential citywide parking reductions are available for transit, bike facilities, historic sites, a fee in lieu of parking, proximity to a shared-use path, or when located within a Regional Centre, District Centre or Neighbourhood Centre.
The CBD central business district is exempt from providing off-street parking.

There is no minimum parking requirement for uses within one-quarter mile from the Altamont Commuter Express (ACE) Robert J. Cabral Train Station or a proposed California High-Speed Rail station. Residential uses in the Downtown Core have a reduced parking requirement as well as all uses in the Magnolia Historic Overlay District. Properties within the Parking Improvement District No. 2001-1, bounded by Park Street on the north, Mormon Slough on the west, Sonora Street on the south, and the Union Pacific Railroad tracks on the east are exempt if the property pays into the district. Parking requirements citywide may be reduced through bike parking, carpool spaces, EV chargers, frequent transit, small infill projects or motorcycle parking.

The Downtown Pawcatuck Parking Overlay District eliminates the need for off-street parking for existing commercial buildings/uses. This enables change of use. There are also some parking maximums for certain uses townwide and bicycle parking required for certain uses. The Commission may allow shared / reduced parking when appropriate.
Any use within the CBD Central Business District is exempt from off-street parking requirements.
In the C-2 Central Business District, no off-street parking is required for non-residential uses. Each dwelling unit above a store or shop requires two off-street parking spaces
Parking mandates were repealed in February 2006. Parking maximums apply to all uses except single-family dwellings.
Minimum parking requirements do not apply within the (CB) Central Business District.
The B-1 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C1 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-2 Central Business Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates.

There are no parking requirements in the Old Downtown District. 

Certain properties adjacent to the Old Downtown District are exempt from parking requirements if a specified number of spaces is maintained. 

On-street parking may be used to offset the required number of parking spaces. Historic buildings may receive a 50% reduction to the minimum parking requirement. 

There is a payment in lieu of parking options for up to three parking spaces required for any use in the Stuart Community Redevelopment Area.
No off-street parking is required in the BC Central Business Commercial District or the DBC Downtown Business Commercial District.

In the central business district (C-2) the required off-street parking spaces only apply to property located south of Redwood Street and to all residential and lodging uses (hotels, boardinghouses, etc.). For uses that are required to provide off-street parking spaces, a per space fee may be paid in lieu of providing the parking spaces.

Parking requirements are reduced in the community parking district which encompasses the downtown area. Uses in the B-N Business Neighborhood District that are not covered by the community parking district may count on-street parking towards parking minimums.
A portion of the General Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements. An exact map of the area is on file at the City of Sturgis Finance Office.
Nonresidential uses in the city center are exempted from parking mandates since January 2023. Parking reductions are available citywide for uses near transit.

Parking requirements are reduced for uses within the Centre Zone, Activity Zone and residential uses near transit. Multiple dwellings within areas coded R40 or greater may substitute bike parking or motorcycle parking for car parking. Parking maximums apply to most uses within areas identified as Activity Centres and for multiple dwellings within areas coded R40 or greater near transit.
No off-street parking facilities are required in the C-3 Central Business District.
Reduce minimum parking requirements in zoning in R2-3 and C5 Zones to 1 parking space per dwelling unit.
No parking spaces are required for commercial uses in the C-2B Central Business District.
Uses with on-street public parking spaces located contiguous to the property may count those towards the required parking space count.
Parking maximums exist for most uses.
The B-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The B-1 General Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
For commercial uses, excluding new and used vehicle sales, maximum parking limits are set at 20% above the minimum requirements.

For nonresidential uses, schools and assembly uses must provide off street parking space. However, there is no minimum off-street motor vehicle parking requirement for other nonresidential uses, although uses requiring special use approval may be required to provide parking for approval.

No on-site parking is required for nonresidential uses in the CC Central Commercial District, unless specifically imposed as a condition of approval associated with a unique or unusual use or situation, as determined by the city council.
The CB Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates, except for residential and lodging uses.
The Central Business District is exempted from off-street parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: A development project located within one-half mile of a major transit stop is not required to comply with minimum parking requirements except for event centers and hotels.
