Citywide, nonresidential uses may have reduced requirements when showers/lockers are provided and parking maximums apply to most uses. ADUs are exempt from parking mandates.
The maximum amount of off-street parking permitted for any use may not exceed 130% of the minimum parking requirements.
Abolished parking minimums in commercial & industrial districts
The C-2 central business district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Multi-family, mixed use, and non-residential uses may count on-street parking towards parking requirements. All uses may pay a fee in-lieu of required parking.

Parking Minimums were reduced by 20% for all land uses in the City Centre, other than office and multi-family residential with underground parking, which received their own rates. Offices were reduced by 44% of the city-wide standard. Multi-family residential with underground parking was reduced to by 38% of the city-wide standard. Former parking minimums are now parking maximums in the City Centre.
Nonresidential uses in the C-N Neighborhood Commercial and C-CBD Central Business Commercial districts are exempt from parking mandates.
Parking maximums exist for most uses.
Permitted uses in the C-1 General Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Within the TC Town Center District, parking requirements are reduced for multi-family uses and mixed-use developments.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of minimums citywide.

Commercial uses in the CBD Central Business District and NMU Neighborhood Mixed Use districts are exempt from parking mandates when the use has adjacent on-street parking, or when public parking is reasonably available to the site. On-street parking in the  CFDD Carrie Furnace Development District may count towards parking requirements.

Off-street parking facilities are not required in a block frontage contained in a GB or I-2 District in which the ground floor area of business or industrial structures, including their accessory buildings, existing at the time of passage of the unified zoning ordinance of the county on September 8, 1994, equaled 50% or more of the entire area of the block frontage.

The regulations do not apply to any uses of new buildings or structures, or existing principal buildings or structures, which are enlarged or increased in capacity and are zoned commercial or manufacturing when located within the Downtown District as defined by Article 1.3.3, to include the area bounded by the following streets including the properties with frontage on said streets as described herein:

Start at High Street and DeKalb Avenue and proceed east on High Street, including the properties fronting on the south side of High Street, to Locust Street; then north on Locust Street, including properties fronting on the east side of Locust Street, to Exchange Street; then west on Exchange Street, including properties fronting the north side of Exchange Street, to Sacramento Street, then south on Sacramento Street, including properties fronting the west side of Sacramento Street, to DeKalb Avenue; then southwesterly to the point of beginning.

This exemption does not apply to residential units.
A fee in lieu of parking may be provided in the Downtown Business District.
Off-street parking spaces are not required for any uses in the central business district.
Off-street parking requirements do not apply to the C-2 Downtown Commercial District.
Currently zoned multiple variations of the Central Business District have no required parking minimums.
The City of São Paulo eliminated parking mandates citywide for all land-uses in 2014. This was part of the strategic master plan of July 31, 2014.

The City of Tacoma has a "Reduced Parking area" that encompasses most of the downtown core area, and effectively requires zero parking. Also all of the mixed use centers (which makes up the majority of all the new development in town) has low/no required parking. There are still parking requirements, but they have been greatly reduced and there is support at the policy level to expand the reduced parking area. As of early 2024, the Tacoma Planning Commission has proposed a significant expansion of the Reduced Parking Area along three transit corridors as part of the "Home in Tacoma" initiative.
Off street parking is not required in the DMX Downtown Mixed-Use District.
Uses within the historic preservation overlay area, UP-1 and UP-2, SCD special character and ASN-A infill/low intensity district are exempt.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums. Parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking or proximity to transit.

Within the CBD Central Business District, and the CD Channel District, parking requirements are reduced by right. Mandates may be further reduced through the provision of motorcycle parking, bike parking or carshare in both districts. In the CBD, a fee in lieu of parking may be paid. Surface parking is banned within the Waterfront Overlay.
B-1 Retail Business Districts are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Existing buildings located in the Downtown Business District are exempt from parking requirements.
Uses located in historically designated structures are exempt from parking mandates.
Parking requirements are reduced where two adjacent businesses develop a shared driveway and parking lot layout.
In parking lots with twenty-five (25) or more parking spaces, bicycle parking spaces may be substituted for automobile parking spaces.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of carshare, EV chargers, bike parking, or on-street parking.
Within the MT-1 and MT-2 Midtown Districts, on-street parking may count towards meeting parking minimums. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums citywide.
The C-2 Community Commercial/CBD District is exempt from parking mandates.
On November 9, 2023 the city of Taylor adopted the Taylor Made Land Development Code which eliminated parking mandates citywide for all uses.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
There are no minimum requirements within the nine (9) square block area bordered by Walnut Street on the east, Vine Street on the north, Webster Street on the west and Franklin Street on the south.

When the application of the off-street parking regulations results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single lot in the commercial districts, such parking spaces need not be provided, unless two or more uses are located on such lot in which case only one of the uses may be eligible for the exemption.

Within the B-2 Downtown District, parking requirements are reduced and a fee in lieu of required parking may be provided. Parking maximums are set at 130% of the minimums, except for single-family and two-family dwellings.
The Downtown Commercial District is exempt from off-street parking regulations.
The C-1 General Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking requirements do not apply in the C-1 district.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Residential uses in Tel Aviv are exempt from parking mandates and instead have parking maximums. Office uses have reduced parking mandates when located near a light rail station. Nonresidential uses in the CA, Central Area district, are exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements are reduced for residential uses in the C, Commercial, CA, Central Area and MU, Mixed Use districts.
Nonresidential uses in the C-2 Central Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Off-street parking is not required in the C-8 Downtown Business District or C-9 Pedestrian Core Area.

On-street parking may count towards parking minimums for nonresidential and multifamily dwelling uses. Parking maximums apply to all nonresidential uses.
Areas which are located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Central business district uses are exempt from minimum parking requirements. However, existing parking in the CBD must be maintained. A change of use in existing buildings citywide is also exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Minimum parking requirements do not apply to any use that is located in the downtown area bounded by Canal Boulevard from LA Hwy. 1 to West 5th Street and Jackson Street from West 5th Street to LA Hwy. 1.

In the Central Business District and the Downtown Fringe District, off-street parking requirements may be satisfied if the commercial use is included within a Parking Assessment District (PAD) and has been assessed pursuant to that PAD.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
Allowed uses in the CD Downtown Commercial District are exempt from providing off-street parking spaces. Within the PO Pedestrian-Oriented Overlay District, non-residential uses are exempt from providing off-street parking spaces. No off-street parking spaces are required for residential building projects of 10 units or less, for larger residential buildings, parking requirements are reduced. Within the Central-City Special Parking District, the minimum off-street parking requirement for multi-dwelling units is reduced. Within locally designated historic districts, no off-street parking or loading spaces are required for rehabilitation or reuse of existing structures. For new construction within locally designated historic districts, minimum off-street parking ratios are reduced by 50 percent.
No use may provide more than 150 percent of the minimum off-street parking, except through approval of an Alternative Parking Plan. Within the Pedestrian-Oriented Overlay, parking maximums are set at 100% of the minimums. Surface parking lots are prohibited in the Downtown Core District and Warehouse District.

Non-residential uses located in the CB Central Business Commercial District are not required to provide off-street spaces while theaters and churches may reduce or omit parking provided that such uses are within 600 feet of a parking lot serving a business or industrial use.

Uses in the central business district are exempt from minimum parking requirements. The central business district is defined as the uses and properties fronting along Tomahawk Avenue from Southgate Drive to Somo Avenue, along Wisconsin Avenue from Railway Street to North 4th Street and along North 4th Street from Wisconsin Avenue to River Street.
The C-3 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
(a) No off-street parking requirements for the D-1, D-3 use districts.
A change of use in an existing building within the C-1 Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates.
On December 15, 2021 Toronto repealed car parking mandates citywide for all uses.
ADUs may be exempted from parking mandates when certain criteria are met.

Whenever off-street parking spaces are to be provided in accordance with the parking requirements, the property owner or developer may instead have the option to pay a fee to the city in lieu of the required off-street parking.

Areas which are located in a fire district as designated on the Official Map are exempt from parking mandates.

The total number of accessory parking spaces provided for a single-family, two-family or multi-family dwelling may not exceed the minimums by more than 50 percent or four spaces, whichever is greater.

Parking mandates only apply to uses in the Houlton Town Center Mixed Use, Rural Mixed Use, and Business Park business districts.

No car parking for any uses is required in the C-4 (Regional Center) District and the Grand Traverse Commons District. Properties located within 500 feet from the public transit center or parking decks have no parking minimums. This City also requires bicycle parking.

No off-street parking is required in the HP - Corazon de Trinidad Historic Preservation District.  In all other districts, both minimum and maximum parking standards are enforced.

Tualatin repealed their parking mandates on June 10, 2024 to comply with state law. Parking maximums apply to certain uses downtown and along transit corridors and large surface parking lots citywide.

Within the Downtown Parking District, parking requirements are reduced by right, a change of use is exempt from parking requirements, and the provision of public amenities or the payment of a fee in lieu of parking will reduce requirements further. 
Citywide, on-street parking may be counted towards certain residential uses, and nonresidential NRHP listings may be exempted. Additional reductions to parking requirements are possible through the provision of EV chargers, additional handicapped parking, bike parking, additional landscaping, or providing trash enclosures.

Tulsa Oklahoma has no parking minimums downtown for all uses.  In the CH District and MX District and surrounding areas downtown, parking minimums are reduced 50% compared to other districts.  Retail uses requiring more than two hundred twenty-five (225) parking spaces may not provide more than four (4) outdoor parking spaces per one thousand (1,000) square feet of floor area.
Restaurant and retail uses have maximum parking limits.
The area located within the fire zone as designated on the Official Map is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Implemented: There are no parking minimums in the Central Business District (BC) and Institutional Districts.

Proposed: No parking minimum in additional zoning code districts (D, DP, DHE, R, IU, and IP) with proposed parking maximum in D, DP, DHE, and R districts.
Stores and other retail establishments are exempt in the B-3, Central Business District. On-street or public parking may reduce requirements for multi-family dwellings and places of public assembly.
Parking maximums apply to residential uses.
In the Downtown P1 District, no parking is mandated. In the P2 district, parking mandates are Reduced by 30% for non-residential uses.

Within the Downtown Commercial Overlay District, nonresidential uses are allowed an exception of the first two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet of applicable building space when calculating the amount of off-street parking required. However, every use must provide one (1) parking space designated for handicapped parking.

There are no commercial minimum parking requirements in the B-2 Central Business District.
Other properties, except for 7th Ave, can be reduced by the Zoning Administrator by up to 15% with a simple parking plan.

The "B-1" Central Business District is exempt from meeting the on-site parking requirements.

For uses located within five hundred (500) feet of a public transit station or stop, the off-street parking requirements may be reduced by ten percent (10%). The Loop Trolley stops and stations are not included in this exception.

Any existing building in the GR General Retail District that is occupied by an allowed use may be reconstructed or occupied by another use allowed in the GR district without providing the minimum motor vehicle parking otherwise required.

The C-1 Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

summary: Neighborhood retail uses and the first 3000 square feet of a bar, restaurant or cafe is exempt from minimum parking requirements. Parking minimums may be reduced through on-street parking or the payment of a fee in lieu of parking. Any application for a surface parking lot exceeding 30 spaces must provide the Planning Board proof of the need for the number of spaces requested.
No parking requirements in the Central Business District. Parking reduction of 30% is possible for tree preservation.

Within the CC1 Commercial Core 1 District, no parking may be provided on site. Instead, developments are required to pay a fee into the parking fund. Parking requirements are reduced for large mixed-use developments citywide.

ADUs may be exempted from parking mandates under certain conditions. Commercial retail uses in multi-tenant buildings having a gross floor area of 2500 square feet or less are exempt from off-street parking and loading requirements. One and two-story nonresidential projects on existing lots that are 5000 square feet or less are exempt from off-street parking and loading requirements. Within the Downtown and Waterfront Mixed-use Zoning Districts, ground floor non-residential uses in mixed-use buildings occupying less than 5000 square feet are exempt from off-street parking and loading requirements. Within the Downtown Mixed-Use Zoning District, buildings constructed prior to adoption of the Downtown Specific Plan (September 2005) are exempt from parking requirements. Parking reductions are available citywide for historic preservation and motorcycle parking.

Vancouver removed all parking mandates citywide on June 26, 2024.  Previously, parking minimums were eliminated for new developments in the West End and Broadway Plan areas as of January 1, 2024 following a similar policy in downtown implemented in January 2019. Accessible spots for people with disabilities, visitor spaces, and loading spaces will continue to be required.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special,transit oriented

Nonresidential uses may count on-street parking spaces on public street rights-of-way abutting the subject property towards satisfying off-street motor vehicle parking requirements. The total number of parking spaces provided for a one-family, two-family, or multiple-family dwelling or hotel may not exceed the requirements by more than 50 percent or four spaces, whichever number is greater.

In the business, apartment and office districts the number of off-street parking spaces may not exceed the required number by more than fifty percent (50%). Such maximum parking requirements do not apply to uses whose off-street parking requirements are allocated within a parking structure.

Uses within the B-3 Central Community Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Parking mandates do not apply to the C-4 central commercial district.

Within the C-1 Central Commercial District, and at the option of the Council, the city may allow a payment toward a parking improvement program that would supply off-street parking spaces as an alternative to provision of parking to satisfy district parking requirements.
Parking space requirements do not apply in a block where 50 percent or more of the area was occupied by business or industrial structures at the time of passage of the ordinance.

Nonresidential uses in existing buildings within the Village Business District are exempt from parking mandates.

The total number of parking spaces provided for a single-family, two-family or multiple-family dwelling may not exceed the minimum requirements by more than 50% or four spaces, whichever number is greater.

In the central business district where no setback building line is required, there are no off-street parking requirements for non-residential uses except for adult entertainment uses. Dwelling units require off-street parking, except where an existing space is being converted to three (3) or fewer dwelling units in an existing commercial building in the basement or on the second or higher floor.

In a U-1 Single Family Residential District, the sum of the open and enclosed accessory parking facilities may not exceed three (3) spaces per dwelling unit on lots of 12,000 square feet or less; and not more than four (4) spaces per dwelling unit on lots of more than 12,000 square feet.

No off-street parking or loading space is required for any use located in the C-2 Central Business District. In all districts, on-street parking may be used to meet a portion of the minimum off-street parking requirements and any use in a space that is two thousand (2,000) square feet or smaller is exempt from the minimum parking requirements.
Within the Village District (V), on-street parking may count toward parking mandates for nonresidential uses and parking maximums are set at two spaces per dwelling unit for residential uses.

Buildings located in the half block abutting State Street between Third Avenue North and Second Avenue South and extending into the 300 blocks of South State Street are exempt from any off-street parking requirements. In addition, the maximum number of parking spaces for any building or use shall not exceed 125% of the number of spaces required.

Nonresidential land uses located in the downtown parking district are not required to provide off-street parking. For land uses located in a commercial, mixed-use, or industrial zoning district, the number of parking spaces provided in a ground surface parking lot shall not exceed the number of minimum parking spaces by more than 15 percent.
Parking requirements are reduced in the V-1 Village District, except for restaurants, which require special approval. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums for surface parking.

scope: city center / business district,main street / special

SSB 6015 reduces parking requirements through allowing more existing spaces to count towards requirements. Garages and carports are no longer be required, tandem parking is allowed, and parking spaces may be smaller in size.
Nonresidential uses are exempt from parking mandates and instead have parking maximums.

In the "C-3" Central Business District, accessory off-street parking is not required. Parking minimums for other districts are the maximum in the "S1" Shopping Center, "M-2,P" Planned Industrial, “C-P” Planned Commercial, “B-P” Business Park, and "R-P" Planned Residence Districts.

Additionally, parking regulations do not apply to any use in a commercial or industrial zoning district within the area bounded as follows:
Pine Street extended to Adams Street, on the west; Grant Street on the north; Maple Street, extended to the Adams Street, on the east; and Adams Street on the south including all parcels having frontage on Adams Street.
Parking minimums only apply to residential uses in the R District. Parking maximums apply to all uses.

The C-1 Community Commercial District is exempt from off-street parking requirements, except for properties that contain more than four residential units which must provide a minimum of 50% of the required parking spaces. This is not applicable to existing structures being converted or remodeled to include residential units.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: All nonresidential uses except bed and breakfast uses are exempt from parking mandates citywide. Residential uses are exempt in the B4 District and have reduced requirements in the L1, L2, and L3 Lakefront Districts. Parking maximums apply to most uses, but may be exceeded through a fee towards city owned bike parking.

The rules regarding parking and loading space requirements do not apply within the Downtown Parking District. However, parking or loading space requirements may be required for new residential construction, any institutional uses, or new commercial construction over 6,000 square feet. The Downtown Parking District means the area within the following boundary: Beginning at the Wisconsin Avenue bridge over the Fox River, east on Wisconsin Avenue to East Avenue, then north on East Avenue to Main Street, then northwesterly on Buckley Street to Corrina Boulevard, then southwesterly on Corrina Boulevard to Barstow Street, then northwesterly on Barstow Street to St. Paul Avenue, then southwesterly on St. Paul Avenue to Madison Street, then southeasterly on Madison Street to the Fox River, then southwesterly along the Fox River to the Wisconsin Avenue bridge.
No off street parking is required in the B-1 Central Business District (CBD).
Any development located with the B2 Central Business District or B7 Riverfront District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Wausau has completely eliminated parking requirements in the downtown. Wausau has also reduced parking requirements by 50% in all commercial zones in the city. As well, Wausau has also enacted parking maximums for all uses in the city.
The C-3 commercial district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Any use within the DC Downtown Commercial District other than Downtown Residential is exempt from the off-street parking requirements.

Parking requirements are reduced within the Limited Commercial Overlay District (LC). A fee-in-lieu of the required spaces may be paid to the village.

The C-4 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The Central Business (CB) District is exempt from parking mandates. Citywide, a change of use in an existing building is exempt from parking mandates.

Commercial mandates in the SMITH/DODD OVERLAY DISTRICT are waived. Properties within the B-3 and B-4 Zoning Districts that either directly abut or are adjacent to a property abutting Robert Street may reduce the minimum parking requirements by 50%.
The "Central Business District" and the "Central Industrial District" are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-2 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C-1 Downtown Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Within the B-3 Central Business District, a fee-in-lieu of off-street parking spaces may be provided, with some exceptions.
Retail stores and banks under 1000 square feet are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Within the DC-1, DC-2 and NB Zoning Districts, parking requirements are reduced for restaurants, theatres and dwelling units.

All uses in the C1 - village center and MXD - mixed use commercial-residential districts are exempt from providing required parking spaces. Newly constructed buildings with dwelling units in the C1 - village center and MXD - mixed use commercial- residential districts must provide a minimum of one on site parking stall per dwelling unit.
Within the FROD Ford Road Overlay District, parking requirements are reduced and shared parking is required.
Parking requirements are reduced by right in the Downtown Parking Area and may be further reduced through payment of a fee in lieu of parking.
Off street parking and loading are not required the CC Core Commercial District except for residential uses.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: When the application of the off-street parking regulations for proposed commercial uses results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single lot in the B-2 General Business District or C-1 Commercial District, such parking spaces need not be provided. Within the B-1 Limited Business District, existing buildings are exempt from minimum parking requirements and new buildings may pay a fee-in-lieu of required parking. In all districts, single-family dwellings are exempt from parking requirements, while two-family dwellings may not provide more than 4 spaces per unit.

There are no off-street parking and loading requirements in the "C-1" Central Business District when the commercial structure is located in blocks 3, 4, 10, 12 or 29 as indicated on the official Zoning Map of the City of Weston.

No site plan may be approved for a multi-family residential or non-residential use that contains more than 150 percent of the use’s minimum number of required parking spaces, except by conditional use permit.
There are no parking requirements for commercial uses in the Mixed-Use Commercial District.
The maximum number of spaces may not exceed 125 percent of the minimum parking requirement in the C Commercial Business District and I Industrial District.

Any on-street parking within 300 feet of a lot in the 47th and Mission Road Area Overlay District may be credited towards the on-site parking requirements. A maximum of 10% of the required parking may be satisfied by on-street parking credits. On-street parking spaces may be counted by more than one user in meeting the requirements.

Parking reductions are available for proximity to transit, on-street parking, bike parking, motorcycle parking, affordable housing and other options. Parking maximums apply in the mixed-use districts.
No off-street parking is required in the C-2 Retail Core Business District
Depending on the number of spaces required, parking may not exceed 105 to 120 percent of the minimums.
The Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums citywide.
Mixed-use developments need only provide parking for one of the uses.
All nonresidential uses in the WB-3 General Business District are exempt from the parking and loading requirements.
Parking spaces may not exceed 90% of the maximum per-person capacity of the building or site.

The off-street vehicle parking provisions are modified in the Downtown for the CC, CM1, CM2, CMW, CPG, PS, and RD zones as follows:
a) parking requirements are reduced for all uses
b) a fee-in-lieu of parking may be provided for non-residential uses
c) a change of use in the CC – Core Commercial zone does not require off-street parking and loading spaces.
d) a change of use in the CM1, CM2 and CMW zones is exempt from providing off-street parking and loading spaces if the parking and loading requirement for the new use is less than or equal to the parking and loading requirement for the former use.
e) Parking provided may not exceed 25% greater than the minimum required. Maximum parking regulations do not apply to single detached housing, duplexes, living suites, or garden suites.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums for nonresidential uses.

Uses within the B-2 central business district and the B-1A university mixed-use overlay district are exempted from the minimum number of parking stalls required, except if specifically required for a particular conditional use in that district.
Off-street parking is not required within the Downtown Business (C-DB-SZ) district.
There are no parking minimums for the Central Business District (downtown and some nearby neighborhoods). This is implemented in the City Center, and applies to all land uses.
The Town of Wickenburg eliminated parking requirements in the downtown zoning district and decreased all other commercial parking regulations by 25% in January 2021.
Parking requirements in the TC Town Center District are reduced by 50 percent.
Any property located in a C-3 Zone (Central Business District) is exempt from providing off-street parking.

Existing structures in the CBD Central Business District are exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements are reduced for new buildings in the CBD. Lots less than 5,000 square feet in the MU Mixed-Use Residential District qualify for the same parking modifications as uses in the CBD. Uses proposed on lots greater than 5,000 square feet in the MU District are permitted a parking reduction. Residential uses in residential districts have reduced parking requirements.

Within the Village Center (VC) District, the minimum parking requirements are waived. In all districts, no site plan may be approved for a multifamily or nonresidential use that proposes more than 120% of the development's minimum number of required parking spaces, except as granted through a conditional use permit.
No off-street parking is required in the C-2 Central Business Commercial District, except two spaces per unit for dwellings.
The Commercial CBD District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
scope: city center / business district,main street / special
summary: Uses in commercial zones that are within 600 feet of public parking or on-street parking are exempt from parking mandates. Parking requirements are reduced by right in the C-1 Central Business District. Parking maximums are set at 200% of the minimums.
Nonresidential uses in the CC Core Commercial District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums, except for single family dwellings.
The 2014 Downtown Parking District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Previously, portions of the Central Business District were exempt from parking requirements. On June 20, 2023, the city removed all parking minimums, however, the planning director may require a minimum number. Parking maximums are determined by the planning director.

No off-street parking area may exceed the required minimum number of parking spaces by more than thirty percent (30%) for multifamily, mixed-use, and nonresidential uses, except as approved by the Village Administrator.
The Central Commercial (C-1) District is exempt from parking mandates.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
In the VC Village Center Business District, non-residential uses containing a total gross floor area (GFA) of 2,500 square feet or less are exempt from parking requirements. A fee in lieu of required parking may be provided for other nonresidential uses in the VC district.
In the VC Village Center Business District and NR-1 Linden Square Neighborhood Business District, uses located in existing structures are exempt from minimum parking requirements, with the exception of any large medical clinics and residential dwellings. In these districts, on-street parking spaces may be counted toward required off-street parking spaces for commercial uses. In all districts, non-residential uses may count public off-street parking spaces.
In the VC District, parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimum, except for residential uses.
Most uses within the C-3 Central retail and C-4 Central office districts are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
All uses in the Central Business District, except for residential uses, are exempt from off-street parking space requirements.

scope: city center / business district,citywide,main street / special
summary: Wilmington, North Carolina eliminated parking requirements for central business districts and historic districts. They also eliminated parking requirements for nonresidential buildings or uses city-wide. Maximum parking requirements are now in place for non-residential uses city-wide.

Within the Downtown Core (DC) district, no parking may be provided except for single-family or two-family dwellings. Instead, a fee in lieu of parking must be provided for all other uses equivalent to the parking minimums otherwise required. On-street parking may be counted toward parking requirements in the district. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums citywide.

There are no minimum parking requirements for land uses in the R/A, OS, IMX and CCMX Districts.

There are no minimum parking requirements for industrial, religious institutions, and some commercial land uses ('amusements [indoor & outdoor]'). 

Parking maximums are set as twice the minimum requirement. Exemptions to parking maximums can be applied to single/two family dwellings and if the parking areas exceeding the maximum requirements are installed using Low Impact Development (LID) treatment OR the minimum number of trees is 1 tree per 10 spaces.
The B-2 Downtown Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

All business use located within the Central Business District as defined and designated in the comprehensive plan or zoned B-3, Central Business District, are exempt from off-street parking requirements.
Any use within the TC Town Center District is exempt from off-street parking requirements.
The "C-2" Central Commercial Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Non-residential uses in the C-2 General Retail District are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No off-street parking facilities are required in the C-4 Central Business District.

Main Street in the City of Winfield is exempt from minimum parking requirements. Any structure on Main Street is only required to maintain the parking that it had at the time of the adoption of the subsection.
Uses in the TC Town Center District are exempt from minimum parking requirements. In addition, all industrial, agricultural and infrastructure uses are exempt.
Surface parking maximums are set at 115% of the minimums for uses located in a commercial, mixed-use, or industrial zoning districts.
Parking requirements are reduced where parking is shared.
Within the General Commercial District (B-1), no off-street parking is required for uses in existing buildings and reconstruction of existing buildings.

Within the C-1 Neighborhood Commercial District and the C-2 General Retail Commercial District, nonresidential uses located on the ground floor and occupying a space with a gross floor area of less than 2,500 square feet are exempt from off-street parking and loading requirements. Minimum parking requirements also do not apply to changes in use for an existing building.

Since 2008, 20% reduction allowed (anywhere in city) if building is mixed-use and we allow developers to double it with infill reduction, totaling 40%. Parking is not required in the Downtown zoning district.
The B-3 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates.

Parking minimums in Winona's Mixed Use-Downtown Core and Mixed Use-Downtown Fringe are 0 for commercial, retail, and office uses and residential developments up to six units. Bicycle parking may substitute for up to four automobile spaces for all residential uses.

In the Central Business district, Winston-Salem has no minimum parking requirements for high-density residential and office that is above first-floor retail. In all other areas, there are requirements.

In the MU-S District, an automotive thirty percent (30%) reduction of existing minimum parking requirements may be applied. There are no parking maximums for this land use.
In 2000, Winter Haven adopted a new Downtown Commercial zoning district that exempted all land uses within it from parking requirements.
In the D-C and R-C districts, a fee-in-lieu of required non-residential or commercial parking may be provided.
The DC Downtown Commercial District is exempt from all off street parking requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: No private off-street parking is allowed in the city center. Parking minimums and maximums vary in the other five zones depending on location and transit availability.

The total number of accessory parking spaces provided for a single-family, a duplex, or a multiple- family dwelling may not exceed the requirements for such use by more than 50% or four spaces, whichever is greater.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for dwellings, meeting halls, churches, auditoriums, or governmental uses.

Parking requirements do not apply to the C-2 Downtown Commercial zoning district.  In addition, the number of parking spaces provided in a ground surface parking lot may not exceed the minimum number by more than 20 percent.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Land uses located in the downtown zoning (B-1) district are not required to provide off-street parking.  Parking requirements may be reduced through the provision of bike parking. For land uses located in a business, mixed-use, or industrial zoning district, the number of parking spaces provided in a ground surface parking lot shall not exceed the number of minimum parking spaces by more than 15 percent.
Parking stalls are not required to be provided in the C-C Community Commercial District.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
C-1 Central Commercial District residential uses with five or less units are not required to provide any off-street parking.
Uses in existing buildings in the B-4 Downtown Business District are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Parking maximums apply to residential uses.
On-street parking directly fronting a lot may count toward fulfilling the parking requirement of that lot.
Commercial uses in the BD Downtown Business District are exempt from parking mandates if located within 300 feet of a municipal parking lot.

Airports, hospitals, religious institutions and schools are exempt from minimum parking requirements. Within the nonresidential zoning districts (C1 through C4, SC, NC, BTI, and I1 through I3), parking requirements may be reduced through on-street parking, bike parking, transit, or the use of pervious surfaces.
Personal service and internal retail uses in a residential building in the MX Mixed Use District have reduced parking requirements.

When the application of the off-road parking regulations results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single lot in the Commercial Districts, such parking spaces need not be provided, unless two or more uses are located on such lot in which case only one of the uses shall be eligible for the exemption.
The CBD Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements. The Woodford County Zoning Code also applies to the cities of Versailles and Midway.

No minimum off-street parking space requirement may be exceeded by more than 15 percent unless good cause can be shown by the applicant and approved by the Board of Zoning Appeals. Single-Family Dwellings, Two-Family Dwellings and accessory apartments are exempt from this provision.
A new commercial use in an existing building is exempt from parking mandates in the central business district.
A change of use in a building existing prior to the code adoption is exempt from parking mandates.
Areas which are located in a fire district as designated on the Official Map are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
No off-street parking or loading is required in the C-2 Central Business District.
Woonsocket, RI does not require parking for non-residential uses in the Urban Commercial and Mixed Use districts.
Properties in the C-4 District are exempt from off-street parking requirements.
Parking maximums apply to all uses except single-family dwellings and manufactured homes.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: No parking is required for uses in downtown (BG-6.0). Within the Commercial Corridor Overlay District (CCOD), parking minimums are reduced by 50% on average across most commercial/mixed use zoning districts. Parking maximums are generally equivalent to 125% of the normal base requirement.
Nonresidential and mixed-use developments may count on-street and public parking towards parking requirements and may utilize bike parking to reduce car parking requirements.

When the application of the off-street parking regulations results in a requirement of not more than three (3) spaces on a single lot in any Business District, such parking spaces need not be provided. However, where two (2) or more uses are located on a single lot, only one of these uses is eligible for the exemption. This exemption does not apply to dwelling units.
Within the B-2 Central Business District, nonresidential uses are exempt from minimum parking requirements, except for automotive and farm implement, mortuary, parking, and terminal uses.
The C-5 Central Commercial District is exempt from parking mandates. Parking maximums are set at 125% of the minimums in the Wilson Bridge Corridor Districts.
Commercial uses in the RMU Remote Residential Mixed-Use District are exempt from parking mandates.
There is no minimum off-street parking requirement in the B-B Business District.
No parking is required for any existing building or use, unless said building or use is enlarged, in which case the parking provisions apply to the enlarged portion of the building or use.

Within the Central Business District (CBD), all uses are exempt from parking mandates, except for residential uses, funeral homes/mortuary establishments, hotels and motels with 34 or more rooms, hospitals and clinics, and private clubs. For properties within the “developed business area”, but not zoned CBD Central Business District, parking requirements are reduced.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.
Parking requirements are reduced for uses within the RAMUI Redevelopment Area Mixed Use Incentive Overlay District. Residential uses may further reduce requirements by providing structured parking.

The B-2 Central Business District is exempt from parking mandates. Nonresidential uses in other districts have no set requirements, but rather must demonstrate that the proposed use has sufficient parking.
Yakima Washington has no parking minimums for all uses in the Downtown Business District.
In the Commercial Core district, off-street parking is not required.
The B-3 central business district is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Uses located in the central business district are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
There are no minimum parking requirements in the B-1 Central Business District. Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums citywide.
Yellowknife, NT has eliminated parking minimums in the Downtown and Old Town areas. Parking reductions have been made in other zones.
The C-1 Downtown Commercial District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.

Small nonresidential uses (except restaurant and eating and drinking establishments) in a historic district in the D-MX District are exempt from off-street parking and loading requirements.
Parking requirements are reduced in the CB District, GC District, and Downtown Districts. A change of use within an existing building within the Downtown Districts or Artisans & Industry Special District is exempt from parking requirements. Apartments and live-work units within 1/4 of a mile of a train station have reduced requirements. Citywide, a fee in lieu of required parking may be provided.
There are no parking mandates in the city. Parking maximums apply to all uses.
There are no parking requirements in the Central Business District.
Yorkton exempts parking requirements for small developments in the city center. There is also an in-lieu option to further reduce requirements.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary: Nonresidential uses within the Downtown Overlay Districts are exempt from parking minimums and instead have parking maximums, except for small retail uses. Within these districts, residential uses have reduced requirements and reductions are available for on-street parking, public parking, and carshare services.

Parking is not required in the downtown area, except for bus or rail transit stations, multi‐family dwellings, and lodging. Nonresidential uses on small lots in Mixed-Use Districts are exempted, as well as uses on lots in a residential district with a width of 25 feet or less and no alley access. Maximum parking is set at 125% of the minimums.
Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums.

policy_change: add parking maximums,reduce parking minimums,remove parking minimums
summary:
Single-family detached dwellings, townhouses, two-family dwellings and ADUs are exempt from parking mandates citywide. Parking mandates also do not apply to uses in the Center District or existing commercial uses in the Historic Corridor zoning districts, except for upper-story dwellings, which may pay a fee in lieu of providing off-street parking.
Parking requirements may be reduced through the availability of transit, or the provision of carshare spaces, carpooling spaces, EV chargers, or bike parking. Parking requirements are reduced by half for uses in the Walkable Urban Zoning Districts. Parking maximums are set at 120% of the minimums for nonresidential uses.
Yukon implemented a form based code eliminating parking requirements in the Urban Gateway Overlay Supplemental District and then repealed it two years later.
Properties located within the Main Street Mall and Off Street Parking Maintenance District No. 1 are exempt from minimum parking requirements.
Minimum off-street parking requirements do not apply to uses within the B-2 Downtown Commercial District.

In the UC Urban Center District and TND Traditional Neighborhood Development District, on-street and public parking may count towards parking minimums. Upon approval, a reduction is possible citywide through the implementation TDM strategies.
Zanesville eliminated parking requirements in the central business district.
No off-street parking is required in the BC Central Business Commercial District.
Parking maximums are set at 110% of the minimums.

Most commercial uses under 1500 square feet in the C-1 Central Business District are exempt from parking mandates. Beyond 1500 square feet, a use may pay a fee in lieu of required parking. Commercial uses in C-1, C-2 and C-3 Commercial Districts may count public parking towards parking requirements.
Parking requirements are reduced within the city center for commercial uses. A fee in lieu of parking may be provided citywide for all uses.
The total number of off-street parking spaces required for any use in and within 600 feet or one parcel, whichever is less, of the VBD Urban Village Business District is reduced by 50%.
The Historic Commercial Land Use District is exempt from parking mandates. No private parking may be built in the district.
The C-1 Central Business District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
The C1 Central Commerce District is exempt from minimum parking requirements.
